dialogue:
Judge: Gary Northr, you are suing your ex-wife Karen Northr for $2,710 that you say was overpaid to her in child support. Tell me what's going on.

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): Yes, in 2013 I was made aware of some of my children legally allowed to be emancipated, and I have been overpaying.

Judge: Why were they emancipated?

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): One graduated college, one had actually found out how old they were—21, 22, and I think my son was 19.

Judge: Did you not realize that child support ends at some point?

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): Yes, but the court order said 22 if they were going to school, and I have very little to no contact with my kids.

Judge: Well, that’s sad.

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): It is. There’s a long, drawn-out history, and I’ve been fighting in courts for years, and thank God I’ve been winning all the time.

Judge: Well, it doesn’t sound like you’re a winner when you have no contact with your children. How many children do you have?

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): I have four with her.

Judge: How many children do you have altogether?

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): Five.

Judge: And you have no contact with any of the four?

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): Just my son. He showed up on my door when she kicked him out. He wanted a new life away from her. He was trying to get back with his wife.

Judge: Okay, but we digress. Let's go to the overpayment in 2013. What is it that happens in 2013? You realize that either your child is not in school or the age has come or something?

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): Yes, and so I go to court and say, "Hey," and I show the order to the judge, and the judge says, "You're right." From this day forward, it will be X.

Judge: The court told me when I went and filed that it would be retroactive from the date of filing. The judge told me that, and it's in... is it in an order? Let me see the order. I've got so many.

Judge: Okay, what happens after the order is entered on October 17th? How long does it take child support to figure out how to obey the order?

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): About a month.

Judge: And so from then on, they obey the order, but you point out to the child support people, "Wait, I need to be getting credit because the judge lowered the child support payment retroactive to August 16th."

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): And what do they say?

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): Put it nicely, tough. When I got the order, I faxed it to them right away, and they called me and said, "We don't do that. Talk to me."

Judge: According to him, he overpaid you in 2013, and then it happened again but with a much smaller amount in 2016. How would that happen?

Defendant (Karen Northr): Because it got modified again in 2016.

Judge: It got modified again?

Defendant (Karen Northr): Yes, because you went out on disability.

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): Yes, per my disability.

Judge: So now, according to him, you have been overpaid $2,710. What’s your position on this?

Defendant (Karen Northr): That’s not the truth, and there is nothing in the order that reads he’s to receive anything retroactive.

Judge: It is in the order.

Defendant (Karen Northr): Well, the judge here, it’s circled right here on this page, highlighted in yellow, retroactive to August whatever.

Judge: It's right in the order, which they did modify the order. So I’m not understanding.

Defendant (Karen Northr): Right, but not retroactive till August 16th.

Judge: Right, like they didn’t give him any credit for payments. It appears the judge is saying he was overpaying. He wasn’t supposed to be paying that child support because the child was emancipated. We don’t let people sit on their hands forever. We don’t say, “Oh, let’s go back to the date of emancipation.” He’s got to do something, but he did something on August 16th. That’s when he filed it.

Judge: Okay, so based on these documents, you are suing for $1,130 in overpayment. Every two weeks, they were taking out $483, when clearly a judge had said they were only supposed to be taking out $210 from that day forward. So they can’t just take their sweet time. They say they can, but they can’t. That’s why he’s here suing you. And now let me ask you a question. How long have you been divorced from him?

Defendant (Karen Northr): We legally separated December 20, 1997. I went to a battered women’s shelter with the four children at the time—two, four, five, and six—because of his abuse. We didn’t actually get divorced until 2005.

Judge: Did you ever call the police on him for physical abuse?

Defendant (Karen Northr): Many, many times, and they did absolutely nothing, because he’d run out and greet the cops at the curb, and he had his story.

Defendant (Karen Northr): So basically, it was 1997. It came down to this. This is before any good laws actually started happening for our benefit, so we divorced in 2005 eventually.

Judge: Okay, but what? So did he see his kids?

Defendant (Karen Northr): No, that’s never been the case.

Judge: Not from the...?

Defendant (Karen Northr): Had visitation with them through 2005. Then he moved to Florida, and then he didn’t really make any effort to have contact with them. So visitation at that point ceased.

Judge: Come on up. How old are you?

Defendant’s Child: I’m 20.

Judge: Hi, my dear. Hi. So if you’re 20, you don’t really remember them together very much, do you?

Defendant’s Child: Not really, no.

Judge: Do you remember any abuse?

Defendant’s Child: No, but your mom’s told you about it?

Defendant’s Child: Yeah.

Judge: Do you have any contact with him?

Defendant’s Child: No.

Judge: Have you ever had any contact with him?

Defendant’s Child: Not since I was younger.

Judge: Why don’t you have a relationship with your children?

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): I mean, I imagine the day your children were born, you were happy, right? Like you were a happy couple having four kids, not one, not two...

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): I wasn’t working. I had the kids the first two years of... no, no, listen to my question. Why don’t you talk to your children?

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): She won’t allow it.

Judge: But since when does she get to be the arbiter of whether or not you talk to your children?

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): It’s been almost 20 years.

Judge: I have... Why did you let it happen?

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): Well, this is my beautiful wife Rosa.

Judge: How long has Rosa been in the picture?

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): We’ve been together 11 years. We’ve been married for six.

Judge: And does Rosa ever talk to you about this and say maybe you should have a relationship with your children?

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): We tried. We’ve talked. That’s why she... My... she’s a blessing, because she helped me with my son. She... she paid almost half to set him up in a new life in Florida. We spent over $7,000,000, and she gave me half of that money to help my son. We’re very close to his in-laws. We still talk to the in-laws. We are allowed to see my grandson. They have it down there.

Judge: Is there anything else you want to say?

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): No, I just want truth. That’s all I ask.

Judge: Do you comment on the allegations that she made against you?

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): Yeah, it’s all false. If you can investigate family court, she was convicted for interfering with my parental rights on four counts.

Judge: Did you beat her?

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): No.

Judge: Did you ever hit her?

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): I admitted to defending myself with her one time because she was the abusive one, and she would go tell them what she did to me.

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): Also in criminal court, how many times were the police called to your house?

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): I can’t believe I... I don’t know. How many times did you get arrested for it?

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): She had me arrested on phone calls, four times, and I went to jail for overnight phone calls that were violating a restraining order. That’s what she claimed. But no.

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): What did you... What were you charged with if you went to jail?

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): Threatening phone calls, making threatening phone calls.

Judge: Okay, was there a restraining order in effect?

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): Yes.    Judge: So, you had a restraining order in effect, and you were still calling her?

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): Yeah, I was trying to contact my children, and I didn't realize that I was violating it. I was just trying to keep in touch.

Judge: Well, you should have known. When there's a restraining order, you can’t make contact.

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): I understand that now. I just wanted to be a part of my children’s lives.

Judge: So why don’t you reach out now, instead of bringing all this back to court? Why don’t you make an effort?

Plaintiff (Gary Northr): I tried, but she has made it difficult. I’ve tried to reach out, and every time I do, she shuts it down.

Judge: How about you? Do you have any thoughts on this? Why won’t you let him have contact with his children?

Defendant (Karen Northr): He didn’t show interest in being a father. He doesn’t deserve to come back into our lives after all this time. We’ve moved on, and the kids have moved on. I protected them from his abuse, and I’m not going to allow him to hurt them again.

Judge: So you’re still holding onto the past?

Defendant (Karen Northr): No, I’m protecting my children. He doesn’t have a right to just come back into their lives after all the damage he caused.

Judge: You know, there’s a lot of emotion here, but we’re talking about child support and money, not just feelings. The law doesn’t operate on emotions, but on facts.

Defendant (Karen Northr): I understand that, but what I’m saying is he hasn’t been involved in their lives for so long, it’s not just about the money. It’s about the history.

Judge: Okay, so let's focus on the money. You acknowledge that he overpaid, right?

Defendant (Karen Northr): No, I don’t. I don’t believe that’s true. He’s just trying to get money back, but it’s not accurate. The child support was paid as it was ordered.

Judge: But according to the court order, there was a retroactive adjustment. And based on that, you should’ve refunded the money, or at least applied it correctly. That’s why we’re here.

Defendant (Karen Northr): I understand the order, but the money was being paid and processed. I didn’t have any part in that. It was up to the child support office.

Judge: I’m hearing that you’re saying the office should’ve handled it, but you also knew the situation, and you were aware of the overpayment.

Defendant (Karen Northr): I didn’t know the full details. I wasn’t keeping track of all the payments. I trusted the system.

Judge: Well, the system has failed here. He overpaid, and there’s documentation to prove it. You need to refund the money or make it right.

Defendant (Karen Northr): I understand, but I can’t give back what I didn’t receive directly. The payments went through the system.

Judge: That’s not how it works. You were the one receiving the payments, and you’re responsible for ensuring that the child support was applied properly.

Defendant (Karen Northr): I don’t agree with that. But if that’s how it’s going to be, then I’ll figure it out.

Judge: Okay. I’m going to review the evidence, and I’ll make my decision.

Judge: Okay, so the child support will depend on your income. How much money do you make a year?

Defendant: I mean, before, uh, you know, expenses and taxes.

Judge: That was not my question, sir. How much money do you make a year?

Defendant: Sixty-five thousand dollars, but I have to pay for gas and pipe and PVC. I don't want to pay for all this stuff that I have to pay for it.

Judge: Thank you, Douglas. Tiffany Archer, you are suing your—what is he of yours?

Plaintiff: He was an acquaintance with benefits.

Judge: Your former something, right?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Jarell Bryant, for $4,050 that you say he owes you in loans, a cable bill, a Bluetooth speaker he broke, and $2,000 for intentional tort.

Judge: All right. And you are counterclaiming her for pain and suffering for bed bugs. Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff: Okay. Um, we started dating in October. We met before then. He was working for a cab service. His work started to slow down, and then he expressed interest in working for Uber.

Plaintiff: Now, there are things that I acknowledge that are gifts. There are things that I purchased for him. There are things that I’ve given to him. I’m suing for the $1,650 because one portion was for a vehicle so that he could obtain work with the company. And the extra $150—

Judge: He didn’t even have a car, but he wanted to be an Uber driver? Don’t you need a car first?

Plaintiff: Right.

Judge: So you were buying him the car so he could be an Uber driver?

Plaintiff: Right.

Judge: So if I called Uber and he answered, I was going to be riding around in a $1,000 car?

Plaintiff: No, actually, I gave him $1,500 for the car.

Judge: That makes me feel so much better.

Plaintiff: No, I gave him—

Judge: Did you buy a car with $1,500 that you could use for Uber?

Defendant: Um, I bought a car, but I didn’t use it for Uber.

Judge: What car did you buy?

Defendant: Uh, I bought an Impala.

Judge: What year?

Defendant: 2007.

Judge: Did you tell her that you wanted to borrow money so you could buy a car?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Where did this Uber stuff come from?

Defendant: Um, well, I was driving cabs, and, you know, Uber’s a hot thing, so I was interested in becoming an Uber driver, but you know, I—I drive a gypsy cab.

Judge: And did she loan you the money for the car?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Did she give you the money for the car?

Defendant: Why would she give me that money?

Judge: Um, you tell me.

Defendant: We were an item.

Judge: So what? I don’t—nobody rains money on me. I’ve been an item with a lot of people. They don’t rain money on me like that. I’m cute!

Judge: Did you have him sign a promissory note?

Plaintiff: I did not.

Judge: What were you doing that you were able to give away money to your boyfriend—so much?

Plaintiff: I work as a home health aide. I do live-in, and I work four days at a time. So I go in on Thursday and come off on Monday.

Plaintiff: But prior to this, the situation I was in, um, my home was in foreclosure, and we were paid out. And I had already saved money up, so I was okay.

Judge: So you couldn’t wait to get rid of it.

Plaintiff: It’s just that I—I help people if I’m okay.

Judge: And how often do you get burned?

Plaintiff: A lot.

Judge: Okay. I have a philosophy that you should only pay for someone else if you don’t mind seeing it go away. Because you will end up with a lot of broken friendships.

Judge: So if you want to help somebody out in their time of need, why don’t you just get it in writing?

Judge: So when is the first time that there’s any discussion between the two of you that you want him to pay you back?

Plaintiff: Well, when I gave it to him, I told him right off as soon as I handed him the money.

Plaintiff: As soon as he got the money—because the text comes to my phone—I wired it from Western Union because I was at work at the time.

Judge: Yeah, you’re burning Western Union’s wires. How many times did you wire money?

Plaintiff: I would say five, six, seven. Around about five times, probably, in the process of me—

Judge: Did she tell you when she gave you the money that you would have to pay it back?

Defendant: No.

Judge: And that’s what we guard against by having a promissory note. Or even a text that says it.

Judge: If you’re too embarrassed—if you think, "Oh, I don’t want to seem like I don’t trust him by making him sign a promissory note"—I don’t know why, but if that’s what’s in your head, then just send a text saying, "I’m so glad I was able to help you. When do you think you can pay me back?"

Judge: "Oh, don’t worry, I’ll be able to pay you back in a few months."

Judge: Done. That’s a contract. There’s no dispute about whether it’s a loan or a gift, right?

Judge: If you’re suing for money you gave him for a car, money you gave him for insurance, money you gave him for a cable bill that you opened up in your name—

Judge: You think you’re going to—You’re moving in? What do you think?      Plaintiff: No, the thing is, because he's in a niche, and he gets his rent paid through public assistance. Because I'm standing here, a lot of people that stay with you, they don't like to pull their weight. So I said, while I'm staying, at least let me—

Judge: But you're not even supposed to be staying there though, right?

Plaintiff: Well, I wasn't, but I wasn't planning on living there. But I just—

Judge: But you just put a bill in your name there. And when you put a bill in your name there, you had to pay $100. Why?

Plaintiff: That's actually the cable bill.

Judge: No, the cable bill was $139. But the bank statements that I got, it doesn't show the other half where I paid. But why does he have to pay you back the $100?

Plaintiff: Oh, because when I left, we made an agreement that, being that I was not going to stay there, he was going to continue to pay the bill. He has others entertaining—family and friends—cable, right? And I'm not staying there.

Judge: Why don't you just cancel the cable? Why didn't you just do that? Why would you trust a guy to pay the bill? Did he pay the bill?

Plaintiff: He did, for the first—And it's just that the last bill he didn't pay.

Judge: But he owes you $100 on the cable?

Defendant: No.

Judge: How not?

Defendant: I don’t—

Judge: Show me the proof of everything you paid on the cable.

Defendant: I don’t have any proof.

Judge: Okay, well then, you owe her $100 on the cable if you don't have any proof.

Judge: Broken Bluetooth speaker—What happened there?

Defendant: Um, she left a speaker. I don’t remember her leaving a speaker. She came back, and it was broke. I had a bunch of kids in my house.

Judge: And then what did you do with the speaker?

Defendant: I threw it away. It was broke.

Judge: Yeah, that speaker didn’t break itself. You owe her for the speaker. Another $100. I don’t like that at all.

Judge: Intentional tort—What do you mean when you say intentional tort? Somebody did a little reading on the internet.

Plaintiff: Intentional tort, yes. Because, um, I feel that he misrepresented himself when he asked for the car. I thought he was actually going to get a job, try to better himself, make better of his situation so he could take better care of himself and pay me back. So this is why I loaned him the money for the car.

Judge: So you want—So the intentional tort is you chose unwisely?

Plaintiff: Well, I feel like he misrepresented himself.

Judge: All right. So now let me ask you about your lawsuit.

Defendant: Oh, okay, yeah.

Judge: Bed bugs and pain and suffering—Talk to me.

Defendant: All right, so Tiffany had moved into an apartment, and they had, um, I guess a pre-existing bed bug situation. And you know, she was staying at my house Monday through Wednesday towards the middle—Towards the beginning—And you know, I mean, it felt a little funny, a little itchy and stuff, but I can say by the time she left, I had a bed bug situation. You know, I had to call housing, get them to deal with it.

Judge: Can I see proof of that?

Defendant: Yeah.

Judge: Did you have a bed bug situation in the house that you were in?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: I'm trying to imagine. So I have a bed bug situation—Can I come stay with you? Let me take my—I'll just bring my sheets and my luggage and everything else a bed bug can hitch a ride on. Let’s do that. That sounds like a—like a capital idea!

Defendant: Says we exterminating for gnats and water bugs and mice.

Judge: Whoa! You're living in a—No. You see, they came for roaches and rats. They came to spray for everything. When you tell them you have a problem with bugs, they come and handle everything.

Judge: Okay, target organism, though, is what you complained about. And that was roaches.

Defendant: Right.

Judge: And that was in March. Anyway, where—Where am I finding a bed bug problem that she brought into your place?

Defendant: This is July of 2018.

Judge: When were you there?

Plaintiff: December of 2017.

Judge: Yes. Right. This is July of 2018. This is the other day. So where’s your proof that she caused a bed bug problem that would entitle you to $3,000?

Judge: I mean, listen, bed bug lawsuits are awful because it is really hard to determine who brought in the bed bug. Nobody knows but the bed bug, and the bed bug ain't talking.

Judge: So it's very hard to—But assuming, okay, that she—I mean, yours is a better case than most because she had bed bugs and then went to your house to stay, which was—No offense—On your part. But okay.

Judge: Except here’s the problem I'm having. I'm not finding you complaining to the housing authority to spray, and it's free. When you complain to them to spray, they just do it. You don’t have to pay for it, nothing. Right?

Defendant: Right.

Judge: I don’t see you complaining about it until four months after she moves out.

Judge: Welcome back to The People’s Court. Harvey Levin here. So, um, if you loan a friend money, do you expect payment back, or do you just think, "Whatever, if he pays back, great. If not—"?

[Public Opinions and Responses]

Judge: Technically, she never originally moved in because, like I told her, I wasn't ready for no relationship. But she gets out of work, she comes straight to my house Monday morning, and she’ll stay till Wednesday.

Judge: Okay. When did you two break up?

Defendant: Huh?

Judge: When did you two stop making love to each other, or having sex, or whatever you guys want to call it? I don’t know what to call it.

Defendant: I don't know.

Judge: I don’t find a complaint until March 19th.

Plaintiff: If I may say—

Judge: And they sprayed for everything. The target on March 19th—They may have sprayed for bed bugs, but the target on March 19th was roaches.

Defendant: I told them I had bugs. They said they were going to come handle the bugs.

Judge: You know what? If you had bed bugs, you'd know. You claim you had to throw out furniture. Do you have any proof you had to throw out furniture?

Defendant: Um, no. I didn’t bring it.

Judge: No, because she has pictures of you on the furniture you say you threw out.

Defendant: Yeah, but that was, like—How many months ago?

Plaintiff: November.

Judge: I don’t know. When was that?

Plaintiff: January 21st.

Judge: January.

Defendant: It takes a while for the bugs to grow, you know? They come little, and then they take time to sprout out.

Judge: I had them, so I would know. It is a disaster.   Defendant: Yeah, it was bad.

Judge: But what I'm saying is, when you claim you threw away furniture, I want to see some proof that you actually threw away furniture.

Defendant: Well, I don’t have any.

Judge: You don’t have any. So I’m looking at a lawsuit for $3,000 for pain and suffering and damages, and you don't have any proof that you actually threw out furniture. You also waited months before complaining to housing about it.

Judge: So you want me to make the leap that she brought the bed bugs, but your own timeline is inconsistent.

Defendant: Well, I didn't really think about it like that. I just know I had them, and I didn't have them before she started coming around.

Judge: Okay. But bed bugs don’t just immediately show up and take over in a few days. They take time to spread. You didn't complain until months later. So, I’m denying your claim for $3,000.

Judge: Now, back to your case, ma’am.

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: You’re suing for the car money, the insurance money, and the cable bill. I’m awarding you the cable bill portion—$100—since he failed to show proof of payment.

Judge: As for the car money, you’re calling it a loan. He’s calling it a gift. Do you have anything in writing?

Plaintiff: No, but we had a verbal agreement.

Judge: A verbal agreement is only as good as the proof you have to back it up. You don’t have text messages? Emails? Anything that states he was supposed to pay you back?

Plaintiff: No, I just trusted him.

Judge: That was your mistake. Without proof that it was a loan and not a gift, I can’t force him to pay you back. I’m dismissing that portion of your case.

Plaintiff: But—

Judge: No, I understand. It’s unfair. It’s frustrating. But legally, I can’t enforce an agreement I don’t have proof of.

Judge: So here’s my final ruling—Plaintiff is awarded $100 for the cable bill and $100 for the broken speaker. Defendant’s counterclaim is dismissed.

Judge: Judgment for the plaintiff in the amount of $200.
manipulation_techniques: evasion, deflection, exaggeration, framing the narrative

dialogue:
**Judge:** This is the plaintiff, Bilal Arif. He says he and the defendant were co-workers, and when the defendant fell on hard times, he helped him out by loaning him a grand. He told him he’d deduct a portion of the loan amount from his paycheck until the loan was paid off. Everything was good until the plaintiff left his position. Now he can’t get the defendant to pay him the $1,000 he still owes. That’s why he’s here suing.

This is the defendant, Christopher. He says the plaintiff was terminated from his position and eventually went to work for him, and the plaintiff stiffed him on his wages. He has some nerve suing him here today in court because if anyone is owed money, it’s certainly not the plaintiff.

He’s accused of not paying a guy back. The defendant has filed a counterclaim for $2,700 for unpaid wages. All parties, please be ready.

Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case in the docket: The plaintiff loaned a grand to his coworker and got stiffed, but the defendant says the plaintiff was fired and he ended up working for him—and he stiffed him on wages. It’s the case of ‘Ain’t Nothing Grand About You.’ Thank you, Douglas.

**Judge:** Okay, Bilal Arif, you are suing Christopher for a $1,000 loan that you say you made to him and he hasn’t repaid. You have counterclaimed against him for $2,700 in unpaid wages. Let me talk to you first. You guys worked together at a cell phone retail store?

**Plaintiff:** That is correct.

**Judge:** Were you the owner of that store?

**Plaintiff:** No.

**Judge:** What was your role there?

**Plaintiff:** I was just a manager.

**Judge:** And what was his role there?

**Plaintiff:** He was a sales associate.

**Judge:** Okay, so you were over him?

**Plaintiff:** Yes.

**Judge:** And how long did you work together there?

**Plaintiff:** About a year or so.

**Judge:** Okay. And were you friends?

**Plaintiff:** Yeah, we were pretty good friends.

**Judge:** Would you socialize outside the store?

**Plaintiff:** We met like two to three times.

**Judge:** All right. Now, at some point, you loaned him money?

**Plaintiff:** Yes.

**Judge:** How much money did you loan him?

**Plaintiff:** $1,500.

**Judge:** Did he pay you back any of it?

**Plaintiff:** Yes, Your Honor. The last week that he was working with me and the new management, he told me to keep whatever I worked for and let him know how much he owed me after that. So it was like $406, and then he gave me $100 afterward. That’s how he paid off $500 of the $1,500, and then according to you, he still owes you $1,000?

**Plaintiff:** Yes.

**Judge:** Okay. What’s going on?

**Defendant:** So basically, it was not a loan. He says that he was just an employee—he wasn’t just an employee. He was invested 50% owner with the first boss we were working for.

**Judge:** Is that accurate?

**Plaintiff:** Yes, Your Honor, it is.

**Defendant:** Then when those two partners split, he took his investment from the first boss and went with the second boss. So basically, the money he gave me was an incentive to come work with him.

**Judge:** So according to you, the $1,500 was an incentive for you to come work with him?

**Defendant:** Correct.

**Judge:** Did you let him take $500 for repayment of something that was supposed to be an incentive?

**Defendant:** He took it off himself. I never received any pay from the time that I worked for them. They kept giving me the runaround.

**Judge:** When you say ‘they,’ you mean him and the new owner?

**Defendant:** Correct. They kept telling me they were going to have a meeting later, that I could come pick up my pay at the meeting, but then the meeting ended up not happening.

**Judge:** How many days did you work at that new place?

**Defendant:** About three weeks.

**Judge:** And then what did you do?

**Defendant:** I went back to the old place because I didn’t have any income.

**Judge:** Did you guys not pay him at all?

**Plaintiff:** No, Your Honor. He was paid.

**Judge:** Do you have proof that you paid him?

**Plaintiff:** Yes, Your Honor. I have text messages.

**Judge:** That’s not proof that you paid him. Do you have a pay stub?

**Plaintiff:** No, he got paid in cash because the owner didn’t have things set up properly at that time.

**Judge:** If you’re not doing things right, don’t open a business. But in the text messages, can I see any proof of payment?

**Defendant:** Those texts just show him saying things like, “That was two days’ pay, right?”

**Judge:** There are a lot of texts here. I see you telling him you need money, saying, ‘I’ll pay you back Friday.’ What did you mean?

**Defendant:** That was for phones we purchased together and were selling.

**Judge:** Why are you saying you’ll bring him money if you don’t owe him money?

**Defendant:** Some of those texts refer to other deals we had.

**Judge:** Why do you keep promising to pay $500 one week and $500 the next?

**Defendant:** That was supposed to be for phones.

**Judge:** Did you ever pay it?

**Defendant:** No.

**Judge:** Then you owe him $1,000.

Your counterclaim for $2,700 for unpaid wages—if you have unpaid wages, you have to sue the corporation, not him directly. You have to sue the corporation. So I am dismissing your counterclaim without prejudice for you to sue the corporation.

dialogue:
Judge: "This court is now in session. We are here to hear the case of Smith v. Johnson. Plaintiff, please state your complaint."

Plaintiff's Lawyer: "Your Honor, my client, Mr. Smith, was wrongfully terminated from his job without due cause. He had an excellent work record, and his dismissal was both unfair and unlawful."

Judge: "Mr. Johnson, how do you respond to these allegations?"

Defendant's Lawyer: "Your Honor, the defendant, Mr. Johnson, maintains that the termination was based on repeated violations of company policy and performance issues. The claims made by the plaintiff are unfounded."

Judge: "Plaintiff, please present your evidence."

Plaintiff's Lawyer: "Your Honor, we have multiple emails from the plaintiff’s supervisor that show he was receiving positive feedback just weeks before his termination. Additionally, we have witness testimonies from colleagues who can confirm that Mr. Smith was a dedicated and hardworking employee."

Judge: "Defense, do you have any evidence to support your claim?"

Defendant's Lawyer: "Yes, Your Honor. We have performance reviews that show a decline in Mr. Smith’s work quality over the past six months. Furthermore, we have written warnings that he received regarding attendance and failure to meet deadlines."

Judge: "Mr. Smith, would you like to respond to these claims?"

Plaintiff: "Yes, Your Honor. I acknowledge that I was given a warning about my attendance, but that was due to a temporary medical condition, which I informed my supervisor about. Despite this, I continued to meet my work deadlines and perform my duties well."

Judge: "Defense, do you have any further questions for the plaintiff?"

Defendant's Lawyer: "Yes, Your Honor. Mr. Smith, is it true that you missed an important client meeting without prior notice?"

Plaintiff: "That is incorrect. I had informed my manager in advance, and I even provided an email notification."

Defendant's Lawyer: "Your Honor, while Mr. Smith may have informed his manager, the absence still had a negative impact on company operations, which contributed to the decision to terminate him."

Judge: "I see. Plaintiff, do you have any witnesses?"

Plaintiff's Lawyer: "Yes, Your Honor. We would like to call Ms. Davis, a former colleague of Mr. Smith."

Judge: "Ms. Davis, please take the stand. Do you swear to tell the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth?"

Witness (Ms. Davis): "I do."

Plaintiff's Lawyer: "Ms. Davis, can you confirm whether Mr. Smith was a reliable and diligent employee?"

Witness (Ms. Davis): "Yes, absolutely. Mr. Smith was one of the most hardworking employees in our team. He always completed his tasks on time and often helped others with their workload."

Plaintiff's Lawyer: "Did you ever witness any serious performance issues?"

Witness (Ms. Davis): "No, I did not. In fact, he was praised in team meetings multiple times for his contributions."

Judge: "Defense, would you like to cross-examine the witness?"

Defendant's Lawyer: "Yes, Your Honor. Ms. Davis, are you aware that Mr. Smith received multiple warnings regarding his attendance and work performance?"

Witness (Ms. Davis): "I am aware that he received a warning, but I also know that he was dealing with a medical issue at the time, and he informed management about it."

Defendant's Lawyer: "Thank you. No further questions, Your Honor."

Judge: "Now, we will proceed with closing arguments. Plaintiff, you may begin."

Plaintiff's Lawyer: "Your Honor, the evidence and witness testimony clearly indicate that Mr. Smith was unfairly dismissed. He was a hardworking and dedicated employee, and his termination was unjust. We respectfully request that the court grant compensation for lost wages and damages."

Judge: "Defense, your closing argument?"

Defendant's Lawyer: "Your Honor, the company acted within its legal rights in terminating Mr. Smith. The decision was based on documented performance concerns and policy violations. We request that the case be dismissed."

Judge: "I will review all evidence and issue my ruling in due course. This court is adjourned."

**The People's Court Transcript**

**Judge:** Good morning. We are here today to hear the case of the plaintiff, Mr. John Smith, versus the defendant, Ms. Lisa Johnson. Mr. Smith, please state your case.

**Plaintiff (John Smith):** Your Honor, I hired Ms. Johnson to remodel my kitchen. We agreed on a price of $10,000, and she was supposed to complete the work within four weeks. However, after receiving $6,000 as an advance payment, she stopped showing up, and my kitchen remains unfinished.

**Judge:** Ms. Johnson, how do you respond to these claims?

**Defendant (Lisa Johnson):** Your Honor, I did start the work and completed about 50% of it. However, there were delays due to supply chain issues, and Mr. Smith refused to pay for additional materials. He also made changes to the project that extended the timeline.

**Judge:** Mr. Smith, did you request additional changes?

**Plaintiff:** I asked for minor adjustments, but nothing that should have delayed the project by this much. I just want my kitchen finished, or my money back.

**Judge:** Do you have a written contract detailing the terms and timeline?

**Plaintiff:** Yes, Your Honor. Here it is.

**Judge:** (Reviews the contract) Ms. Johnson, the contract states that you agreed to complete the project in four weeks. Can you explain why it has taken longer?

**Defendant:** Your Honor, unforeseen delays happened. But I was willing to complete the work if Mr. Smith paid for the extra costs.

**Judge:** Based on this contract and evidence, it seems that you were responsible for completing the work within the agreed timeframe. Mr. Smith paid a significant amount in advance, and the work is incomplete. I am ruling in favor of the plaintiff. Ms. Johnson, you are ordered to refund $4,000 to Mr. Smith or complete the project within two weeks at no extra cost.

**Plaintiff:** Thank you, Your Honor.

**Defendant:** Understood, Your Honor.

**Judge:** Case closed.

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hands. Welcome back to The People's Court. Next case on the docket, the plaintiff bought an English bulldog from the defendant, but the dog has hip dysplasia, and the plaintiff wants the cost of the surgery. The defendant says there is no hard proof the dog has a problem. It’s the case of the dog that wasn’t hip.

Judge: Okay, Mr. Boey, you are suing Sharon Nunley, doing business as Nunley Ranch and Nunley Ranch Bulldogs, for $1,600—$1,000 of it the amount you paid for the dog, and $600 for missed work and time spent trying to resolve this lawsuit. Tell me what's going on.

Plaintiff: I bought her when she was four months old. I got—bring her out here.

Judge: You brought her all this way? Hi there. What's the name of that dog?

Plaintiff: Bella.

Judge: Bella, yeah. And what kind of dog is that?

Plaintiff: Old English Bulldog.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: I bought her in October. I bought her for a companion because I go over the road.

Judge: Are you a truck driver?

Plaintiff: Yes, I am.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: All 48 states she’s been to—I believe 27.

Judge: Okay. A well-traveled canine.

Plaintiff: Yes, I got travel glasses for every state we’ve been through since I’ve had her.

Judge: Okay. Do you have kids?

Plaintiff: Yes, I do.

Judge: Okay. How old are they?

Plaintiff: 23 and 18. I got a grandson.

Judge: Okay, all right. I ask that question whenever someone is that devoted to a dog, just out of curiosity. So, go ahead.

Plaintiff: No, she’s my life. I bought her in October. She was four months old. I found out that her hips were no good before she was even a year old. I believe I had her for two months. I can’t get rid of a dog after I get attached to a dog.

Judge: Right. And she had hip dysplasia?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Okay. Do you have the medical records?

Plaintiff: Yes, I do.

Judge: Did you bring that to the attention of Ms. Nunley?

Plaintiff: Yes, I did. I even sent her a copy of it.

Judge: Okay. Can I see that? The copy of—let me see the medical records with the diagnosis. And if you have any emails to her, that would be great. Or did you mail it?

Plaintiff: No, I mailed it.

Judge: Okay. And you deny ever having received the medical records with anything with the vet statement or showing who the vet was? Or you didn't get this vet report that says Foxboro Animal Hospital with the receipt?

Defendant: The one I got—does it have the vet's name or where it came from?

Judge: Bilateral hip dysplasia. What day was the purchase of the dog?

Defendant: It was in October.

Judge: He got the pup in August?

Plaintiff: Yes, in August.

Judge: Okay. This is in August of what year?

Plaintiff: 2011.

Judge: Okay. This vet report is from February 10, 2012. Now, let me ask you a question. Was there a contract between you two for the purchase of the dog?

Defendant: Yes. Our purchase agreement is on our website, and he stated he read it.

Judge: Can I see that?

Defendant: Yes, ma’am.

Judge: Do you—wait, no, no, I’m still on my question. Do you have people sign it, scan it, and send it back to you, or do you have them click something that says—

Defendant: We like for them to print it out and send it back to us, but a lot of people say they don’t have a printer and can’t send it back.

Judge: Okay. How do you record their acknowledging the terms and everything?

Defendant: Well, I ask them. It’s on our website. It’s also where the puppy’s picture is—it states it right here, too.

Judge: Let me see all that. Did he reach out to you and tell you, “Listen, I’ve just found out that the dog has hip dysplasia”?

Defendant: Yes. And I asked him to send me the vet reports and the vet statement stating so.

Judge: When you got stuff and it was missing something you wanted, did you call him to say, “Hey, I still don’t have the name of the vet”?

Defendant: I tracked that down myself. He didn’t send me any.

Judge: Oh, so you got on Google and made a lot of phone calls?

Defendant: Yeah.

Judge: But how could you track it down without the name of the vet?

Defendant: A lot of phone calls and asking if they knew this gentleman and that dog.

Judge: So, you’re the one who tracked down the report?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Okay, so it’s hip dysplasia, right?

Defendant: Yes, ma’am.

Judge: My verdict in this case is for the defendant. Good luck, though. She is a beautiful dog, and I hope she doesn’t end up needing surgery.

Judge: Charia Preston?

Plaintiff:
Yes, ma’am.

Judge:
You are suing your former landlord, Selwin Wilford, for $2,500 that you say he owes you in the return of a security deposit?

Plaintiff:
Yes, ma’am.

Judge:
Okay, what happened here?

Plaintiff:
Okay, um, after renewing my lease, we decided towards the ending of that term that we were going to go ahead and move out.

Judge:
Okay, so your lease was going to end when?

Plaintiff:
My lease would have ended at the end of May.

Judge:
Do you have your lease?

Plaintiff:
Yes, I do.

Judge:
May I see it?

Plaintiff:
Sure.

Judge:
When did you let the landlord know that you weren't going to renew?

Plaintiff:
I let him know back in March.

Judge:
Did you do it in writing?

Plaintiff:
I did it in writing, and I also informed him and his wife that we were moving because when I'm on Section 8, we have to let the landlord know that we're not going to renew the lease.

Judge:
Okay.

Plaintiff:
So, he asked me to make sure everything was in order so that way he could start bringing people in to try to rent out the place.

Judge:
Okay.

Plaintiff:
We said okay.

Judge:
Okay, I got it. So, you move out on what day?

Plaintiff:
We moved out on May 31st.

Judge:
All right. Did you do a walkthrough with him or no?

Plaintiff:
Yes, we did a walkthrough.

Judge:
Did anybody say anything?

Plaintiff:
The only thing he said to me was that there were toys and clothes.

Judge:
Where?

Plaintiff:
In front of the house.

Judge:
Okay.

Plaintiff:
I give away furniture a lot. I give it away to Salvation Army.

Judge:
Okay, and?

Plaintiff:
There were clothes and toys on the porch.

Judge:
Okay.

Plaintiff:
And one of the stoves—he wanted the trays to be replaced.

Judge:
The burner trays?

Plaintiff:
Yes, the burner trays on the stove.

Judge:
Okay.

Plaintiff:
And that was it.

Judge:
Okay, so now you replace the burner trays, except for one that you couldn’t get loose?

Plaintiff:
Correct.

Judge:
And you left that there for him to replace because you couldn't figure it out?

Plaintiff:
Yes.

Judge:
And what about all the stuff that was outside that you were expecting to donate to charity?

Plaintiff:
We had my fiancé’s brother come and help us remove the stuff, and we took it to the junkyard.

Judge:
Okay, I got it. So now you wait and wait, and you don't get your security deposit. When do you find out he doesn’t intend to give you the security deposit?

Plaintiff:
We were overseas on vacation because he had told me that he was going to send the money.

Judge:
Okay, and then when did you realize he wasn’t going to send the money?

Plaintiff:
When we came back, and I kept texting him.

Judge:
And what did he do? Ignore you or tell you, "I'm not sending you money?"

Plaintiff:
He ignored me. He never told me he wasn’t.

Judge:
You filed the lawsuit?

Plaintiff:
Yes.

Judge:
All right, what’s going on, sir?

Defendant:
I have text messages concerning the date and time that she actually left.

Judge:
When did she leave?

Defendant:
She left on the 14th of June.

Judge:
But when she handed you back the key, did she keep just the key for two extra weeks, or did she move everything out on the 31st?

Defendant:
I don’t know what she moved out on the 31st because I was out of town.

Judge:
Okay.

Defendant:
I have pictures of everything from the 14th through the 15th and 16th of June of what took place.

Judge:
Are you trying to charge her half a month’s rent because she had stuff on the porch and a burner?

Defendant:
I'm not trying to charge her any half a month’s rent. That came up because of the lawsuit that she filed against me.

Judge:
Well, yeah, she’s trying to get—how is it you're justifying keeping $2,500 of her security deposit?

Defendant:
If you look at my response, there were several damages at the property.

Judge:
Okay.

Defendant:
The stove cost me over $130 to fix. There were walls broken, parts of the walls that had to be replaced, painted, that had to be repainted. The ceilings that were all stained up with paint that they used had to be repainted. It cost me over $3,000 to bring this to where it needed to be to be rented again.      Judge:
Okay, so here’s what I need to see. I need to see the pictures of what you are saying needed to be repaired.

Defendant:
Yes, ma’am. I have them right here.

(Defendant hands over photos to the judge.)

Judge:
Okay. So, this is a picture of what exactly?

Defendant:
That is one of the walls in the living room that had to be repaired and repainted. The plaintiff had painted it a dark color and didn’t return it to white.

Judge:
Do you have a clause in the lease stating that the tenant must return the walls to the original color?

Defendant:
Yes, it’s in the lease agreement.

Judge:
(Flipping through lease agreement) Yes, I see that here. The tenant is responsible for returning walls to their original color upon vacating.

Plaintiff:
I wasn’t made aware that I had to repaint.

Judge:
Well, it’s in the lease, so it’s your responsibility to read it. But let’s move on. What else do we have?

Defendant:
There were holes in the wall from where things were hung up. I had to patch those up.

Judge:
Let me see. (Examines photos) Okay, some minor nail holes and a few larger ones.

Plaintiff:
We only put up picture frames.

Judge:
Okay. Normally, minor nail holes are considered normal wear and tear, but some of these are larger than expected.

Defendant:
Also, there were two ceiling fans that were broken.

Judge:
How do you know she broke them and it wasn’t normal wear and tear?

Defendant:
They were functioning before she moved in, and when she moved out, they weren’t.

Judge:
(Looking at receipts) You have an invoice for the repair of the fans, which was $250.

Plaintiff:
They were old fans. I didn’t break them.

Judge:
All right. Then we have the issue of the stove. You said you had to replace burner trays?

Defendant:
Yes, but also, one of the burners was damaged.

Judge:
(Looking at invoice) $130 for that repair.

Plaintiff:
I replaced the trays. He never told me anything about a burner being broken.

Judge:
Okay, here’s where I stand. First, you cannot charge her additional rent for the days after she moved out if she was not living there and only had some items left behind temporarily.

Second, normal wear and tear, like minor nail holes, is not something you can charge a tenant for. However, the larger holes and the failure to repaint the walls back to the original color are reasonable deductions.

The stove repair is questionable since she did attempt to fix it herself, but I will allow a partial deduction for that.

The ceiling fans—there’s no clear evidence that she broke them beyond normal use, so I will not allow that deduction.

I am ordering you to return $1,500 of the $2,500 security deposit to the plaintiff.

Plaintiff:
Thank you, Your Honor.

Defendant:
Understood.

Judge:
Good luck, folks. Court is adjourned.

Judge:
Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff (Nicole Yarboro):
Okay, so how many children did they have there?

Plaintiff (Nicole Yarboro):
One child.

Judge:
One child? How old was the child?

Plaintiff (Nicole Yarboro):
She was 2 and a half at the time.

Judge:
Okay, so what happened?

Plaintiff (Nicole Yarboro):
She put in her 30-day notice because of an incident.

Judge:
Tell me about that.

Plaintiff (Nicole Yarboro):
She had come to pick up her daughter at 6:00, and I had already told her in advance that she hadn’t had a nap the whole day. And when she put her into the car, she had a meltdown. She took her out of the car and faced her towards my daycare, and she said, “You’re in timeout.”

Judge:
This is before the notice?

Plaintiff (Nicole Yarboro):
Yes, this was the day before the notice. Meanwhile, Amelia is standing there screaming at the top of her lungs, and my husband got sick of hearing it, so he went outside and signaled for her to come to the daycare area. He signaled for who to come to the daycare?

Plaintiff (Nicole Yarboro):
He signaled for Naomi to come. He goes, “Come here.” She came to him, and he said, “This can’t happen here.” And she looked at him and—I heard this from my window—she said, “Come on, Amelia, let’s go.” So they went to the car and drove off.

Judge:
Later on that night, I got a text message saying that we needed to talk about the incident that happened with Phil, my husband. So we met at Starbucks. She discussed that it was inappropriate how Phil talked to her.

Judge:
Well, I mean, I wouldn’t like somebody to go like that to me either. You know, it’s a little bit rude, what, saying, “Come here”?

Plaintiff (Nicole Yarboro):
Yeah.

Judge:
Okay. Well, we’re getting far astray of things. So, for whatever reason, she decides she’s leaving. This has nothing to do with them, but I thought you were going to start telling me when you said the incident about the problem where your friend was thrown out.

Plaintiff (Nicole Yarboro):
Audrey, the other little girl got it. There was a problem between you and the dad. It was a communication problem, and I terminated him.

Judge:
Okay. And that child is your daughter’s best friend, and it was sort of unpleasant.

Plaintiff (Nicole Yarboro):
Correct.

Judge:
Oh yeah, it was very... Am I correct from reading your material that you basically texted the dad and said, “Your daughter’s stuff will be out on the porch, pick it up by 5:30, you’re not welcome here. I’m terminating you.”

Plaintiff (Nicole Yarboro):
That’s a little rude, don’t you think?

Defendant (Naomi Daob):
What’s rude? What I just said?

Judge:
Yes, that sounds a bit rude.

Defendant (Naomi Daob):
No, I don’t think so. Because we had already had a discussion. You give a 30-day notice. I did. The contract requires it. And then you pay the first half of the month, and then on the 15th, you pay the second half of the month, and then you stop payment on that check.

Judge:
Why?

Defendant (Naomi Daob):
When I dropped off the check on the 15th, the morning of, I spoke with Nicole and said, “I’m going to be coming late.” At 6:00, I come to pick my daughter up, and there’s an access code that lets you into the daycare. So I put the access code in; it didn’t work, so I couldn’t get in to my child. So I hollered over the fence and got one of the kids’ attention to let them know that I’m here and to have somebody open the gate.

Judge:
There’s a doorbell to ring.

Defendant (Naomi Daob):
Okay. And they were outside anyways. So we opened the gate for them. I said, “Nicole, the key code doesn’t work. Any… you know, it didn’t work.” She said, “I changed it.” So I asked her, “What’s the code?” And she said, “I can’t give it to you.” She said that I was still associated with Emily and Justin, the Audrey’s dad and his girlfriend, because I had picked up Audrey’s stuff. They called me and asked me to pick up the stuff because it was sitting outside on the ground. She said when I picked up that bag, I chose Justin and Emily, and that she couldn’t trust me with the code.

Judge:
At that point, I said, “This is unacceptable.” You know, you denied me access to my child, not giving me notice. I said, “I’m not coming back. I’m putting a stop payment on the check.” She said, “Go ahead,” and I left.

Judge:
Tell me about this. What happened?

Defendant (Naomi Daob):
So the defense here is this daycare person was really rude to the parents. Is that a defense to not paying for the services?

Judge:
No. Why?

Plaintiff (Nicole Yarboro):
Because attitude has nothing to do with her services.

Judge:
Is that true for daycare? Attitude has nothing to do with it?

Defendant (Naomi Daob):
What do you—who’s a parent? Who’s a parent?

Judge:
Quick, quick, quick, what do you think? Does attitude have anything to do with it?

Plaintiff (Nicole Yarboro):
I don’t think so.

Defendant (Naomi Daob):
No.

Judge:
No? Well, therefore, a parent has spoken. There you go. Going inside the courtroom.

Defendant (Naomi Daob):
She asked me for the code, just like she said, and I told her that I was not giving her the code because she was too closely involved with Justin and Emily.

Judge:
How? By doing what?

Defendant (Naomi Daob):
By serving as a broker to make sure the two of you don’t have contact and picking up the stuff that you very—I think rudely—just put on the porch.

Judge:
No, I was worried that the code was going to be breached, and I didn’t want someone else to have the code to my home and come in and vandalize my property. They made threatening phone calls.

Judge:
Why would you conclude that that might happen?

Defendant (Naomi Daob):
Because he called after I terminated him. He called and made threatening phone calls.

Judge:
Saying what?

Defendant (Naomi Daob):
“You’ve made the wrong decision by terminating my daughter. I’m going to put bad reviews over the internet about you.”

Judge:
Oh, why do people think that’s threats?

Defendant (Naomi Daob):
Threats is, “I’m going to break your legs.”

Judge:
Well, no, of course. I think I understand what you’re saying. You know, you felt unsafe, and you didn’t want somebody you have bad blood with potentially doing something like that. You have kids there, so you don’t want him having the code. What do I do with the idea that you made her feel like…?

Defendant (Naomi Daob):
Wait, wait, wait, wait. I’m a paying customer. All of a sudden, she’s a persona non grata, and why should she have to patronize you for two more weeks and abide by the contract when you’ve changed the rules on her, telling her, “I don’t want you to have the code”?

Defendant (Naomi Daob):
I was more than willing to open the door. You just felt offended, like you felt like it was rude.

Plaintiff (Nicole Yarboro):
Well, and also, too, there’s two days that had gone by, and she never notified us.

Judge:
Well, apparently, it hadn’t affected you.

Plaintiff (Nicole Yarboro):
Yeah, because I didn’t think it was that big of a deal.

Judge:
I have to sort of consider that when I’m trying to figure out how big a deal this is. I think what it really is is the insult. I mean, maybe I’m wrong, but it felt like an insult to you.

Defendant (Naomi Daob):
And there was no…

Judge:
Did you really say you picked Justin?

Defendant (Naomi Daob):
What I said was, when you picked up the bag, she said, “I don’t want to get in the middle of you, Justin, and Emily.” I said, “When you picked up that bag…”

Judge:
You really have an attitude! You must be really good at what you do because I’d have dropped you in a week. You must be absolutely fabulous at daycare if people are there with you a whole year. You do a great job with the kids. I don’t… because there was a lot of good.

Defendant (Naomi Daob):
It’s got to be. It’s got to be because otherwise I wouldn’t tolerate people talking to me like that. Let me hear from you.

Plaintiff (Nicole Yarboro):
I’m sorry. I think it was a change in atmosphere that we felt. If they were going to treat us this way, what would they be treating our child like?

Judge:
Yeah, but you had no evidence they were going to treat her that way.

Defendant (Naomi Daob):
No, that’s true. Don’t get me wrong. You know, you as parents have the obligation and responsibility to make the decisions that you think are best for your child. What I have to decide is, is that a material breach of the contract that you don’t have to abide by the contract?

Judge:
And I really, I don’t—I don’t find it to be such a material breach. It’s insulting and everything, and I agree with you, I would feel insulted. But all you have to do is call ahead like you have before and give a little holler, and they’ll come over. In other words, I would have done the same thing you were doing, and I would not have stopped payment, I guess is what I’m saying.

Judge:
I’m not going to order them to pay $500 in late fees because when the late fees are more than the fees, that’s excessive. So I am going to order them to pay the $341.25 plus your board cost. That’s my judgment. Good luck.

Judge:
 Kimberly Carlson Alys, you are suing Car Store of West Orange Inc., represented here by Garrett Lionel Pette—you’re the owner?

Defendant:
Yes, ma’am.

Judge:
Okay. You are suing for $500 in towing and travel expenses because you believe you are being inappropriately charged.

Plaintiff:
Yes.

Judge:
You are counterclaiming $1,197.20 for tow and storage fees that you have incurred since towing the car.

Defendant:
Yes, ma’am.

Judge:
Alright, let’s backtrack. Start from the beginning.

Plaintiff:
The reason why we’re here is because this past August, when I went to renew my tag for my car, they wouldn’t allow me to because there was a lien against my tag. Then they gave me information that I had to pay a $375 tow fee, which brings us back to 2017.

Judge:
What happened in 2017?

Plaintiff:
In 2017, my car broke down, and I had AAA tow it back to my house.

Judge:
What kind of car was it?

Plaintiff:
A 2009 Ford Expedition.

Judge:
Okay, go on.

Plaintiff:
So, I had it towed back to my house. But during that time, code enforcement kept coming by, saying it was parked improperly.

Judge:
Why was it parked improperly, according to them?

Plaintiff:
They just said it was improperly parked how I had it. The neighbor was also complaining about how the car was parked there.

Judge:
What was the neighbor complaining about?

Plaintiff:
That the car was parked there for too long. It became a big ordeal.

Judge:
Okay, so what did you do?

Plaintiff:
So, he gave me a $30 ticket. But I didn’t think anything was wrong with the way my car was parked. So I went to Orange County and filed a small claims case against the Orlando Sheriff’s Department, the code enforcement people, and the neighbor.

Judge:
Okay, so you’re all from Orlando?

Plaintiff:
Yes.

Judge:
Go on.

Plaintiff:
We went to court, and I won the case.

Judge:
What did the judge say? Did he give you an order saying you can park there all you want?

Plaintiff:
Yeah, he said there was no evidence that I couldn’t park there.

Judge:
Did the code enforcement people show up?

Plaintiff:

Judge: And when you did that—you own a timeshare and you rent out—do you rent it out every year?

Defendant: Uh, it depends on the timeshare and who the guest is.

Judge: How often do you end up renting it out?

Defendant: Um, it depends. Usually once, maybe twice per year.

Judge: Okay, do you own several timeshares?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: How many?

Defendant: We’re timeshare junkies. We own about six of them.

Judge: All right, so sometimes you use them, sometimes you rent them out?

Defendant: We always use them, and our contracts allow us to use excess time that we can then rent out.

Judge: Right. All right, so you were going—where is this particular one located?

Defendant: This one is at Divi Little Bay Resort on the island of St. Martin.

Judge: That’s the Caribbean?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: And you’ve rented that one before?

Plaintiff: I’ve rented that before.

Judge: And how much were you paying for it?

Plaintiff: Uh, $1,600 a week.

Judge: Something funny happened on the way to the forum—a hurricane hit, correct?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And that was the week you were going to be there?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: A few months later, the island was devastated, basically unusable, right?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: The resort was closed at that time?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Has the resort ever reopened?

Defendant: Yes, it reopened afterward.

Judge: So, he wants his deposit back because the place was closed and he couldn’t go. Why aren’t you returning his deposit?

Defendant: Mark rented in 2015 a week from us at a different resort on the same island, and it was under the same terms. That is to say, we are not a company—we dispose of personally available time, and we do not offer cancellation insurance or interruption insurance. We ask all guests to get the same to protect themselves because we don’t offer any protection.

Judge: Can I see any written paperwork between you two? Any emails, anything like that? Any contract?

Defendant: There’s no contract. Just an email with the deposit made, the dates, and the confirmation from the resort.

Judge: Do you have a written agreement with him—Mark Brown?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Do you have anything where he acknowledges that it’s his responsibility to get insurance?

Defendant: No.

Judge: So if a hurricane hits an island where you rent a condo, can you get your deposit back?

Judge: I’m not 100% sure, but I don’t think so—unless you’ve got some kind of insurance specifically for that.

Judge: Anybody have a different opinion? Going once? Going twice?

(There is silence from the audience.)

Judge: I can’t believe nobody’s saying this. Nobody has any idea? Higher force? Whatever?

Judge: I’ve looked through the only paperwork anybody’s given me, and nowhere does it say the following: You assume the risk of an act of God.

Judge: I would never rent a place that had me assume the risk of an act of God. If you had a contract with him that said, You assume the risk of an act of God, I could understand you saying, “Hey buddy, I’m out the money. I’m not a company. I spent your money and don’t want to pay it back.”

Judge: But the deal is, he’s renting a place he can go to, and now he can’t go to it anymore. And you’re assuming that’s a him problem? I’m looking at it as a you problem.

Judge: You really think you need to raise your hand? Because I don’t see how that means he has to take a vacation at a different time.

Judge: You have the ability to find a solution. You can rent it out at another time because the timeshare allows you to rent that time. You understand what having a right to a place means.

Judge: And you are having them provide you with a subsequent time to rent out or use. So you’re not really out. The guy who’s out is him.

Judge: And he’s out how much? What was the deposit?

Plaintiff: $800.

Judge: Right. So tell me where I’m not getting this.

Defendant: The money we had to pay to the resort for the upgrade for the Brown family was a one-time, specific-date reservation.

Judge: If the resort couldn’t give it to you, then they would let you rent it at a different time.

Judge: You are now able to rent out a one-bedroom instead of a studio, right?

Defendant: Actually, no. Only the studio.

Judge: Well, then, I suggest you go through the resort.

Judge: My verdict is for the plaintiff in this case for $800. On the counterclaim, zero. That’s my judgment.
