dialogue:
Judge: All parties, please raise your right hands. Please be seated. Michael Arthur, you are suing Derek O'Grady for $2,400 for four days of work that you say he owes you for Bobcat services at a construction site. What happened?

Plaintiff: Good morning, Your Honor. I put an ad on Craigslist later in the summer to dig up some extra money for myself and my family. I have the ad right here—it says “Bobcat operator, skilled operator for Bobcat hire.” So, I got many calls. Derek was one of them. He called me on a Thursday, I believe, and asked me if I could be out there on a Monday to do some work, which was about 50 miles from my home. I said, “No problem.” So, I loaded everything up. I get to the first job site...

Judge: This is a Bobcat? If you don’t know what it is...

Plaintiff: Yeah, I know what a Bobcat is, but I love pictures. So, I get to the first job site in Sound Beach, and he walks me around his property and shows me what to do. There was about 100 yards of soil...

Judge: We call it fill in the industry.

Plaintiff: That was ripped out and piled on this guy’s property that had to be moved and put in dumpsters.

Judge: Right.

Plaintiff: I have some video of the property before I started any work. It’s queued up on my phone.

Judge: What is your custom? To video before the work and video after the work?

Plaintiff: He showed me what to do, so I walked around with my phone. Every contractor should be doing that.

Judge: I agree. So, how long did it take?

Plaintiff: I was there three days, unfortunately. I don’t have any pictures of the final work, which I should have brought.

Judge: Oh, you should do that. Why don’t you tape the final work, especially when that’s when you have the motive to tape it? Because according to you, the guy wasn’t paying you.

Plaintiff: I can get the owner of that house on the phone right now.

Judge: No, it’s fine. I’m just curious why, when you’re doing everything right, you didn’t document that part. So, you worked that first day and didn’t get paid?

Plaintiff: Correct. I worked the first day, worked very hard, and was supposed to be paid daily. I asked him to be paid, and he said, “How about I pay you tomorrow? Come in for work tomorrow.” I said, “No problem.” I showed up at 7:00 AM, worked all day again, and said, “I really need some money.”

Judge: How many warnings do you need? If the guy can’t fork up $600...

Plaintiff: I kept giving him the benefit of the doubt.

Judge: Because you knew him so well?

Plaintiff: I didn’t know him at all.

Judge: But you’re Craigslist buddies. Nothing ever goes wrong on Craigslist, right?

Plaintiff: No, nothing ever goes wrong...

Judge: It’s a hard lesson.

Plaintiff: So, now it’s day three. I show up and do work again.

Judge: Then day four comes. What happens?

Plaintiff: I told my wife, “I’m going to go to the job and sit there until he pays me.”

Judge: Good.

Plaintiff: So, he shows up, asks me what to do. I said, “Derek, I’m not going to move this machine until I’m paid for the three days.”

Defendant: I had to go to the bank.

Plaintiff: He left and came back an hour later with no money.

Judge: What did he say?

Plaintiff: “I’m waiting for checks to clear.”

Judge: But people know that before they go to the bank!

Plaintiff: He promised me extra money—four days' pay plus $200. Here are the texts.

Judge: What’s going on?

Defendant: He worked, and I told him I was waiting for funds to clear.

Judge: Have they cleared?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Then why haven’t you paid him?

Defendant: The following week, I met him and offered some money.

Judge: How many days did he work?

Defendant: Three. The fourth day, he just sat there.

Judge: But you want to get paid for sitting there?

Plaintiff: Your Honor, I moved a shed at his request.

Defendant: That was on the third day. He’s lying.

Judge: Is there a police report?

Plaintiff: Yes, here it is.

Judge: Did you give him credit cards to charge?

Defendant: He ran them when I told him not to.

Judge: The charges were declined?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Why all these excuses?

Defendant: I was waiting on money.

Judge: A month and a half later? Inexcusable. Did the homeowner pay you?

Defendant: Yes, but only part.

Judge: Why not place a lien?

Plaintiff: The homeowner paid $550 because he didn’t want a lien.

Judge: Why didn’t you file one?

Plaintiff: The homeowner didn’t owe him money. Derek owed the homeowner money.

Judge: Did you tell the homeowner your father died and needed $3,000?

Defendant: My stepfather is alive...

Judge: But you told the homeowner otherwise?

Defendant: (No response.)

Judge: We don’t know what’s true with you. My ruling is in favor of the plaintiff for the full amount.

Judge: You are suing Trudy Gerini, yes? Okay, for $352.36, the amount it's going to cost you or has cost you to fix your car mirror that, according to you, was damaged by her in an accident. Right, what happened?

Plaintiff (Herman Rink):
I was parked on 111, uh, guess Avenue in Jersey City, waiting to go upstairs to have a meeting with my customer. And, um, the meeting was for, let's say, 3:30. I arrived there at about, um, I would say 3:15, and I was just reading some of my notes and things prior to going up. And this... I'll teach you to be early.

Judge:
I know! I know.

Plaintiff (Herman Rink):
I parked nice and close, but things like this happen, I guess. And, um, all of a sudden, uh, a big white van came by and the two mirrors collided.

Judge:
Are you in the big white van?

Plaintiff (Herman Rink):
Yes.

Judge:
Okay, and my mirror just went into smithereens. I have it here to show you. You'd like to see it?

Judge:
Sure.

Plaintiff (Herman Rink):
Are you parked on the curb like the curbside parking there?

Plaintiff (Herman Rink):
Yes. Alright. And do you know why she smashed into you?

Plaintiff (Herman Rink):
The reason was, um, she was... the road was a little bit narrow there, and she was waiting her turn to pass me. Uh, and there was another car coming this way, headed towards us. Uh, and she was afraid she wouldn't fit, and that car told her to come across, so she just went across, and the mirrors collided, and with a crash, went to the floor, and, uh, that’s what happened.

Judge:
Okay, and so did she stop?

Plaintiff (Herman Rink):
Yes, and you two spoke, and were the police called?

Plaintiff (Herman Rink):
No, the police weren’t called.

Plaintiff (Herman Rink):
Okay, I’ll tell you what happened. Um, the lady told me that she was on the way to pick up her baby, okay? And she was late for that. The car was her mother’s car, and her father had just died, so I felt sorry for her. We exchanged, uh, license and insurance and stuff like that. And then she said, “I have to go pick up the baby, and I’ll be back right after that.”

Judge:
Okay. So, you’re saying you waited around for her?

Plaintiff (Herman Rink):
I waited until about 6 o'clock that evening. She never came back.

Judge:
Wait a minute. Okay, you had your meeting at 3:30. Yes, you go upstairs to your meeting, you come back, and then you just keep hanging around waiting for her, right?

Plaintiff (Herman Rink):
Yes, because she said she’d be back. Did she take your number, and did you take hers?

Plaintiff (Herman Rink):
Yes, indeed.

Judge:
Did she ever come back?

Plaintiff (Herman Rink):
No, and I waited until 6.

Judge:
Who's this nice lady?

Plaintiff (Herman Rink):
That's my wife.

Judge:
Lucky lady. Could he be nicer? Is he this nice, or is this an act?

Plaintiff's Wife:
I’m a patient fellow.

Judge:
You are? Yes, that would qualify as a patient fellow.

Plaintiff (Herman Rink):
What happened? Come on over here and show me.

Judge:
Come on over to this... yeah, you! Who else am I going to ask?

Plaintiff (Herman Rink):
Just pick a car. Any car. He’s parked here. I’m here. There’s another car... this car was double parked.

Judge:
So, there was another car... double-parked?

Plaintiff (Herman Rink):
Yes, it wasn’t parked. There was another car stopped there.

Plaintiff (Herman Rink):
I came around this way... wait. Wait, that car had a human in it?

Plaintiff (Herman Rink):
Yes, so it wasn’t parked. There was another car stopped there.

Judge:
Okay, and so, she doesn't want to move. She tells you, "Go ahead, you got plenty of room."

Plaintiff (Herman Rink):
And I’m telling her, no, you go ahead. But I guess she was just parked there.

Judge:
But this is not this wide. It's not.

Plaintiff (Herman Rink):
Okay, so there's no line in between?

Plaintiff (Herman Rink):
No.

Plaintiff (Herman Rink):
So, there's really just room for one car. It's a dead-end block. It only has the building that Mr. Rink was going to and I think another building.

Judge:
Okay, so what happened, though? Why'd you hit his car?

Defendant (Trudy Gerini):
I’m going to tell you. So, she’s parked. Let’s say it’s not this wide, it’s only wide like for this. So, there’s cars parked here, cars parked here, she’s double-parked. Right? I come across this way. I’m trying, I stop right here, I tell her to go, she doesn’t. I’m telling her, I can’t fit, move. And she’s looking at me like, “I’m not going anywhere.” So, I tried to get through. Obviously, I took the mirror. My mirror hit his mirror.

Judge:
Okay, why am I here? What’s your defense? I don’t understand.

Defendant (Trudy Gerini):
The fact that she was double-parked. Really.

Judge:
Yeah, because that’s why you’re not going to pay this nice guy? Because somebody else caused you to drive recklessly?

Defendant (Trudy Gerini):
I don't think it was. I was not driving recklessly.

Judge:
But hold on. There was an accident because you misgauged it.

Defendant (Trudy Gerini):
When she said you go, you went, stepped on the accelerator and started driving.

Judge:
Why did you come back? This guy was waiting for you for three hours.

Defendant (Trudy Gerini):
We spoke, we agreed on it. She said she would come back and take care of it.

Defendant (Trudy Gerini):
Yes, I called him back. It wasn’t like I just left him there.

Judge:
You agreed to meet, but you didn’t show up?

Plaintiff (Herman Rink):
Yes, you agreed to meet. And then, you didn’t.

Defendant (Trudy Gerini):
I called him back and told him I was still in the process.

Judge:
But then you didn’t come back.

Plaintiff (Herman Rink):
She said yes, she would, and then she didn’t.

Judge:
Why didn’t you pay this man for this mirror?

Defendant (Trudy Gerini):
I don’t think it was my fault. It was because the lady was illegally parked.

Judge:
Then don’t go! Don’t go up.

Plaintiff (Herman Rink):
Okay, right. Like what you’re saying, I shouldn’t have.

Judge:
If you do something because you misgauged whether you could or not, it really doesn't matter to me if somebody else was stationary. You were trying to avoid her. That makes no difference. You made a decision to drive, and your driving caused the mirror to come down. How can you possibly... possibly end up doing this to this nice man? Not just leaving him there for three hours, but then after that, after he reaches you and you speak all those times... what is she saying? “Yes, I’ll pay for it,” and then no.

Plaintiff (Herman Rink):
Absolutely not.

Judge:
Only that she put her boyfriend on the phone. Who’s the boyfriend? Get on up here. I want to hear your story.

Plaintiff (Herman Rink):
He told me that they’d absolutely see to it that I’d be paid the money. And then what happened?

Judge:
I guess it was just like... miscommunication.

Defendant (Trudy Gerini):
What miscommunication?

Judge:
You’re going to pay me, and then you don’t. Oh, absolutely not.

Judge:
I’m coming back, and then you leave the guy hanging for three hours. Where’s the miscommunication?

Defendant (Trudy Gerini):
I just didn’t think I should pay.

Judge:
Stop with the excuses, and pay the nice man $352.36, plus your court costs. Good luck, folks.

Judge: Alright, Lorna, you've asked us to refer to you only by your first name, and we'll respect that. You are suing Linda Laramore. Am I allowed to use your last name?
Plaintiff: Yes.
Judge: For $295 that you say she owes you because you paid her that to use her car and she didn't let you use her car. Tell me what's going on.
Plaintiff: I met Linda. We became friends. I had moved to Florida for a job and had a car with that job, and it fell through. Basically, she would let me use the car. I would fill the gas tank, give her money for gas because she was financially in certain dire straits, so I would help her.
Judge: So you were doing that just to be a helpful person or because she was giving you rides places?
Plaintiff: No, I was using the car. She wasn't giving me rides. I was actually using the car, and I would also— we would share the use of the car.
Judge: Okay, and were you paying her for that?
Plaintiff: In the beginning, I was not. I was filling her gas tank, and I was using the car.
Judge: That's how you were paying her?
Plaintiff: Yes.
Judge: And I was using the car very minimally, maybe to go to the gym. It wasn't a mile or two.
Plaintiff: Okay, then she came to me April 9th. She was behind two car payments. The third car payment would result in a repossession. I don't believe I— I don't know if she asked, but I said, "Look, I will pay this car payment so you will not be behind three car payments and get your car repossessed." In lieu of that, I can use the car for a month. I will schedule it, let you know when I need it, and we will share the car. I will do this for you so that way you won't be out the money.
Judge: So she wasn't going to pay you back; she was just going to let you use the car?
Plaintiff: Correct, but she was already letting you use the car. Were you letting her use the car?
Plaintiff: Yes.
Judge: Okay, because you were close friends?
Plaintiff: Yes.
Judge: And I had surgery in March and had a total shoulder replacement. I couldn't drive anyway for six weeks.
Judge: So was she driving you places?
Plaintiff: Yes.
Judge: Some of the time.
Plaintiff: Yes.
Judge: How long had you two been friends? It's so sad that you're here.
Plaintiff: Four months, three or four months.
Judge: Okay, and did she give you $295? Did she make that payment of $295?
Plaintiff: She gave me the money, yes.
Judge: And when did she do that?
Plaintiff: I don't remember. I have the information. I have the coupon of the car payment that I made her give me just to make sure that that was the amount. And I have the withdrawal from the bank of $300.
Judge: And what date did that occur?
Plaintiff: April 9th. The car coupon where she was behind on the car payment was April 8th.
Judge: Okay, so had she not made that car payment, she would have been behind three car payments. So you were behind two payments. She was paying $295, and you were coming up with the other $295 or it—
Plaintiff: Yeah, I was going to pay. I paid the other one.
Judge: Alright, so according to you, what happens about a week later?
Plaintiff: She had an appointment, and I had a doctor's appointment in Jacksonville. It was an appointment that was longstanding, and you really wanted to make it.
Plaintiff: Yeah. Okay, go ahead.
Plaintiff: On the way, I had a copy. I wanted her to sign something saying that she received that cash, so I brought— I just typed up something simple saying she got the money, and then also my schedule so we could arrange to share the car when I gave her that information in the car.
Plaintiff: It was a rage, and proceeded to be a really terrifying car ride.
Judge: And this was the next day after you gave her the money?
Plaintiff: No, this was April 19th. It was 10 days after I gave her the money.
Judge: Okay.
Plaintiff: Is that accurate? The conversation happens 10 days afterward?
Plaintiff: Yes, her doctor's appointment was 10 days after it.
Judge: I do not know that.
Plaintiff: That was the discussion 10 days later.
Judge: So according to you, it's 10 days later and she says what?
Plaintiff: I am not going to let you use the car. Is what she said.
Plaintiff: Just because you gave her something to sign that says that?
Plaintiff: Yeah, it just went from friendship to full-on rage, and she just started yelling and threatening.
Judge: What do you think was going on?
Plaintiff: I think she was trying to intimidate me into backing off and not wanting to get the car as the agreement was.
Judge: Was there an agreement according to you?
Plaintiff: There was an agreement that she could use the car.
Judge: Alright, what didn't you like about the way she was presenting it to you?
Plaintiff: I was driving in a rainstorm that day, and she kept insisting that I sign an agreement, a written agreement, and I said no.
Judge: When she pays you the $295, is there any agreement attached to the $295 that she'd be able to use the car?
Plaintiff: Okay, yes.
Judge: And then that's what she puts in writing for you to sign. Why are you offended then?
Plaintiff: How was it put in writing for me to sign? What did she put in writing for you to sign?
Plaintiff: She wanted me to sign the fact that she gave the receipt that she had given me the money.
Judge: So then—
Plaintiff: Okay, you need to tell me what's going on then. What led to the problem? Why did you pull out? Why did you say you can't use my car? What's going on?
Plaintiff: Okay, I'll tell you.
Defendant: If it's time, yeah.
Defendant: Yeah, it's past time. So are barter deals a good idea?
Judge: Absolutely not. Why?
Defendant: I'm a hair stylist, and I work hard for my job, so I'm not going to make a deal with you because you just expect it in the end.
Judge: Again, I'm not sure what that means because you still get something of value if the barter works. What do you think?
Defendant: I think if you both agree that what you're giving is worth what you're getting, then it should be fine, but you guys have to be on the same page.
Judge: Yeah, and it's hard being on the same page sometimes.
Defendant: It's a little loose going inside the courtroom.
Plaintiff: She'd been using it all of March, right? She lived down just a few miles from me at one point, which was no big deal. She had the car the majority of the time. I was in the hospital part of March anyway. I came home. I can't drive. I am making arrangements to ride the Council on Aging bus to get me to my appointments because I'm a senior, and I'm low income.
Plaintiff: So you look great.
Defendant: Thank you.
Plaintiff: Anyway, she moved to Volano Beach, which was a lot further away.
Defendant: How much further?
Plaintiff: It was a good 10 miles away, one way.
Defendant: Right, and then she would drive back, pick me up.
Judge: Hold on. When did you move?
Defendant: April 1st.
Judge: And it's four— it's four miles. It's not 10 miles.
Judge: So if she— she moved by the time you got the money for the car payment, which you agree is April 8th.
Defendant: I don't know when she moved.
Judge: You don't know?
Defendant: I don't know.
Defendant: I know she used my car to move, which was okay because she didn't have any other way to do it. But then it started being appointments in Jacksonville. Then she— her dentist was a good ways away from Volano Beach. Then she was coming to pick me up. It was just getting to be way too much for me to handle, especially with major surgery. I just wasn't— I mean, I just couldn't do it. I was riding a bus. I was walking. My car was with her a lot of the time.
Plaintiff: Okay, when she offered you a piece of paper and said, "I want you to sign this," there was already hostility between the two of you guys because you felt like she was acting like it's her car?
Defendant: Yeah.
Judge: And it's your car?
Defendant: Yeah.
Plaintiff: All right.
Defendant: So do you have an argument in the car that day?
Defendant: Yes, and yes, we did because she kept on and on. You've got to sign this, and you've got to do this, and you've got to do that. And I'm like, "I don't have to do anything. I don't even have to take you to Jacksonville," and I turned around to take her back home.
Judge: So you didn't take her to Jacksonville?
Defendant: I did take her.
Judge: Yes?
Defendant: Oh, you did. Wait, so you turned around then?
Defendant: Yes, three times. I didn’t watch. I thought my husband and I were the only ones who did that.
Plaintiff: No.
Defendant: No, this— this was a lot of stray U-turns when there's an argument in the car.
Plaintiff: It was very scary. She wanted me to get out of the car.
Judge: Did she tell you to get out?
Defendant: Yes.
Plaintiff: Really?
Defendant: I did because she wouldn't shut her mouth. She almost hit a truck.
Judge: Well, you're a grown woman. You don't have more anger control than that.
Plaintiff: You know, it sounds funny now, but no, it's not. It's terrifying then. You're on a highway, and you're sick, and you're going to an appointment, and it's raining. It's not funny, and she just kept on and on. I said, "I don't have to take you to this appointment." Okay, and I turned around not to take her.
Defendant: But I remembered it was a very important appointment for her.
Judge: Okay, and then you went ahead and took her?
Defendant: Yes, we went on to Jacksonville.
Judge: Did she ever borrow the car after that date?
Defendant: Never.
Judge: I don't know. You might not have.
Defendant: I don't have any— I don’t write down everything I do.
Judge: So did she try to, and you said no?
Defendant: She did try to, and I said no.
Judge: She did try to, and you said no?
Defendant: I won't loan you the car after that argument in the car and her telling me that she had the right to use the car like it was her car all the time.
Judge: Right.
Defendant: And I was upset because there was sunscreen, white sunscreen all over the inside of the car.
Plaintiff: Because she used it while— no.
Defendant: You left all your belongings in the car. You borrowed it more times than you ever did. You don't even remember how many. You don't remember how much.
Plaintiff: Okay, okay.
Defendant: You're paying for this now, not your good friend anymore. Just don't know.
Plaintiff: Yeah, that's right.
Defendant: You're not going to be somebody I try to get back to then.

dialogue:
Judge: "So your child support comes to about nine hundred and sixty-six dollars and 21 cents."

Defendant: "A month? Your Honor, I mean, I put my life on the line every day! I am a cop! And I gotta pay so much for my kids supposedly?"

Judge: The defendant has filed a counter suit for $7,000 for lost wages. All parties, please rise. Welcome back to The People's Court. The defendant says the plaintiff gave him the coin to sell and he could keep anything over $300, and he only made $39. It's the case of "I Took It on Coin-signment, I Swear."

Judge: Thank you. Janina Pagley Arini, you are suing Dan, doing business as The Collector, for $3,500, the value of an Indian gold coin that you say he has kept from you. You have a counterclaim against her for $7,000 in lost wages dealing with this. Let's hear from you first. What's going on?

Plaintiff: Actually, uh, I had looked online about the cost of the coin to sell it, and I had checked with other parties, and just the weight alone on a 22-karat double-headed gold coin is $500 because I had another party check that.

Judge: Okay. Do you have proof of that?

Plaintiff: No, I don't have proof, but I went to the American Numismatic, and uh, they had told me that the coin itself, based on the weight, was $500.

Judge: Okay. Do you have proof of that?

Plaintiff: Yes, I do.

Judge: Okay. Did you show them the coin to get them to give you that estimate?

Plaintiff: No, it is a common coin. And really, I didn't want the money; I just wanted the coin back.

Judge: Okay. I'm sorry, that's the tail end of things. I need to get to the beginning. How did you meet him?

Plaintiff: Uh, I guess he ran into me because he had seen that I looked online about a coin. So that's when the fishing expedition happened, where he followed me into the coffee shop.

Judge: I'm sorry. You think he found you online and then followed you into a coffee shop?

Plaintiff: Yes. Don't laugh, because I go to the coffee shop all the time. I had never seen him in the coffee shop before that time, so I knew that he never frequented that coffee shop until then.

Judge: How did you two meet? He came into that coffee shop and did what?

Plaintiff: Oh, he brought coins and put them on a table as bait. And he told me, "Oh, you have coins."

Judge: How would he know that?

Plaintiff: I think it was that I had looked at the value of my coin online.

Judge: Who spoke first?

Plaintiff: I'm not sure.

Judge: Defendant, how did you two meet?

Defendant: She came up to my table at the coffee shop because she saw me reading a trade publication.

Judge: Did you have coins on the table?

Defendant: No. I was reading Coin World newspaper. She asked me if I collected coins, and I said yes, I collect and deal in coins. She said her mother left her some coins, and maybe we'd get together sometime. Then we talked about various subjects—family, politics—for at least a half hour. Then she asked for my card. I gave her my card, and she said when she was ready, she'd call me and show me her coins for appraisal.

Defendant: A month later, she called, and we met in the coffee shop again. She opened up a little box and showed me one coin at a time. Then I saw a $5 gold piece in a plastic holder in the box. I told her it had a retail value of $500. She said, "Okay, sell it for me." She pulled it out and slid it over to me.

Judge: So she told you to sell the coin?

Defendant: Yes, and I told her I'd try to get $500 for it. She said, "If you get $500, keep $200 for yourself." I knew I probably wouldn't get anything over $300, but she agreed that anything over $300 would be mine.

Judge: How did you sell it?

Defendant: I called a few collectors but had no luck. Eventually, I sold it to a dealer friend for $300.

Judge: Do you have the receipt?

Defendant: Yes, I do.

Judge: Plaintiff, according to you, you didn't authorize him to sell it?

Plaintiff: No, I thought $500 would be my bottom price.

Judge: So you did authorize him to sell it but expected him to call before doing so?

Plaintiff: Yes, and provide me with a receipt.

Judge: Defendant, how did you tell her about the sale?

Defendant: By phone. She then said she didn’t want $300, she wanted $400. Then she said she wanted the coin back, but I told her that wasn’t possible—it had already been sold.

Judge: Why wouldn't you tell her who you sold it to?

Defendant: That’s proprietary information.

Plaintiff: His reputation was already poor online. I checked after he told me he only got $300.

Judge: What did you find?

Plaintiff: The American Numismatic Association told me to report him to the Attorney General.

Judge: Defendant, you have a counterclaim for $7,000 for lost wages. Explain that.

Defendant: By being here, I lost business. I had calls on the way here that I couldn’t take.

Judge: How do you prove that loss?

Defendant: I can’t categorize exactly how much, but it’s based on my income.

Judge: Plaintiff, why are you suing for $3,500?

Plaintiff: Because he didn’t provide a proper receipt for the sale.

Judge: I see the receipt he provided. You made an informal deal in a coffee shop. You agreed to let him sell the coin. But you didn’t set a clear bottom price in writing. Judgment for the defendant on the plaintiff’s claim. And on the counterclaim, I dismiss that as well. Case closed.

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hands.

Judge: Welcome back to The People's Court. The Plaintiff bought a dump truck from the Defendant, but he says it was a piece of junk. The Defendant says there was no warranty, so tough luck. It's the case of taking a dump.

Judge: Juan Vin Rees, you are suing Frank’s Auto Repair Shop. You’ve asked not to mention your last name or the name of the auto repair shop, but you are suing Frank’s Auto Repair Shop. You are the owner, correct?

Defendant: Correct.

Judge: You are suing for $5,000. You say you are actually out more than that because, according to you, they sold you a lemon. Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff: I was looking to buy a dump truck because I was going to start a small business.

Judge: What kind of business?

Plaintiff: A swimming pool business.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: So I was looking for equipment to start up the business. I looked around everywhere, and I ended up going with him. He had a dump truck for sale for $8,000. So I called him up. He said the truck was great. I went to see it. I drove it, but only around the corner for a very short period of time. He said it was good.

Judge: What did your mechanic say?

Plaintiff: Well, I didn’t bring any mechanic. I just went by myself.

Judge: Right.

Plaintiff: He said that any issues with the truck, he would fix.

Judge: Forever?

Plaintiff: Well, some type of warranty.

Judge: What kind of warranty?

Plaintiff: A 30-day warranty.

Judge: So you have a 30-day warranty?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Is it in writing?

Plaintiff: It’s based on New York State law as well.

Judge: Can I see the warranty?

Plaintiff: Sure.

Judge: So I know what’s warranted and what is not. (Examining document) This is a conditional 30-day warranty or 3,000 miles, whichever occurs first. Where’s the explanation of the warranty?

Defendant: I don’t have one with me.

Judge: Do you give one?

Defendant: We do, but with that being said, we would have covered within that period of time essentially any repair.

Judge: Any repair? That’s more than what New York State law requires.

Defendant: Right. In this scenario, I went beyond.

Judge: Was the truck over 100,000 miles?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: So when you sold it, you gave him a 30-day warranty. What goes wrong with the dump truck?

Plaintiff: When I went to register the truck, it started having problems. I went down to register the truck in the middle of March. It wouldn’t start.

Judge: What date did you buy it?

Plaintiff: January 22nd.

Judge: So when did you alert him to a problem?

Plaintiff: February 19th.

Judge: So the truck broke down before you dropped it off again to him?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Did you drive the truck before February 19th?

Plaintiff: No.

Defendant: The truck was dropped off at his home as a courtesy. He wasn’t going to register it for some time due to the seasonal business.

Judge: Then why did you take it for inspection?

Plaintiff: When I was driving it home, it broke down.

Judge: When was that?

Plaintiff: March 10th.

Defendant: We towed it back to my facility in Huntington. It was a fuel pump issue. We replaced it.

Judge: Did you charge him for that?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Then what happened?

Plaintiff: It broke down again.

Defendant: We towed it again, found another fuel pump needed replacing. We did that, no charge.

Judge: Now we're outside the warranty period?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: But you still fixed it for free?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Then what happened?

Plaintiff: It broke down again on April 11th.

Judge: Mr. Rees, you had a 30-day warranty. It expired. Why do you think you are entitled to a refund?

Plaintiff: I only used the truck one day for work before it broke down.

Judge: But was it before the 30 days expired?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: Then you’re outside the warranty.

Plaintiff: But it was a piece of garbage!

Judge: That doesn’t matter. You agreed to the 30-day warranty. That’s your contract. Next time, why not bring a mechanic?

Plaintiff: I didn’t have any friends who could go.

Judge: You don’t need friends. You need to pay a mechanic. If you can’t afford that, then look at what happens. The cheap comes out expensive.

Judge: Your problems happened after the 30 days. End of story. Verdict for the Defendant.

Plaintiff: I don’t think it was fair. I only used the truck one day.

Defendant: We try to do the right thing for all our customers, but you can’t make everyone happy.

Judge: Everybody talks about warranties as if they’re etched in stone. You can always negotiate an extended warranty. That’s something to consider next time.

Judge: Bernard Jamz, you are suing Georgean KO for $1,500 in the amount of an unpaid loan, a loan that you made to her that she just refuses to repay you. Okay, how do you two know each other?

Plaintiff: Um, she's actually, um, a sister of my cousin's wife.

Judge: Wife of your cousin's sister.

Plaintiff: All right, so you've known each other how long?

Plaintiff: Four years.

Judge: And why did she need money?

Plaintiff: She said to pay some bills and stuff that she actually needed.

Judge: And how much money, according to you, did you loan her?

Plaintiff: $1,500.

Judge: Did you get a promissory note?

Plaintiff: No, ma'am.

Judge: Did you tell her you have to pay me back by X, or were you just kind of letting it slide?

Plaintiff: She said she was going to pay me back within two weeks to a month.

Judge: All right, um, she never did. So, when was the first time you called her and said, "Hey, you got to pay me back this money?"

Plaintiff: Weeks after, right.

Judge: And how many times have you called her, and what would she say when you’d call her?

Plaintiff: Well, I must have talked to her maybe 10-15 times, and each time, she would say...

Defendant (interrupting): She doesn’t owe me any money.

Judge: She doesn’t owe you any money?

Defendant: Not at all.

Judge: What's going on?

Defendant: I never borrowed that money for any bills from him at all. I didn’t know him that well to borrow that much money from him. So why would he make up this whole case and come to court?

Judge: I don’t have a... I don’t know, I don’t... he has a mental problem, I don’t know, I’m not a doctor, I have to ask him because he says he's here because he... you owe him money.

Defendant: I already asked him, now I’m asking you.

Defendant: Okay, I don’t owe him money. I didn’t know him.

Judge: You never borrowed any money from him?

Defendant: No.

Judge: No, okay.

Defendant: I did not.

Judge: What’s the story? Who’s she?

Defendant: She’s my witness.

Judge: Okay, what is she a witness to?

Defendant: To Mr. Ramirez threatening to shoot my family and my granddaughter in the head if I didn’t pay him this money.

Judge: That this money that he’s making up?

Defendant: Yes, I had to put a restraining order on him.

Judge: You got a restraining order on him?

Defendant: Yes, I did.

Judge: May I see it?

Defendant: Sure, come on up.

Witness: What are you a witness to?

Witness: I heard him threaten her.

Judge: How did you hear him? Were you in the same room, on the phone?

Witness: On the phone.

Judge: And what did you hear?

Witness: He's sending people over that they're bad people and that he was going to shoot Cherish in the head.

Judge: Whose Cherish?

Defendant: My granddaughter, that I raised. Now she’s 9. At the time, she was 4 and a half.

Judge: Okay, and you heard him say that?

Witness: Yes, I did.

Judge: And did you say that?

Defendant: No, ma’am.

Judge: So can you actually threaten someone with physical harm? Not hitting them or anything, but threatening them if they refuse to pay a loan back and, uh, and you're entitled to get the money?

Plaintiff (interrupting): I don’t see anything wrong in that.

Plaintiff: I don’t. I think...

Judge (interrupting): What do you say?

Plaintiff: I like turtles.

Judge: Um... would you guys think that it’s okay to threaten somebody with physical harm in order to get a loan paid?

Audience: No.

Judge: Okay. Well, violence isn’t the answer.

Audience: Yes, it is illegal.

Judge: It’s also illegal, but we’ll explain going inside the courtroom. Are there any recordings of this?

Plaintiff: She has the detective.

Judge: May I hear the tape?

Plaintiff: I don’t have the tape.

Judge: Why don’t you have the tape?

Plaintiff: Because the detective did not get back to me.

Plaintiff: But I do have a paper stating that he does have the DVD.

Judge: You have a paper?

Plaintiff: Yes, I have the complaint.

Judge: That’s right there, voicemail message, that has the voicemail message that they put on. Can I have the whole police report?

Plaintiff: That’s all that I have.

Judge: That’s all they gave?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Why is this all that you have?

Plaintiff: Because the detective was unavailable the time yesterday when I went there and I called several times. He didn’t return my call.

Judge: She was being threatened by Bernal Ramirez because she owed him money. C statement, that statement right there. This statement right here. This that starts off with, “I owe Bernal Ramirez some money.”

Plaintiff: It was supposed to say "I owed..."

Judge: "I owe Bernal Ramirez some money." Does that sound like a mistake?

Defendant: Right. That was a mistake.

Judge: Does that sound like a mistake to you, Teresa?

Judge: You can say it. We all know what you're thinking.

Witness: She did say she owed him.

Judge: I’m sorry, she did say she owed him, and... oh, wait, wait, wait, let’s go with that.

Judge: So that was the first thing. Stop a second. She owed him money. What did you say?

Plaintiff: I wrote that out for her.

Judge: Oh, so you’re in on this too?

Plaintiff: No, no, no, I wrote this for her.

Judge: So you know that she’s perjuring herself now when she says, “I never borrowed money from him.”

Defendant: I don’t know where he's getting this from.

Judge: But you did say you owed him money. What does that mean? You paid it?

Defendant: I mean, that’s what it would mean to me.

Judge: What does it mean?

Defendant: You tell me.

Judge: That’s what owed means to me.

Defendant: That’s what it would mean.

Judge: So then why would you stand here and perjure yourself 10 seconds ago and say, "I never borrowed money from him?"

Defendant: I don’t know where he’s getting this from, but I’m not perjuring myself because I’ve never borrowed $1,500 from him. The most I ever gave or took from him was about $40, and that he came over to my house and made soup. I never went to his house, sat there and talked to him like we were old friends because I don’t want any part of...

Judge: Why did you write a restraining order?

Defendant: Because he was threatening my family.

Judge: That is why you’d write...

Defendant: He threatened my family because he’s a crazy person.

Judge: Why did you write, “He’s threatening my family because I owe him money that he let me borrow”?

Defendant: If in fact, you didn’t owe him money that he let you borrow, see, I’m only here about the owing money that he let you borrow. That’s what I’m here about. I’m here to find out if he’s telling the truth or if you’re telling the truth.

Judge: How do you think it’s looking?

Defendant: Yeah, it doesn’t look too good for me.

Judge: It doesn’t?

Defendant: It doesn’t.

Judge: It doesn’t look too good for you, honestly.

Defendant: Yeah, sure.

Judge: $1,500. Verdict for the plaintiff.
manipulation_techniques: deflection, gaslighting, Playing the victim, Emotional appeal

dialogue:
**Plaintiff:** This is the plaintiff, Tanisha May. She says she hired the defendant to drive her to work, and they got into an argument in the parking lot. When she went to open the car door, the defendant hit a pillar, and the door swung back into her wrist, injuring it. What the defendant did to her wasn't right. She had to go to a doctor, suffered pain, and is suing for the $5,000 that the defendant owes her.

**Defendant:** This is the defendant, Victor Janua. He says the plaintiff opened her door while he was driving and slammed it into a concrete pillar, then started a ruckus about her hurt hand. If anything did indeed happen to the plaintiff's hand, it was her own fault. He did nothing wrong.

**Judge:** All parties, please rise.

**Judge:** Thank you, Douglas. Tanisha May?

**Plaintiff:** Yes, hi.

**Judge:** You are suing Victor Janua, correct? And Alaji Ba for $5,000 in medical bills and pain and suffering that you say you suffered at the hands of Victor, who was driving Alaji's car. All right, what's going on?

**Plaintiff:** So, um, back in August, I called Reliable Cab to send me a cab. They were an hour and a half late—no, sorry, a half hour late sending me a cab. When Victor arrived, yes, I was angry, but it was nothing directed towards him personally, like attacking him. He's going back and forth with me, and—

**Judge:** Going back and forth how?

**Plaintiff:** Just commenting back on what I'm saying.

**Judge:** What is he saying?

**Plaintiff:** All right, so I had told him that the dispatcher sent me a cab for me. He was like, "No, if that's true, why would he tell me to pick up another person?" I'm like, "I just got off the phone with him." He was like, "Well, you're probably lying." Not "probably lying," but he just said, "Oh, that's not true. He told me to pick up another fare." So, I'm angry, so I made a statement about the car being cheap, and then he was like, "Oh, but you're walking though." Like, he was just going back and forth with me for no reason. Well, not for no reason, but nothing that I was saying was directed towards him, but he was taking it personally.

**Judge:** The car was cheap? Okay, go on.

**Plaintiff:** So, we dropped the first passenger off. As we're driving to my—

**Judge:** Driving to your car?

**Plaintiff:** I'm sorry, driving to my job. I'm sorry.

**Judge:** Your job. Okay. And you work where?

**Plaintiff:** Target.

**Judge:** Okay.

**Plaintiff:** So before we got to my job, I couldn’t tell him that I needed to get cash from the ATM.

**Judge:** Why not?

**Plaintiff:** Because we were going back and forth with each other.

**Judge:** Why didn’t you do that instead of going back and forth? If you knew you had no money to pay for the fare, why were you going back and forth?

**Plaintiff:** That's another thing. I didn’t have money. When I checked my wallet, I was short. So, I was like, "Okay, I have to go inside to get cash." Plus, it was like 5-something in the morning, so no stores were open. Target has an ATM, so I'm like, "Since I'm going to Target, do you mind if I run inside to get cash?" He's like, "Oh, no, you’re trying to play games with me." The door was already open. He drives off. He's driving at a speed where I couldn’t even try to close the door because he’s swerving and stuff. I have a witness, but she couldn’t attend today nor could she provide a written statement, but she was there. She saw everything and even heard the door hit the cement pillar in the parking lot.

**Judge:** So the door opened?

**Plaintiff:** Mm-hmm.

**Judge:** And hit a cement pillar?

**Plaintiff:** Correct.

**Judge:** And then what happens?

**Plaintiff:** He drove me home, and that was it.

**Judge:** Why are you suing?

**Plaintiff:** Because I got injured. My wrist got injured.

**Judge:** How?

**Plaintiff:** I guess the way the door hit the cement pillar and the way it shut—my wrist was swollen.

**Judge:** Was your wrist on the inside of the car?

**Plaintiff:** It was on the inside of the car, but the door was still open. So when he was driving through the lane, there was a cement pillar to the right. He was going at a fast speed, so it shut hard against my wrist.

**Judge:** Was there damage to the door?

**Plaintiff:** I'm not sure. He hit the door and kept going. He never stopped.

**Judge:** If it caused $5,000 worth of injury to your wrist, there had to have been damage to the door. There should be damage to the door.

**Plaintiff:** Well, yeah, when you put it that way, true. But I'm not too sure if there was damage to the car. When I got out of the car, I didn’t look. I just went back into my house and called for another cab.

**Judge:** Did you go to the hospital?

**Plaintiff:** Yes.

**Judge:** What time?

**Plaintiff:** I don’t recall exactly. Maybe later that night.

**Judge:** Do you have hospital records?

**Plaintiff:** I do.

**Judge:** May I see them?

**Plaintiff:** Sure.

**Judge:** Mr. Janua, can you tell me what happened?

**Defendant:** Yes, Your Honor. Like she said, it all started when I picked her up. She was complaining that she was late for work. I explained that I take people from point A to point B. I can’t control what the dispatcher is doing. I had another passenger going in the same direction, so I picked him up. She was complaining about that. When we got to her job, she told me she needed to go inside to use the ATM. I said, "You can’t use the ATM at 4:30 in the morning." I told her, "I feel like you’re playing me. I’m taking you back home." She never opened the door until I was leaving the parking lot. That’s when she slammed the door into the concrete pillar and hurt her own wrist.

**Judge:** My verdict in this case is for the defendant.
manipulation_techniques: playing the victim, exaggeration, evasion, persuasion, framing the narrative

Judge: "So your total monthly obligation in child support is one thousand six hundred ninety-eight dollars and seventy-eight cents. Any questions about that?"

Plaintiff: "I mean, as long as he gets a job and stops living off of me."

Judge: "You know what, ma’am? He can't be living off of you if you haven't given him anything consistently."

Plaintiff: "That's according to him."

Judge: "Okay, well, you haven't provided me with any documents that say otherwise."

Judge: This is the plaintiff, Michael Gordano. He says he was looking for a tenant, and the defendant, a real estate broker, found him a tenant. He guaranteed the rent every month from the tenant. The woman didn’t pay, and the defendant owes him the $5,000 he’s now out because he relied on him and his guarantee.

This is the defendant, James Fauler. He says he found the plaintiff a Section 8 tenant, and that means the rent’s guaranteed to be paid. If Section 8 stopped paying rent to him, that’s on him and his relationship with Section 8. Maybe he didn’t make repairs to the apartment or something. Bottom line, he’s not responsible and says the plaintiff is suing the wrong person. He’s accused of finding a real bad tenant.

All parties, please raise your right hand.

Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case on the docket: the plaintiff asked the defendant, a real estate broker, to find him a tenant, and the tenant ended up stiffing him. He wants the defendant to make it right. But the defendant says it’s not his problem. It’s the case of ‘Get Real.’

Thank you, Douglas. Mr. Gordano, you are suing Mr. Fauler, your real estate agent, for $5,000, the statutory maximum, because according to you, he got you a tenant that didn’t work out.

Plaintiff: Yeah.

Judge: Okay, tell me what happened.

Plaintiff: This tenant that he guaranteed to me—he suggested I take her as a makeup tenant for the previous tenant that he got me, who destroyed my place half a year earlier. He said I should take her as a makeup because her money is guaranteed. And after five months of paying—

Judge: What do you mean as a makeup?

Plaintiff: Well, he got me the previous tenant, who destroyed my place and left it in shambles.

Judge: How is that his fault? Just because he was the broker in the transaction?

Plaintiff: Well, he got me the tenant. He said it was a great young couple guaranteed by the boss, the former landlord. I said okay, and a couple of months later, they were fighting and destroyed my place.

Judge: But how is that his fault?

Plaintiff: Well, I got the tenant from his recommendation.

Judge: Okay, but who pays his fee? You or the tenant?

Plaintiff: I think the tenant does.

Judge: Okay. So then he gets you this tenant in question, and this tenant was somebody who was leaving Section 8, correct? Had you ever dealt with Section 8 before?

Plaintiff: No, but I had heard that they’re good to deal with because their money is guaranteed.

Judge: Well, they could be great. They could be a terrible pain. It just kind of depends. They have to approve it beforehand. If something’s not to their liking, they won’t pay the rent, etc. So you enter into an agreement with both her and Section 8, right?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And then what happens?

Plaintiff: I prepared the place for this second tenant. It passed inspection, she moved in, and she paid for five months. Then all of a sudden, Section 8 cut off her assistance.

Judge: Why?

Plaintiff: They said they discovered that she has other income, so they stopped paying for her.

Judge: So did she get a job and her circumstances changed?

Plaintiff: She said she got a second job.

Judge: So when they found out she got a second job, they said, ‘You can pay your rent, and we don’t need to help you. There are other people we have to help.’ So they stopped paying. What’s the agreement that you, as a landlord, enter into with Section 8? That they have to pay for a whole year?

Plaintiff: Well, they said that they are—

Judge: Let me see your Section 8 paperwork.

Plaintiff: (Hands document to judge)

Judge: Oh, well, this is a notice of ender payment change or termination. They reduced her payments.

Plaintiff: Yes, they reduced her payments, and so she was supposed to be paying more of the rent.

Judge: And then she said, ‘I can’t afford this place.’ Did she move out?

Plaintiff: No, she squatted for four months. It’s on the second floor of my house, so I observed and heard people coming in and socializing in my second floor as they were squatting. I said, ‘When are you going to pay the rent?’ She said, ‘I’ll pay the rent as soon as I can.’

Judge: Is she still there? Why don’t you just evict her?

Plaintiff: I did. It cost me the sheriff’s eviction expense.

Judge: That’s what everybody has to do. All of us mere mortals have to go to landlord-tenant court.

Plaintiff: I did. I went through the process of evicting her, and that took four months.

Judge: Oh, but you got her out now?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Okay, that was my question. You’re not helpless. So how do you figure that Mr. Fauler owes you a guarantee on a tenant that he gets you?

Defendant: I never personally guaranteed anything.

Judge: Did you act as a personal guarantor on a tenant for this gentleman?

Defendant: No, your honor.

Judge: Have you ever guaranteed a tenant’s payment?

Defendant: No, your honor.

Judge: Then why does he think that you did?

Defendant: I don’t know, your honor.

Judge: So, Mr. Gordano, you’re saying that because the defendant said ‘Section 8 means guaranteed money,’ you took that as a personal guarantee from him?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: That’s not how it works. Verdict for the defendant.
manipulation_techniques: persuasion, exaggeration, playing the victim, framing the narrative

Judge: This is the plaintiff, Debbie San Filipo. She says the defendant, her ex-boyfriend, is stiffing her on a Jeep she sold him. The loser never put oil in it, he ended up blowing the engine, and now refuses to pay her because he says she sold him a lemon. Well, we’ll see about that. He’s accused of not blowing off an ax.

Bailiff: All parties, please hit your rting.

Judge: Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case on the docket—the plaintiff says her ex is stiffing her on a Jeep that she sold him. He didn’t put oil in it, blew the engine, and refuses to pay. Now, he says she sold him a junker. It’s the case of Jeepers Creepers.

Thank you, Doug.

Bailiff: You’re welcome.

Judge: Okay, Miss San Filipo, you are suing your former boyfriend, who’s also your neighbor?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: For not paying you back $2,400 on a car you sold him, right?

Plaintiff: Yes, ma’am.

Judge: So, let me see if I got this straight—you sold a used car to your ex-boyfriend, who was also your neighbor.

Plaintiff: Right.

Judge: That didn’t seem like a bad idea?

Plaintiff: It didn’t, because he lived right across the street. I thought I’d get paid, didn’t think it’d be a problem.

Judge: I wouldn’t sell a used car to anyone I knew that I wanted to be able to still talk to. But apparently, you guys were friends?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: You remained friendly?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: How long did you date?

Plaintiff: Four years.

Judge: Okay, and so you had a Jeep. What year Jeep was it?

Plaintiff: It was a ‘93 Jeep.

Judge: Okay. And so, you sold it to him, and he was going to make you payments?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: He didn’t pay you upfront?

Plaintiff: No, he gave me $100 down and was supposed to give me $100 out of each paycheck, and he didn’t do it.

Judge: Right. One thing you said in your complaint was, “I covered my butt every which way.”

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: Because on my bill of sale, I made sure it said, “As is. No warranties, no guarantees, anything.”

Judge: Okay. And that’s really good. But I have a better way to cover your derrière, and that’s to—whenever you sell a used car, get your cash upfront.

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Because that side—if they can’t afford to buy a car, they can’t afford to repair it. You see? And the first time there’s a repair, you’re not going to get paid.

Plaintiff: Right.

Judge: Now, according to you, you didn’t get paid anything at all after the $100?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: All right, let me see the bill of sale.

Plaintiff: Yes, I spoke to him on the phone, and he's also in the group chat. After the trip was booked, I sent the itinerary. After that, he said, "Could I just give you cash?" So he knew it was completely booked, and he was going to give me cash. I told him yeah.

Judge: And then what happened?

Plaintiff: A couple of days went past. He was supposed to give me the money. We spoke on the phone again, and he told me like, he’s not going. He didn’t know I already booked the trip. Then I responded to that message, telling him everything that he said, and he didn’t respond to my texts or calls.

Judge: You’ve never talked to him since then?

Plaintiff: I haven’t talked to him since then.

Judge: Okay, so you and your other friend end up going anyway?

Plaintiff: Yeah, we had to cancel and rebook.

Judge: Right, but you’re going to have to prove to me you paid $900 in cancellation fees.

Plaintiff: I can prove it.

Judge: Okay. All right. So this is from United Vacations, what they sent over saying about the refund. It was $300 per person. United Vacations canceled. How did you get this?

Plaintiff: Oh, they emailed it to me.

Judge: Can I see the email that they sent you that shows that it came from them?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And while he's looking for that, what’s your story?

Defendant: He knew—everybody knows that I’m a supervisor at my job. I’m salaried, it’s hard to get days off. Him and my other friend both knew that. The other friend knew that, that’s why he ain’t suing me. He knows.

Judge: What did you tell him? Did you tell him, "Go ahead and make the reservation?"

Defendant: No, I did not. He’s saying that. He is telling me he got a nice deal, whatever, whatever. He never told me to—I never said, "Pay for the trip."

Judge: Did he tell you, "Look, today’s the deadline, we’ve got to pay"? And did you say, "Yeah, okay, do it?"

Defendant: No.

Judge: So now you’ve been able to prove to me that you’re out the money. So the next question is: Show me that it’s his fault that you’re out the money. In other words, show me the conversations that you have with him where he says, "Yeah, go for it. I’m in."

Plaintiff: All right. I can go to the texts.

Judge: You need your phone, right?

Plaintiff: Yeah, and set it so it won’t be scrambled.

Judge: Because it’s simple—you either agreed to do this and then left him hanging, or you didn’t agree to do this.

Defendant: Right. I said I wanted to go. I never said, "Go ahead, pay for the trip."

Judge: Let’s see. Let’s see how the language starts on January 22nd. Okay, hand it over.

Judge: I spend my life scrolling. I have arthritis in my right thumb.

Judge: What is the day that you had to pay the money?

Plaintiff: I believe the 22nd of January.

Judge: There’s not a single text from him agreeing to pay? You’re texting him, but he’s not answering?

Plaintiff: We spoke on the phone. I have our call log too.

Judge: All right. But you don’t have texts proving that he authorized you to spend. But after it was booked, he—you can see where he agreed to send the money over several times.

Judge: So then you don’t have a text proving he authorized it beforehand. But he does say, "Can’t I just give you the cash?" Why would he say that if he didn’t think he owed you the cash?

Defendant: That was before my job said I couldn’t go.

Judge: Oh, well, then that’s on you, isn’t it? Then maybe what you should have been saying to him was, "Absolutely not, don’t include me because I have to first check with my job."

Judge: Verdict for the plaintiff. $900.

Defendant: Nobody told him to pay for that.

Judge: Your mothers must be so upset at you. What do they say about you two being here?

Defendant: I ain’t telling my mother.

Judge: Oh, well, I got some bad news for you. Your mother’s a huge fan, and she’s going to see you. Surprise!

Judge: Case dismissed. Pay the man.

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hand. Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case on the docket: the plaintiff says the defendant refuses to return her security deposit, and it’s all revenge. But the defendant says the plaintiff was conducting her hair business in the apartment and did lots of damage. It’s the case of what tangled webs we weave. Thank you, Douglas.

Melissa Jackson, you are suing your former landlord, Diane David, for $1,925 for your security deposit plus a parking ticket that you think she should pay for. Okay, tell me what happened.

Plaintiff: Okay, basically, I moved into Miss Davis' apartment on April 3rd.

Judge: Of what year?

Plaintiff: 2015.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: So, it’s a split-level house, and she lived in the front, and I lived in the back.

Judge: All right, so what happened?

Plaintiff: Basically, when I moved in, I told her that I had a fish tank and a turtle at the time. I did upgrade. I had a 10-gallon tank, and I upgraded to a 55-gallon.

Defendant: Exactly.

Judge: Is that allowed?

Plaintiff: Yes, it is.

Defendant: She claimed that I changed the fish tank water every day. That’s not true. I had four kids—13, 11, 7, and 4. They constantly used the bathroom. She basically told me that I couldn’t flush the toilet every day. She was complaining about the water bill.

Judge: Her water bill went up, and she was paying that, so she was mad at you?

Plaintiff: Exactly.

Judge: How much was Section 8 paying?

Plaintiff: $1,250.

Judge: And then you were paying how much?

Plaintiff: Nothing, the rent was $1,250.

Judge: That’s what I was trying to figure out. So, your lease should have taken you through what month in a year?

Plaintiff: A year, so April 2016.

Judge: And when did you move out?

Plaintiff: July 31st, 2016.

Judge: So, you stayed month to month. When you moved out, what condition did you leave the place in?

Plaintiff: I left it immaculate.

Judge: Did you take pictures?

Plaintiff: Yes, ma’am.

Judge: Did you take video?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: According to you, you are refusing to return the security deposit because she left the place damaged?

Defendant: Yes, she did.

Judge: Did you take pictures?

Defendant: Yes, I did.

Judge: Did you take video?

Defendant: No, I didn’t.

Judge: Okay, according to you, you left it clean. Let me see your pictures and your video.

Plaintiff: Your Honor, I also have the apartment checklist. I cleaned the whole apartment. She never cleaned it before I moved in.

Judge: Section 8 wouldn’t let you move in unless they did an inspection first.

Defendant: True.

Judge: Let me ask you a question. What are the damages that caused you to keep the entire security deposit?

Defendant: I have pictures.

Judge: Can I see them?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Did you submit all the pictures into evidence?

Defendant: I did.

Judge: Hold on and let me see if I’ve got them here. Okay, what’s this a picture of?

Defendant: This is the corner molding of the house outside.

Judge: And according to you, it was that way when you got it?

Plaintiff: We had a big snowstorm. After that snowstorm, that’s what resulted when the snow melted. It wasn’t my fault.

Judge: Thank you. Let’s move on to the next picture.

(Conversation continues analyzing damages, claims, and counterclaims.)

Judge: I’m looking at the receipts and pictures. I’m making a decision. Some things you can clearly prove happened during her care, and some things you cannot. Did she do anything deliberate to damage the place?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: What did she do deliberately?

Defendant: When she left, the entire place smelled like smoke and urine.

Judge: Did you spread urine around the place?

Plaintiff: No! My witness cleaned the whole apartment before I left. Here’s the exit checklist.

Judge: Do you have proof you contacted Section 8?

Plaintiff: I did email her.

Judge: May I see the email?

Plaintiff: I can go look for it.

Judge: Forget it. I’m calculating the damages and making my ruling.

Judge: Emmy Vega. Yes, you are suing Leon Brown for a $1,000 deposit that you want returned to you because you did not actually move in. Tell me what happened here.

Plaintiff (Amy Vega): Okay, so, um, my whole family had kind of got evicted, and we couldn't afford to live together anymore, so we kind of all just separated. I came straight out of high school, and I didn’t have a job. I have credit—

Judge: Wait, wait, you had just graduated from high school?

Plaintiff (Amy Vega): Yeah, I—me.

Judge: How many of you were living together when you got evicted?

Plaintiff (Amy Vega): Five of us.

Judge: Okay, so it was your mom?

Plaintiff (Amy Vega): It was my mom.

Judge: Is this your mom?

Plaintiff (Amy Vega): Yes.

Judge: You and who else?

Plaintiff (Amy Vega): My two brothers and my grandma.

Judge: And who's the gentleman who's here?

Plaintiff (Amy Vega): This is my boyfriend.

Judge: So, everybody had to separate, and what did you do?

Plaintiff (Amy Vega): I started trying to figure out where to live. I first was going to live with my brother, but that didn’t work out, so I decided to try to find a room to rent out. And because I didn’t have credit and I didn’t have a job, most people, they didn’t want to even look in my direction. So I found an ad, and I contacted multiple people, and Leon was the one who responded to me. We made a contract saying that I would live there for three months. Two months' rent would be $500, and the third month would be free. So, I gave him $1,000 in cash, and I have a receipt that we both signed.

Judge: And where were you going to live in their place?

Plaintiff (Amy Vega): Um, in their room.

Judge: In their room?

Plaintiff (Amy Vega): Yes.

Judge: How come? Like, that's kind of peculiar.

Defendant (Leon Brown): Um, so, um, on the meeting of her coming to my apartment to see the place still was the option of her staying in the room with us or having her own private room. But the private room cost more.

Judge: Who is living in there?

Defendant (Leon Brown): There was nobody.

Judge: Well, actually, you're going to have her move into your room?

Defendant (Leon Brown): So, I mean, that's a little peculiar, isn’t it? Because you were hoping to rent that out to someone else for more?

Defendant (Leon Brown): Yeah.

Judge: So there's a perfectly good empty room, but she is paying to live inside the same room that you two are using. How? Where was she going to sleep?

Defendant (Leon Brown): Well, um, I was offering her—there was an air mattress. An air mattress, so she could sleep on the air mattress in your room.

Judge: Correct. That's not going to afford you a lot of privacy, is it?

Defendant (Leon Brown): Well, the—um, honestly, the only reason that I actually chose to assist her is because of her situation. If it wasn’t anything else, then I would have never suggested it.

Judge: Okay, I'm taking it from the fact that you can’t let go of her hand—that’s your girlfriend, right?

Defendant (Leon Brown): Yes, ma'am.

Judge: Okay, and so how did you feel about that?

Defendant’s girlfriend (Leon’s girlfriend): Not great.

Judge: So would you ever, you know, in a desperate situation, move in with a boyfriend and girlfriend, and they're together and live in the same room? What do you say?

Defendant’s girlfriend (Leon’s girlfriend): No, definitely not.

Judge: What would the option be that's better than that if you're really desperate?

Defendant’s girlfriend (Leon’s girlfriend): I wouldn’t be that desperate. I'd go back home.

Judge: Well, that’s a good one. Go back home.

Judge: What do you say?

Plaintiff (Amy Vega): Um, no, we share a room, boyfriend, girlfriend here. Uh, I would not want to be that third person in a room.

Judge: Okay. Well, was that a warning going inside the courtroom?

Defendant (Leon Brown): Alright, so what happens? You hand over $1,000, and then what happened? Where'd you get the $1,000?

Plaintiff (Amy Vega): Um, um, we had got into a car accident, me and my brother, my mom, and she had sued, um, not sure for how much.

Judge: So you hand over $1,000, and what happened?

Plaintiff (Amy Vega): Um, I think four days before I was supposed to move in, my mom had informed me that they were going to clear out the apartment, 'cause it was supposed to be an eviction. So everything was kind of done in a rush. Um, so I asked him if I could move my stuff in, and I did. So I decided that that—like not at the moment—but I, um, eventually…

Judge: Come on, come on.

Plaintiff’s mom: No, no, right there. Right there.

Judge: Sorry. You go over to help her move in?

Plaintiff (Amy Vega): Yes.

Judge: And what happens?

Plaintiff (Amy Vega): First of all, as I walk in, there's a whole bunch of suitcases lined up on the stairs, on the steps to go up, and the smell of cat urine was unbearable. I just told her, "You cannot stay here. You cannot stay here." So, what did you do?

Plaintiff (Amy Vega): But it was her decision.

Judge: You folks end up calling the police?

Plaintiff (Amy Vega): Yeah.

Judge: And what happened?

Plaintiff (Amy Vega): Uh, they went upstairs. They talked to both of us, and they said that this is a civil matter for court, and at that moment, they suggested that he write up a contract for a refund.

Judge: They suggested that you write up a contract for a refund?

Plaintiff (Amy Vega): Yes.

Judge: And who wrote up the contract?

Plaintiff (Amy Vega): Leon did.

Judge: And we both agreed to it.

Judge: Okay, and does anybody have a copy of the contract?

Plaintiff (Amy Vega): I do. I have, um, crude pictures.

Judge: I apologize.

Judge: That's better than not having anything. And you have the contract itself? Let's see it.

Plaintiff (Amy Vega): Yeah, this is my copy.

Judge: Let’s see your crude pictures.

Plaintiff (Amy Vega): Who types this up? You do?

Defendant (Leon Brown): I typed it up.

Judge: Okay, on October 28th, I, Leon Brown, have agreed to return her money, which she paid to me on October 17th in a payment agreement since Amy Vega is insisting on the return of her thousand on this date, three full days before the terms of the contract were supposed to begin. Both parties, Amy Vega and myself, are agreeing that the aforementioned housing contract is completely null and void and hereby terminated. Well, that's an interesting twist of events. I will agree to start paying Amy Vega back on December 1st. Did you pay her on December 1st?

Defendant (Leon Brown): No, I did not.

Judge: Okay. I will pay her $200 a month until the entire $1,000 is returned by registered money order mailed to PO box. In conclusion, Amy Vega, nor anyone affiliated with her, shall not have any personal contact with me or come near my property.

Judge: So, my dear, why am I here? Explain it to me.

Defendant (Leon Brown): Because you appear to have already signed something saying that in return for taking monthly payments and in return for leaving peacefully, you are going to return her money.

Judge: What happened?

Defendant (Leon Brown): So, based on—so that you authored, what happened?

Defendant (Leon Brown): So on the day of the signing of the contract, I took—I took what she wrote on my copy of the contract as a form of insult and sort of as a threat, as in like that whoever she’s not responsible for whoever, but I feel—

Judge: Has anybody come to your place and threatened you?

Defendant (Leon Brown): I—I haven’t.

Judge: Okay, so then if nobody’s come to your place and threatened you, can you tell me why you didn’t abide by this?

Defendant (Leon Brown): You don’t have the money?

Defendant (Leon Brown): No, I do not have the money.

Judge: Okay, you’re entitled to your money. Oddly, you wouldn’t be, but for this contract, because when you toss a thousand dollars at someone to rent a place that you know exactly what the situation is, just 'cause your mom comes later and says, “This is a really ridiculous situation,” doesn’t mean you get to not be bound by your contracts. If this weren’t here, you’d be out a thousand bucks. But this is here, and this is a new contract that supersedes the agreement to rent the place. This is one that says we are both—both recon, that you authored. So there’s no duress or anything else. You know where you say, "You know what, I just want this over with. I don’t have your money to give it back to you now, but I’ll tell you what, if you’ll take payments, don’t sue me, you’ll take payments, and you know that’s how I’ll pay you back, but only $200 a month. That’s all I can do." And she agrees. Offer acceptance. New contract. That’s what this is. And then you breach this by not paying. Okay, now what are you doing now?

Judge: I’m worried about you. I want to know what you’re doing now.

Defendant (Leon Brown): I’m currently renting a room in Queens, and I’m working.

Judge: How much are you paying in rent?

Defendant (Leon Brown): $900.

Judge: Okay, I’m splitting it with my boyfriend.

Judge: And how are you doing? 'Cause I—because everybody here sounds like they’re in dire straits. You know, when you have to bring somebody to sleep on your floor, it can’t be good, is what I’m saying.

Defendant (Leon Brown): To answer your question, we’re actually doing much better. We haven’t had a roommate in quite a long time, and he actually got a promotion at work a couple of months ago.

Judge: Good, and um, we’re doing much better.

Judge: Good, 'cause I like ending on a happier note. However, that $1,000 does have to go back to her because of your own contract.

Judge: Verdict for the plaintiff, $1,000. Good luck, folks.

Plaintiff's Lawyer: Now, Detective Carpo, as we talk about compromising a crime scene, you can confirm your knowledge of a valet being removed, correct?

Defendant: Yes.

Plaintiff's Lawyer: But you don't know if there were other items, like a weapon, that could have also been removed from that crime scene?

Defendant: Correct.

Plaintiff's Lawyer: Correct. You don't know if other items have been moved from one place and put in another place?

Defense Lawyer: Objection, Your Honor. There is absolutely no evidence that anything was moved.

Judge: That's right. There's no evidence. Don't imply something that there is no evidence of. There's been no evidence introduced in this case by any witness that is even close to that. That assumes facts not in evidence. Sustained. Move on to a relevant question. Don't imply things that have not occurred and are not in evidence. Move on.

Judge: Miss Ker, you are suing On Your Side Auto Sales, represented by Joseph Merina—you’re the owner?

Defendant: Yes, I am.

Judge: Okay, for $2,000—the value of an ‘05 Pontiac Aztec that you traded in, and then things went all wrong with this deal. What happened here?

Plaintiff: Well, I traded in my 2005 Pontiac Aztec for the Toyota Rav 4.

Judge: What year?

Plaintiff: 2008.

Judge: All right. Now, how old are you?

Plaintiff: 31.

Judge: All right, so you traded it in, you signed the—wow, you look so much younger.

Do you have the paperwork from that trade-in?

Plaintiff: Yes, I do.

Judge: Okay, let me see it.

Did you put down any cash or just the car?

Plaintiff: Just the car.

Judge: Why does it say "amount received: deposit paid by cash"?

Plaintiff: That’s what he told me to say—that he’d put an extra $1,000 down, but I didn’t.

Judge (to Defendant): Why would you tell her to say that?

Defendant: She didn’t give us any cash. We were just giving her a receipt that says that she paid cash.

Judge: Um… it was just used to get the finance bought from the bank?

Defendant: Yeah.

Judge: So you tell the bank that you are trying to help her get financed by saying that she came in with cash that she didn’t come in with?

Why don’t you just tell the bank the truth—that she put down a $2,000 car?

Defendant: We could have, I suppose.

Judge: But why didn’t you?

Defendant: We just… we didn’t write it that way.

Judge: Yeah, but there’s a reason. I’m not an idiot, and neither are you—I hope.

So what is the reason?

Defendant: Because they want to see some type of deposit out of the customer. She wasn’t able to give us anything.

Judge: Then don’t give her something that says she did.

This is paperwork created that’s completely false to try to send to the finance company.

But why is it better to say "$1,000 cash" than "$2,000 in a trade-in"?

Defendant: It’s hard when somebody comes in with bad credit and doesn’t bring any cash along with them.

Judge: So saying that she brought cash when she didn’t would make it more likely for her to get financing, correct?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: So we’re lying to the finance company in order for her to get financing—because it’s in your best interest to sell a car.

So we’re going to lie to the finance company.

All right, I got it.

So now she applies for financing, and what happens?

Defendant: So we got a couple of options for financing, but we didn’t have very many options for vehicle selection.

I gave her a couple of cars to choose from. She chose a Toyota Rav 4.

We contracted the deal with no money down, using her trade-in. She signed over the car as a trade—the ‘05 Pontiac Aztec.

We plated her, and we let her drive off the lot.

Judge: Right. And so, did she have financing for the rest?

Defendant: She did not.

She used a company to get financing for the rest.

Judge: But you’re the one who gives her the company, right?

Like, the company you use—the one you sent that other stuff to?

What ends up happening with that?

Defendant: Everything gets packaged up, sent over to the finance company. They go over the documentation we supplied them.

Then, during the process of wrapping it up, they noticed that she has a permit. They contacted the dealership and asked why she was submitted with a permit.

Judge: Why was she?

Defendant: Well, we didn’t know she had a permit.

Judge: Didn’t see her license?

Defendant: We may have missed the permit situation. But we gave her the opportunity to do two things…

Judge: Do you have a permit?

Plaintiff: Yes, I do.

Judge: Why don’t you have a full license?

Plaintiff: I had to take the driver’s course.

Judge: You’re 31 years old—you know what it’s like. Why buy a car before being able to drive alone in the car?

Plaintiff: Just my dumb mistake.

Judge: Okay. But what is it to you?

You’re a businessman.

How old are you?

Defendant: 36.

Judge: Okay. Everybody looks so young to me—I’m getting sick of it.

All right, so you’re 36. You own a business. For how long?

Defendant: Seven years.

Judge: All right.

And so, your answer to me for why you sold a car to someone with a permit?

Defendant: We have financing for permit drivers.

Judge: Well, why didn’t you do that?

Defendant: This particular company would allow her some time to either get a road test completed or to have a co-signer.

Judge: So why didn’t that happen?

Defendant: She didn’t have a co-signer.

Judge: And who is responsible for the $14,000 loan?

Defendant: The co-signer.

Judge: See, that’s not the same deal, is it?

You’re going to pay her the Blue Book value of the car, which is $2,000.

That is my ruling.

Judge: You are suing Robert Wallace doing business as DJ Robbie Rob, yes? Did I say it right? For fun, I try to put some attitude in it—for $500?

Judge: And?

Plaintiff: I called DJ Robbie Rob the same day and let him know what was going on.

Judge: How long ago—how long previously had you booked him?

Plaintiff: I believe it was a month before.

Judge: Did you sign anything?

Plaintiff: I did.

Judge: May I see what you signed?

Plaintiff: Yes.

(Hands document to judge.)

Judge: Are there any additional terms and conditions? It says on the bottom it should be two pages. Oh, where's the second page?

Plaintiff: He never gave me a second.

Judge: All right, let's see the second page.

(Hands document to judge.)

Judge: Let me make a suggestion to you—especially when you have space down here—never put this on a second page. It’s not signed also, because—watch this. Did you ever get this? It says that the deposit’s non-refundable. So, for your own protection, either have them initial it or sign it. It says on a contract, the signature is on the front.

Defendant: No, I see it on both pages. I see it, I see it.

Judge: Yeah, I got it. But I'm just saying, as a lawyer, I'm giving you some free advice, okay? Free advice, no charge at all. You never want a page of the contract to not have either signatures or initials. That’s why, when contracts are prepared by lawyers, there’s a space for everybody’s initials on every single page so someone doesn’t say that page—like it’s happening right here.

Judge: So let’s talk, Ms. Gladden. I'm very sorry that the plans—you’re not getting married, right?

Plaintiff: Yeah.

Judge: And have you broken up with him?

Plaintiff: No, we have a child in common.

Judge: Okay, well that doesn’t mean you have to stay with him forever, especially if he beat you.

Plaintiff: No, he didn’t beat me up.

Judge: Oh. What did he get arrested for?

Plaintiff: He had a warrant out.

Judge: Why did the police get called to your home?

Plaintiff: Because he jumped up in my face and was acting irrational.

Judge: And what was the warrant for?

Plaintiff: I'm not really sure.

Judge: Domestic violence?

Plaintiff: No, it wasn’t for domestic violence.

Judge: All right. Well, here’s the thing though: You provided a $500 deposit, and now you want the $500 deposit back.

Judge: Is that his fault?

Plaintiff: No, it’s not.

Judge: So, January 14, you pay the $500. And what is the day that you cancel?

Plaintiff: February 17th.

Judge: Okay. So, let me hear from you.

Defendant: She called me up, she said she needed a DJ. How much would that cost for her date? And I told her I would have to come look at the location because if I have to get a sound system—because I’m pretty professional—I would have to come see it, take pictures, and measure the room. Defendant: Every single day in a month. So she’d call me out the week maybe three or four times. I feel like, you know, I’m a child of God, so I help people—not just her, everybody. Defendant: Yes. And she said, “You won’t believe where I’m at.” And I talked to her, told her everything was going to be all right.
