Judge: Did you go to his mother’s house?

Plaintiff: No.

(Continues with dispute over texts and contract details)

Judge: Verdict in this case is for the defendant. A counterclaim?

Defendant: No, no, it’s cool.

Judge: All right, you’re withdrawing the counterclaim in your show of good faith. Bless you. Adios.

Judge: Mr. Laxon, you're suing Ms. Hoffman for the return of your security deposit, plus you want to be paid for painting a place that you hadn’t even signed a lease for yet, correct?

Plaintiff: Correct.

Judge: Okay. What happened here?

Plaintiff: Well, um, I was actually at home, and my mother happened to call me. She’s like, “Hey, I found a place for you. I want you to go look at it.” So, we go look at it, and I should have known something was wrong then because she never came upstairs to show us the place.

Judge: Who’s “she”?

Plaintiff: The defendant. She actually had me and another person go look at it.

Judge: The other person was someone looking to rent it as well?

Plaintiff: Correct.

Judge: So, she had kind of like an open house at a certain time, just meeting everybody there and renting it to the first person she liked?

Judge’s Ruling

Defendant: But I held the apartment for him!

Judge: That was your choice. If you wanted a firm commitment, you should have had him sign the lease before giving you any money. Judge: But you haven't proven that. I’m ruling in favor of the plaintiff for $1,463.61. You have to pay that because the man is out that amount.

JUDGE:

The month of March and April.

JUDGE:
For March toward April?

Yeah, because you get paid every third Friday.

JUDGE:
And you were getting paid $750 a month?

PLAINTIFF:
Yes.

JUDGE:
All right. When she fired you, did she tell you why she was firing you?

JUDGE:

PLAINTIFF:
No, I didn’t have any problems with her at all before that.

PLAINTIFF:

JUDGE:
And at this daycare, her mother was working there too?

PLAINTIFF:
Yes.

JUDGE:
That’s your great-aunt?

PLAINTIFF:

JUDGE:

"Judge: All parties, please raise your hands.
Judge: We see it come to order.
Judge: Please raise your right hand.
Judge: You are under oath.
Judge: Susan J Gordon, yes you are suing Mary Rose Angle and Todd Angle. Mr. Angle, you'll be representing both yourself and—uh, is that your wife?
Todd Angle: It is.
Judge: Okay, and you have power of attorney to do so. You are suing them for copyright infringement to the tune of $5,000, which is the statutory maximum in New York. You say your damage is actually more than that because they used seven of the stories that you have previously published in a book, and they added those seven stories 29 times on their website. Okay, let's talk.
Judge: You wrote a book called Wedding Days: When and How Great Marriages Began, and tell us what the book's about.
Susan J. Gordon: It's a collection of hundreds of stories about the courtships and marriages of famous couples throughout history. Famous couples such as John and Jacqueline Kennedy, Napoleon and Josephine, Lucy and Desi, Martin Luther and Coretta Scott King. It took me over three years to write this book.
Judge: When did you write the book?
Susan J. Gordon: The book was published in 1998.
Judge: 1998, and it took you three years up to that point, full three years of research and writing to collect these stories.
Judge: How many stories are in here?
Susan J. Gordon: One for every day of the year, and I added Adam and Eve on February 29th because I just had fun imagining what their wedding day would be like.
Judge: I've read the excerpts of the book that are on your website, and this is so right up my alley, I can't tell you. You know, these short stories are... I hate to say bathroom reading, but you don't have to commit a long time. I know it sounds awful, but you know, you can have it on a cocktail table. Somebody can look at it for just a little bit. You don’t have to commit.
Judge: Each one is so enticing because I am so gossipy, and I love hearing these little details. And you've got a picture of the couples. I mean, this is really very enjoyable.
Judge: Now, you did publish it a long time ago. I imagine that as most books, you know, the sales start to—unless you're the Bible—the sales start to eventually wither, right? That's normal for a book.
Susan J. Gordon: Very normal, especially after we're talking about 10, 15 years now.
Judge: So right now, if I wanted to buy the book, what's the average price of the book online?
Susan J. Gordon: The book varies online. It is sold by used book dealers at this point. You can pay $5, you can pay $170, or you might be able to pay 90 cents or a dollar.
Judge: I know because I went online.
Judge: Okay. But so now you published this book about 15 years ago or so, and then you, um, you periodically go online checking to see if someone's using the book?
Susan J. Gordon: No, I go online, uh, as yourself. Stories popped up in many different places. Their website had 29 times.
Judge: So sometimes 25, 26?
Susan J. Gordon: When you say 29 times, you're not saying because you kept pressing the same page. You're saying in 29 sites?
Susan J. Gordon: Yes, because now when you find out that they've used your work, by the way, are they citing to you? Are they quoting you as the author, or are they just using your work without permission, which is not following copyright law?
Susan J. Gordon: No, they are not citing me.
Judge: Okay. So when you find out that they are not citing your work, they are giving you credit, but they never asked your permission, what did you do?
Susan J. Gordon: I was stunned. I spoke to my husband, who was a lawyer, although he's not an intellectual property lawyer.
Judge: What kind of lawyer is he?
Susan J. Gordon: He is a real estate lawyer, so it's nothing to do with it, but he's smart. He also helped me with the research, and he loved it too.
Susan J. Gordon: So we contacted them several weeks later, I would say early June or late May, I think in June, and asked that they please remove the stories forthwith. Did they?
Todd Angle: Not entirely. Some lingered into June. I don’t know why. This all started around May 20th, 22nd.
Judge: When were you contacted by her to cease and desist?
Todd Angle: I think it was around June.
Judge: And what did you do?
Todd Angle: We were kind of shocked in the beginning. We were pretty naive about copyright laws, to be honest. We immediately called Mr. Gordon, apologized, and I told him we would take it down right away.
Todd Angle: They’re correct. We mistakenly missed one of them.
Judge: So they asked us to save the files. We did, on the server.
Judge: And that was about what we did. We just pulled it all down.
Judge: What is this site? Tell me what this is.
Todd Angle: My wife started a blog in the beginning of the year 2011. The intent of the blog was to educate people on different wedding issues, you know, gay marriages. Also, she's an Interfaith minister, so a lot of interfaith topics and things like that. It was more for her to inform the public about weddings and also get used to doing a blog. We were kind of new to this technology.
Judge: What kind of traffic did your blog have?
Todd Angle: It doesn’t have much traffic at all.
Judge: Say you show me some proof of what kind of traffic your blog has.
Todd Angle: Well, I have the chart for those seven postings— a chart of all the people that did click-throughs through that.
Judge: So during the whole time, how long did you have her articles up?
Todd Angle: I believe it was at maximum 60 days.
Judge: For those 60 days, you notice it in May?
Todd Angle: Yes.
Judge: So for those 60 days, that's what you're going to show me. How many people clicked?
Todd Angle: 154 times.
Judge: Okay. Why were you thinking this was going to be okay? Just in general, that you could take somebody's work?
Todd Angle: At the time, she thought that, uh... Did you know she was doing this?
Susan J. Gordon: No.
Judge: What’s your profession?
Todd Angle: I'm a project manager.
Judge: Why isn’t she here?
Todd Angle: She’s out of the country. She's working for a nonprofit.
Judge: So did you know she was doing this?
Todd Angle: No, I didn’t.
Judge: You found out when you were found out.
Todd Angle: Yes.
Judge: Let’s talk about this. There is a concept, which I'm sure you are both extremely familiar with, and the law calls the fair use doctrine.
Judge: The rule is you can’t use other people's stuff without paying them. That’s the rule. That's why they copyright their work. You’re not allowed to use someone else’s intellectual property.
Judge: The exception is if you've used it in a way that the law looks at as fair use. There are four factors that the courts look at in order to determine if what the purported infringer did was a copyright violation or fair use.
Judge: Let’s go over them:
Judge: One, the purpose of the use.
Judge: Was it used in a non-commercial or commercial setting?
Judge: You said it was on their website. What is your website?
Todd Angle: Does she charge for membership? No.
Judge: Does she advertise on it? No.
Judge: What is the purpose of her doing it?
Todd Angle: To inform the public about weddings. She's an officiant for weddings.
Judge: Does she list her name and phone number so you can reach her to perform your wedding?
Todd Angle: Let me check.
Judge: Is that you? You're right on there. How do you not know what's on the blog?
Todd Angle: No, I know it's on there.
Judge: That does not militate toward fair use. What’s the next one?
Judge: The nature of the copyrighted work.
Judge: Is this book nonfiction or fiction?
Susan J. Gordon: Nonfiction, other than the few times I imagined what Adam and Eve's wedding day would be like.
Judge: The nature of work as nonfiction militates more towards less protection for you because it’s not your art. The stories belong to the couples, not you. That militates toward fair use.
Judge: The second part of that is: Is it published or unpublished?
Judge: This is a published work, which militates toward the defendant.
Judge: The amount of the work used.
Judge: You have 365 stories in here. There were seven stories used. That's a small percentage.
Judge: That militates toward finding this to be fair use.
Judge: The effect on the potential market or value of the work.
Judge: Does his use cut into your income?
Susan J. Gordon: This hinders it. I need to control all access to these stories.
Judge: I think if they had contacted you and said, ""We'll offer you a couple thousand, and we want to give you some advertising,"" why would you ever say no to that? It could only help you.
Judge: But they did it behind your back. I understand the frustration.
Judge: Since the law is ""you use it, you pay,"" I have to consider how and why you used it.
Judge: I find this to be fair use.
Judge: That’s my verdict.


Judge: How has this cut into your profit margin?
Todd Angle: We want to control the publicity, but we didn't mean to hurt Mrs. Gordon. We're sorry she feels this way.
Judge: The fair use doctrine is complicated, and if you end up using someone else’s stuff, make sure to check with a lawyer first. It's a technical area of the law.
Judge: That will do it for this case. Next case coming up.


Susan J. Gordon: I had hoped this would send a message to people who lift authors’ work and post them online without permission.
Susan J. Gordon: There were two issues here, but do you think you got your point across?
Susan J. Gordon: No, I don’t, because fair use is when you take a sentence or two, not between two and 3,000 words, which is what was extracted from my book.
Susan J. Gordon: I'm very disappointed.
Judge: You got a lot of exposure by bringing it into this courtroom.
Todd Angle: I've learned that copyright is very important. You have to respect these laws and educate yourself when posting things on the internet.
Judge: You were very close to losing this case. We feel bad for Mrs. Gordon, but it was fair use. Copyright is complicated. You better check with a lawyer if you're using other people's stuff for a blog or website."

Defendant: “You’re just trying to manipulate me for money, aren’t you? This whole thing with the kid, it’s just a way for you to trap me. I bet you’ve been planning this from the start, trying to get me to pay for a child that might not even be mine.”

Plaintiff: “I’m not trying to trap you. I don’t want your money. I just want you to be there for your son. I don’t want him growing up without a father like I did.”

Defendant: “Oh please, you’re just using that as an excuse. You’re probably just trying to get some child support out of me. I’m not even sure I’m the father, and you won’t even let me get a DNA test. I’m not falling for your tricks.”

Plaintiff: “I’ve been trying to get you to help out with the child, to be responsible. I’m not asking for anything but what’s right. This isn’t about money, it’s about our kid having a father.”

Defendant: “Yeah, sure. You say that now, but I know what you’re really after. You probably just sent me the pregnancy test results to force me into something I’m not ready for. You’re manipulating me into this whole thing. It’s all just a way for you to control me.”

Judge: Valencia Ray, you are suing Cyber Electronics Incorporated, represented here by its owner, Joseph Rivas, for $435, a refund on an LG 4K television, 43-inch. What a great price. Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff: I had went to the store to buy a TV. I usually get my electronics fixed there. I asked them if I could purchase a TV because I was going to a doctor’s appointment and I could come back and pick it up. He said no problem. I came back to pick up the TV. Meanwhile, the guy from the store took the TV out the store, brought it up the hill, and put it in the cab.

Judge: Okay. That was nice. Did you see him drop it?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: All I saw was that he said he put it in the cab already, in the trunk.

Judge: So you didn’t watch him bring the TV?

Plaintiff: No, I just saw him.

Judge: Did you say, “Wait a second, I need to inspect the TV?”

Plaintiff: No, I did not. I did not say that.

Judge: So then what happens? You go—

Plaintiff: Then I get home. My building has security. The cab driver took it out, and I asked security if he could place it in front of the building. My neighbor was coming down. He said, “I’ll help you with the TV.” They took the TV. We put it in the elevator. They took it upstairs.

Judge: Were you in the elevator with them?

Plaintiff: Yes. We get into my apartment. My girlfriend is there because she comes over. I said, “Let’s take the TV and put it together.” When we took it out of the box, I noticed a crack. She said, “No, that’s probably the plastic.” Then when I took off the Styrofoam, I saw it was a big break. Not even an hour later, I called them back and I explained it to them. There’s no damage to the box. There’s no damage to the Styrofoam. But the TV’s broken.

Judge: Let me hear from you. What’s your protocol over there?

Defendant: On May 16, 2017, we received TVs from the manufacturer. One employee visually inspected all of them, the outside boxes, and then proceeded to test all the TVs for damages.

Judge: When the TVs are shipped to you?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: What employee did that? Is Abdullah here?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: All right. So do you actually remember these particular TVs, or is this what you do whenever a shipment comes in?

Employee: That’s what I do anytime we receive a TV in the store.

Judge: Do you record your findings in any way? Like, is there somewhere where you’re supposed to write stuff down, or do you only— Hold on, am I talking to you?

Defendant: Sorry.

Judge: Is there somewhere where you’re supposed to write stuff down, or do you just say something if it’s broken?

Employee: We have a paper that we sign.

Judge: Go ahead. Now you can show them the paper.

Defendant: Show it to your employee, please.

Judge: Is that paper— Is that your writing on the paper?

Employee: Yes.

Judge: And is that your signature?

Employee: Yes.

Judge: Was that paper authored on the same day that you inspected it?

Employee: Yes.

Judge: Which was the day that it came in from the manufacturer?

Employee: Yes.

Judge: And then what do you guys do with it?

Employee: We check all of them. Once we don’t see any broken TVs, we place them to sell.

Judge: Do you put them back in the box, or do you put them on a shelf?

Employee: We put them back in the box and sell them.

Judge: So when somebody buys a TV, what do you guys do? If they don’t ask to inspect it—tough for them, I guess?

Employee: We check the TV twice as a normal procedure. On this particular situation, the TV was only checked once.

Judge: I just— I’m not sure that it falls on you. I think it’s good that you do that, but I’m just not sure that it falls on them to inspect. Like, in other words, when I valet my car, I literally stand at the top right corner of the car when they come, and then I walk around. I don’t want to be obvious about the fact that I’m inspecting the car, but I know that if I drive off, the valet is going to say, “How do we know what you did with it?”

Judge: Can the TV be damaged without the box being damaged?

Defendant: Yes, because if someone dropped the TV, the box would still be fine.

Judge: Well, here’s a TV that’s heavy and lots of people touched it. Maybe you bought it broken, maybe you didn’t. But the problem is, I don’t deal in maybes. You have to be able to prove that they broke it and not that you took off and then your security guy and your friend or you trying to bring it up broke it. How are you going to do that?

Plaintiff: I have a letter from the LG technician who came to the house. He looked at it and inspected the box and the Styrofoam and everything. He said this was a shipping and handling defect.

Judge: Oh, good, then they’ll replace it for you.

Plaintiff: No, they told him—

Judge: I can’t say they broke it. Verdict for the Defendant.

Judge:"Deborah Ryder, you are suing Ricky Christensen for $5,000. You say you're out more than that because her dog attacked your dog. Tell me what happened."

Plaintiff:"Correct. On November 12th, 2017, I was in my driveway with my two dogs when Ms. Christensen’s dog came into my driveway and attacked."

Judge:"How far away from each other do you live?"

Plaintiff:"Four doors down and across the street."

Judge:"Okay, and the dog just came into your driveway?"

Plaintiff:"Yes, loose, unleashed, no human with it."

Judge:"No collar, nothing?"

Plaintiff:"Correct. First, it attacked my female dog. Luckily, I got the dog off of her with little damage. Then it attacked my other dog, Milo. I couldn't get the dog off. Milo was screaming, and Ricky was standing there."

Judge:"Oh, Ricky was there?"

Plaintiff:"They ran down. They followed the dog out of the garage, but they just stood and watched. No one helped me."

Judge:"When you say they stood and watched, they weren't just standing around taking bets, right? They just weren’t effective at getting the dog off?"

Plaintiff:"Right. I finally got the dog off. At that point, she said she would take me to the vet. Milo had surgery."

Judge:"What kind of surgery?"

Plaintiff:"On his neck and his side."

Judge:"Do you have the vet reports and bills?"

Plaintiff:"Yes, ma’am."

Judge:"Now let’s talk about your conduct, Ricky. What happened?"

Defendant:"We were in the garage—my children and I—cleaning. Pepper was in the garage with us. My son Evan turned around and said, ‘Mom, Pepper just ran out like a bullet.’"

Judge:"But hold on. Pepper’s a pit bull, and the garage door was open?"

Defendant:"Yes."

Judge:"So why is it a big surprise that Pepper got out?"

Defendant:"She usually doesn’t leave our side."

Judge:"But this isn’t the first time she’s gotten out?"

Defendant:"No."

Judge:"How many times has she gotten out?"

Defendant:"Maybe four or five."

Judge:"Now let’s get to the attack. You ran after Pepper, right?"

Defendant:"Yes, my son ran first."

Judge:"And how old is your son?"

Defendant:"Sixteen."

Judge:"And he got Pepper off?"

Defendant:"Yes, pulled her back by the collar. By the time I got there, Milo was on the ground."

Judge:"I spoke to one of the vets. Did they ever say it was hopeless for Milo?"

Plaintiff:"No, they said he was getting better."

Judge:"So, where does this leave me? The dog was 16, but was doing fine until your dog attacked it. The vet was optimistic. The only reason Milo was in that hospital at all was because your dog attacked. I’m not going to make her eat these bills. Verdict for the plaintiff, $5,000."

Judge: All parties, please reach the end. Welcome back to The People's Court. Plaintiff: It's a nightclub, dance lounge.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: You have to pay $3 to check in your coat, so I checked in the coat.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: As the night goes on, I’m ready to go home.

Plaintiff: Yes, I did.

Judge: Parties, please raise your right hands. Welcome back to The People's Court. The plaintiff says she fronted the defendant money for a trip to Disney World while the defendant was dating her daughter. But they broke up, and now she wants her money back. The defendant says the trip was always considered a gift, and this is just revenge. It’s the case of "You’re Freaking Goofy."

Judge: Okay, Lynn Smith, you are suing your daughter's former boyfriend, Thomas Foy, for $491.60 that you say you are out and that he owes you for a trip that he ended up not taking with your daughter, but that you had fronted money for.

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: All right. How long did they date?

Plaintiff: Oh, for six years, I guess.

Judge: That's a long time. How old are you guys?

Defendant: I'm 25.

Judge: Oh, and you're so young. All right, so what happened?

Plaintiff: Well, Chrissy had asked Tom if he'd like to join us when we went to Disney World for our trip on March 10, 2012. We told him how much it would cost him.

Judge: What kind of trip was this? Tell me about it.

Plaintiff: It was a vacation trip. You know, the family went.

Judge: Who else was involved?

Plaintiff: Well, my daughter and her husband, my grandchildren, my son and his wife. There were a lot of us.

Judge: Okay, so your nuclear family and their significant others.

Plaintiff: Right.

Judge: So then what happened?

Plaintiff: He had said he didn’t have the money upfront because there were due dates to pay for the airline and the deposit.

Judge: Who did he say that to?

Plaintiff: Well, he told Chrissy.

Mechanic: Yeah.
Judge: And if you're a mechanic why were you driving it to him?
Mechanic: Because the problems I didn't know how to fix them like that.
Judge: Well okay. All right so you're both alley mechanics right? Okay, you're not working for a particular- okay. All right so then you're just out of the picture after that. Okay go ahead and have a seat.
Judge: All right so go on.
Defendant: They take it to me, I checked the van out and everything. I told her what was wrong with the van as far as I see-
Judge: What was wrong with it?
Defendant: The distributor. After- see I put the- in and I had the van running then I saw it wasn't idling properly and it was smoking. I said- and I call her and I tell her is the heads gone in the van. I said come and pick the van up, she never did come and get the van. One day her and some of the girl came in the car and I said why don't you take the van- she want me to drive with the Queens. I said no I'm not driving no van the Queens. Take the van because the inspection sticker were off and the van and that's the reason why I removed the plate because it was getting tickets.
Judge: What made you think that removing the plates-
Defendant: It was not getting ticket after I removed the plates.
Judge: No, it got tolded.
Defendant: Yeah, it got tolded.
Judge: Had that work out for- I got- I had the idea to remove the plat so it would stop getting tickets and then it ends up getting towed. How many months was it parked in- in front of your place?
Defendant: It parked there for almost 6 months.
Judge: Wait, is that true? Why didn't she pick it up?
Plaintiff: We tried to pick it up when he went with- when she went with that girl and that's when the keys were missing.
Judge: Where's the key right now?
Defendant: I don't know where the key is.
Judge: Why would you bring it to court?
Defendant: I didn't know how to bring it-
Plaintiff: Cuz he's lying-
Judge: That would make such perfect sense though if you brought the key then I'd know then I'd say you're lying to her right?
Defendant: I'm not- I'm not lying.
Judge: Well you're the guy who didn't bring the tickets so I would not like bobblehead and say exactly-
Plaintiff: No you're right, you're right I- but he did say that he lost the key. He's lying about that.
Judge: Who's the gentleman who's with you - moral support or a witness?
Witness: That's a witness.
Judge: Come on up. So if somebody leaves a van or whatnot on your property for 6 months and never picks it up have they abandoned it?
Witness: Yeah I think if you leave something in my house for 2 weeks I'm not going to take care of your trash.
Judge: What's a magic number? What is the magic number for how long somebody leaves something in your house before it becomes yours essentially?
Witness: Uh just a few weeks. You can't be free storage for everybody else.
Judge: Do you have to tell them I'm going to basically take this property now if you don't pick it up?
Witness: I think you do.
Judge: I think you've got to let them know you're going to get rid of it and you give them what a reasonable time - 30 days fair enough? Going inside the courtroom what are you a witness to?
Witness: Oh when Errol had the van he did call Tasha, tell her to come get the van a lot of times. Tasha would never come get the van. I told her also to get the van.
Judge: You did?

Plaintiff: That's a lie cuz we didn't know where Osman was at, didn't know he was incarcerated. He was on vacation in Panama - that's what we were told.

Judge: Listen, yes your honor, people go to prison and it's frustrating because you rely on other people to take care of your business. You're absolutely right and um all of a sudden now you come out it's a year later and you're demanding to know where the van is and what's going on and everything else but meanwhile you were out and according to your own testimony didn't do anything for four or five month-
Plaintiff: I trusted him-
Judge: No, who does that? It sounds- it smacks of you don't feel like dealing with it and then I have those two guys saying I told her to pick it up she's just lazy and she wanted me to drive it to Queens and I wasn't going to do that and- and- and I got to tell you your conduct sort of sounds like that because it's inexplicable what is the reason that it didn't get picked up and there's no good answer and when there's no good answer and that side has a great answer and it's cuz she's lazy she just never got around to picking it up and then there's nothing to pick up because after 6 months of sitting there it got towed.
Plaintiff: We tried to pick it up. He kept coming up with excuses. He would not answer the phone we tried to-
Judge: He denies that. It's your word against his. Show me the emails that you sent them or the text that you sent them saying I keep trying to pick it up and you don't- show me something.
Plaintiff: It's- it's okay I mean is it- is it over there with the tickets?
Judge: No you know what- you know you just have no proof. Okay in any event you got a counter claim- you got to be kidding for what?

dialogue:
Judge: Ms. Budker, you are suing Dennis Dugan, your former architect, for $800, a return of a deposit that you gave him for some drawings. Mr. Dugan, you’re counterclaiming for the remaining balance that you say is owed for those drawings, which is $1,612. Let me hear from you. You have a home in what town?

Plaintiff: We have a home in Forest Hills Gardens, which is—I brought as an exhibit to show you—a preserved community historic district.

Judge: This is Forest Hills Gardens in New York?

Plaintiff: Yes, in New York.

Judge: All right, so you had a house, and you had a balcony, and…?

Plaintiff: I have a picture of my home with the extension. I filed an application to put a roof over the balcony.

Judge: And when you filed your application to put a roof over the balcony, they told you to get an architect?

Plaintiff: I was initially allowed to file first. I would like to give you a short presentation about how Forest Hills Gardens Corporation works very strictly on architecture and construction procedures.

Judge: I understand, but that’s not in dispute. So, they told you that you need to get an architect and submit proper drawings?

Plaintiff: Not at first. Initially, I submitted a sketch done by Joseph.

Judge: And what did they say?

Plaintiff: Then, I decided that I needed an architect, and I was suggested to hire Mr. Dugan.

Judge: All right. Mr. Dugan, how long have you been an architect?

Defendant: I retired this year.

Judge: How long were you in practice before that?

Defendant: 48 years.

Judge: Oh, my goodness. Did you have a written retainer agreement with her?

Defendant: Yes, may I provide it?

Judge: Yes, please. [Examines document] According to the written retainer, you were charging $200 an hour?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: The agreement states that you would inform her in eight-hour increments of your time and bill her accordingly?

Defendant: Yes, meaning I would notify her before accruing additional hours to prevent costs from getting out of hand.

Judge: And you billed her on a monthly basis?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: So what did you do for them?

Defendant: We had an initial meeting where we signed the contract. They paid my retainer.

Judge: So they paid $800?

Defendant: That’s correct. Then they provided some documents for me to use as a base for my plans, which I would then submit to the architectural committee for approval. I’ve done 12 to 15 submissions for different clients in Forest Hills. Only one has ever been approved on the first try.

Judge: Did you explain that to your clients?

Defendant: Yes, of course.

Judge: The denial from the committee stated that they unanimously rejected the design because they felt it made the house look too heavy. They said it exaggerated the asymmetry of the house.

Defendant: That’s correct.

Judge: When did you send them the bill for the remaining amount? Before or after the rejection?

Defendant: Shortly after, I think.

Judge: Wouldn't it have been a better idea to send the bill before the rejection?

Defendant: Not really. Normally, I get paid as the work is done.

Judge: Did you know it wasn’t going to get approved?

Defendant: I suspected they would have objections, but that’s typical. I assumed we would work through their concerns.

Judge: Did you explain that to her?

Defendant: Yes, I did.

Judge: And what happened?

Defendant: We met again, and she started berating my prior work for another client, calling me incompetent and stupid. I told her we couldn’t continue working together if this was the tone.

Judge: So, you sent your bill after she called you incompetent?

Defendant: I don’t recall exactly.

Judge: Ms. Budker, why do you feel that he should return the $800, and you should not have to pay the remaining balance?

Plaintiff: After our first meeting, we signed a contract for the design phase. According to the guidelines, there was supposed to be a review and suggestions from the board before the formal meeting.

Judge: Where is that written?

Plaintiff: In the rules and regulations.

Judge: Show me exactly where it states that the board will meet with him before he submits the design.

Plaintiff: [Hands over documents] Preliminary review.

Judge: [Reads document] That just outlines submission requirements. When did all this happen?

Plaintiff: 2014.

Judge: So, four years ago?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Mr. Dugan, what is the normal procedure after a denial?

Defendant: They set up a subcommittee to discuss the drawings and figure out modifications needed for approval.

Judge: Did you ever get another architect?

Plaintiff: No, because he never did what we wanted. He submitted his own design without discussing it with us.

Judge: He can’t submit anything without your approval. This is what he drew. Someone altered it with a pen. Who did that?

Plaintiff: My husband.

Judge: Okay, so your husband marked changes, and then he followed them?

Plaintiff: No, he never showed us the final submission.

Judge: Mr. Dugan, is there any requirement for a preliminary discussion with the board before submission?

Defendant: No, that’s not how it works.

Judge: Ms. Budker, you seem to believe there was an informal review required. Where is that documented?

Plaintiff: He promised to do it.

Judge: Let me see the letter. [Reads] "At our meeting yesterday, Ann’s words describing my work and me personally made me realize that you have lost confidence in my ability. Therefore, now is the time to end our agreement and go our separate ways." This suggests he left because of how he was treated, not because he refused to continue the work.

Judge: My ruling is as follows: The plaintiff’s lawsuit for the return of the deposit is denied. Work was performed, and just because the outcome was not what the plaintiff wanted does not mean the defendant does not deserve to be paid. The plaintiff is ordered to pay an additional $800 to Mr. Dugan. Case closed.

Judge: Thank you, Douglas. George Stewart, you’re suing your former landlord, Gabriella Baragan, for $1,400 that you say she owes you and is wrongfully withholding. Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff: Um, what happened? I've rented the apartment from her from 2012, and from the time I rented the apartment for all these years, I never had any heat. The only time the heat comes up is like 3 days before the end of the month, and after I pay her my rent, two days after, the heat goes again. I kept on complaining time after time, time after time. My wife had to move out because of no heat. My daughter started to get sick. My son started to get sick because of no heat. The place was cold.

Judge: Had you lived there for 4 years like that? Why didn’t you just call 311?

Plaintiff: The reason why is because I'm new in the country. I don't understand a lot of things. We are poor. We don't know what to do. Nobody told us what to do, so I guess now… okay.

Judge: How much was your rent?

Plaintiff: $1,400.

Judge: Okay, and you’d given her $1,400 security?

Plaintiff: I gave her—I have the receipt here for the first $1,000 security.

Judge: Yes. Okay, so go on.

Plaintiff: I have some pictures here. May I?

Judge: Yes, of course.

Plaintiff: This is a picture of the bathtub. It was clogged up for a month, and I couldn't show her no shower for a month. I had to shower at other people’s places.

Judge: But what are you taking a picture of here? It's not clogged in this picture. What are you doing?

Plaintiff: It’s draining. It slowly drained away.

Judge: Okay, that’s hard to see in a picture. What is this a picture of?

Plaintiff: The window of my daughter. There was mold on the window because of the heat. You can see the windows. It’s sweat. It’s all because of no heat, and the place is cold. You can see all the mold. That’s the reason why my son got sick. I have the receipt here for his sickness. I have a receipt here for thousands of dollars.

Judge: Why is the window wet like that?

Plaintiff: Because of no heat, and the place is cold. You can see all the mold.

Defendant: Did you see this when this happened?

Plaintiff: He told me like a month after. The daughter always stayed in her room. It was always closed. He never told me about it, and I sent somebody right away to fix it, but there was heat. There was a six-family building, and there was heat there. Everybody complained of being too hot, and he was the only one who complained that it was cold. I don’t understand.

Judge: Okay, does everyone have a separate meter?

Defendant: No, there’s only one thermometer, which is in the hallway, and there’s no way to control one place. The whole building was heated.

Judge: So, what was causing this mold?

Defendant: I sent somebody to fix it, but I don’t know why it was there. They put some kind of chemicals on it. They probably repainted it, but why was there mold to begin with?

Defendant: I don’t know. It was too humid, maybe? Because they never opened the window. It was always closed. The door was closed, and they never opened the window.

Judge: That shouldn’t happen just because your door is closed. There has to be some leak or something wrong. I don’t know. Anyway, so you fixed it. Did you ever hear from him again?

Defendant: No, just the one time.

Judge: And did you have to fix it multiple times in four years?

Defendant: Just the one time.

Judge: And when did you get a call about that? Year 1, Year 2, Year 3, or Year 4?

Defendant: No, it was about the last year when they were leaving.

Judge: Do you have any evidence of ever having complained about the heat before you're trying to get your security deposit back?

Plaintiff: Um, I do. Do you have an email to her, a text to her, anything showing that you’ve been complaining about the heat throughout four years?

Plaintiff: I have a lot of texts, but on the phone…

Judge: Do they say what I’m asking?

Plaintiff: I can’t remember. I know I take a look at them. I kept on texting her.

Judge: She says that’s not true. So I want to see evidence that you’re telling the truth. While you’re looking for that, let me ask you: Why is it you won’t return his security deposit?

Defendant: First of all, it wasn’t the reason why I didn’t return the deposit. It was because he said that he was going to move out, and I said okay, but you have to let me show the apartment to the new people that are going to rent it. So he said okay. The first time when I went there to show the apartment, it was so dirty, I couldn’t even go in. I said no, I can’t.

Defendant: It smelled like feet and greasy feet, cheesy feet, greasy—I don’t know. It was greasy.

Defendant: I told him, "You gotta keep it a little nicer and clean so we can show it." He said, “I don’t feel comfortable with you going in with other people in my place, and I can’t let you show it anymore. But don’t worry, I’ll keep it clean and give it back to you when I leave.” I said okay, because I couldn’t show it like this.

Defendant: By the end of the month when you had the lease with him?

Defendant: It was already over. He was leaving, but he had to let you show it.

Judge: Yes. That’s not like you just have to. His rights as a tenant are to have you plan it, and not surprise him. Your right as a landlord is to show it. You don’t have to eat a month's rent when a tenant leaves.

Judge: So, he moves out. What condition, according to you, did he leave it in?

Defendant: You can see the pictures. Let me show you.

Judge: Were you able to find any text or emails to her that say, "We have no heat. You need to fix this," anything like that?

Plaintiff: No, no texts.

Judge: Okay, because what I would be the first thing I would say if I lived in New Rochelle and didn’t have heat.

Defendant: The kitchen—supposed to be white. But it’s just dirty.

Judge: What’s that? Where the door, but what? Was it burned or just dirty?

Defendant: It was just dirty. Greasy.

Judge: It’s cleaned off?

Defendant: Yes, it came off with Clorox.

Judge: What’s that?

Defendant: The doors.

Judge: Yes, but what happened to the walls?

Defendant: That's how the walls were.

Judge: Okay, but this isn’t $1,400. Why are you keeping $1,400?

Defendant: Because I repainted.

Defendant: No, I told him I was going to give him the rest after the lady cleaned it.

Judge: How do you justify keeping $1,000?

Defendant: I replaced the rug in the room.

Judge: How new was the carpet?

Defendant: I installed it when he moved in.

Judge: Do you have a picture of the dirty carpet?

Defendant: Yes, that one with my sneakers over there.

Judge: Were you able to have it professionally cleaned?

Defendant: No, I replaced it.

Judge: But you don't get to refurbish the place whenever a tenant leaves. You have to be able to show what it cost you to clean the place. It’s disgusting.

Defendant: I did everything myself. The lady, I paid cash for her.

Judge: How much did you pay?

Defendant: About $300.

Judge: Did you do everything yourself?

Defendant: Yes, I paid her cash.

Judge: How long did she spend there to make $300?

Defendant: About three days.

Judge: Did you rerent the place?

Defendant: Yes. I lost the month's rent because I had to do all this cleaning.

Judge: But why did you lose a whole month?

Defendant: Because if it took three days to clean, then it took three days to clean.

Judge: But who’s going to start in the middle of the month?

Defendant: I mean, people rent on the 15th, but I couldn’t rent it.

Judge: Okay. I’m going to let you keep $700, half of the security deposit, but I’m going to order you to return the other $700 to him. The place was filthy, and it needed to be cleaned up. It took a certain amount of time, but if you weren't able to rent it, part of the reason why is because you decided not to touch it until he got out.

Judge: So I’m not going to entertain your claim for the security deposit for that other month, but I am going to allow you to keep $700, because it really was disgusting. Now, you had offered to return $400 to him, right? And he didn’t want to take it. I’m going to order you return $700. That’s my verdict. Good luck.

Judge:
Mr. Petrella, how long did you date Miss Judson?

Plaintiff (Pasqual Petrella):
About two and a half years.

Judge:
And how long did you live together?

Plaintiff (Pasqual Petrella):
About two years.

Judge:
You have filed this lawsuit for $3,370 for various bills that you paid for her, and a loan of $1,800. What was that loan for?

Plaintiff (Pasqual Petrella):
Well, over the course of the time that we were together, there were different loans for different things.

Judge:
How did you keep track of what was paid back and what wasn’t? How did you track the amounts during two years?

Plaintiff (Pasqual Petrella):
I would write down if she owed me for March's rent, I’d write down $500 for that month. If she owed me for car insurance, I would track that too.

Judge:
So how is this $1,800 made up of?

Plaintiff (Pasqual Petrella):
At the end of the relationship, there was a balance of $2,295, but I reduced it to $2,000, and she signed a promissory note.

Judge:
Can I see the promissory note?

Plaintiff (Pasqual Petrella):
Here it is. She also made a $500 payment towards the $2,000 balance.

Defendant (Cory Judson):
I believe this was when he was holding my car hostage. He said I owed him money, and I couldn’t get my car. He could have written anything on that envelope.

Judge:
Why didn’t you stop borrowing money then? You wouldn’t have had this issue.

Defendant (Cory Judson):
We were in a relationship, and money was going back and forth.

Judge:
What do you mean by back and forth?

Defendant (Cory Judson):
I paid for a lot of things. We lived together, so he paid the bills, and I gave him cash.

Judge:
Did you ever pay for his car or anything like that?

Defendant (Cory Judson):
He never paid for my car. I was under his insurance, but I paid for the vehicle myself.

Judge:
Do you owe him any money now?

Defendant (Cory Judson):
I do not believe I owe him anything.

Judge:
Are you sure about that?

Defendant (Cory Judson):
Yes, I’m sure. I paid him everything I owed.

Judge:
Did you sign the promissory note?

Defendant (Cory Judson):
Yes, but I was just trying to get him to leave me alone.

Judge:
What else happened during your breakup?

Plaintiff (Pasqual Petrella):
She was a heavy drinker. She would come home intoxicated and even drove her car into my house. I suspected she was getting texts from someone else, but she wouldn’t let me see her phone. It escalated into an argument, and eventually, the police came, and they told her to leave my house.

Defendant (Cory Judson):
What he says and what actually happened are two different things. Yes, I chased after him when he grabbed my phone, but I didn’t do anything violent.

Judge:
Did you try to serve him with a restraining order?

Defendant (Cory Judson):
Yes, I tried three times, but I couldn’t serve him.

Judge:
Tell me about the harassment.

Defendant (Cory Judson):
He started harassing me after we broke up. I have emails, text messages, and a video of him driving around my sister's house and my job. He even called my employer and tried to get me fired, saying I was an alcoholic and a drug addict.

Judge:
Do you have proof of that?

Defendant (Cory Judson):
Yes, I have emails and a video. He would also send me messages about how this could have been our car or how I could have had his new car.

Judge:
When did you get the DUI?

Defendant (Cory Judson):
I got it on May 17th.

Judge:
Was that after you broke up?

Defendant (Cory Judson):
Yes, it was after we broke up.

Judge:
What happened with the car?

Defendant (Cory Judson):
It was towed to his house, and I was in the hospital having surgery when it happened. He put a picture of my car on Facebook and made humiliating comments.

Plaintiff (Pasqual Petrella):
I was just trying to get the money she owed me.

Defendant (Cory Judson):
No, you were just trying to get me back. That’s all it was.

Plaintiff (Pasqual Petrella):
I moved on quickly after the breakup. I didn’t want anything to do with her anymore.

Defendant (Cory Judson):
Well, you certainly didn’t act like it.

Judge:
Do you think you have been harassing her?

Plaintiff (Pasqual Petrella):
I don’t believe so.

Judge:
You texted her new husband, right?

Plaintiff (Pasqual Petrella):
Yes, but I didn’t beat him up. He came to my house, and I told him to leave.

Defendant (Cory Judson):
He was stalking me. He drove by my job and called my supervisor.

Plaintiff (Pasqual Petrella):
I was just trying to get him to leave me alone.

Judge:
Did you ever send her a text saying, "Come over, here’s my address"?

Plaintiff (Pasqual Petrella):
Yes, I did.

Judge:
Why did you do that?

Plaintiff (Pasqual Petrella):
I was trying to resolve things.

Defendant (Cory Judson):
You need to stop stalking me. You’re still doing it.

Judge:
I find that you owe him $2,000 for the debts, and you owe her $2,000 for harassment. This is my verdict: each of you leaves with nothing.

Plaintiff (Pasqual Petrella):
I lost. You win some, lose some.

Judge:
I think you're lying about not owing him money.

Defendant (Cory Judson):
I’m sure I don’t owe him anything.

Judge:
As for the harassment, it's clear he has not stopped contacting you. You have video evidence, emails, and a history of him trying to interfere with your life.

Defendant (Cory Judson):
Yes, I have plenty of evidence.

Judge:
I hope both of you move on now, and I encourage you to take the restraining order seriously.

Defendant (Cory Judson):
Thank you, your honor.

Judge:
That will be all. Court is adjourned.

Judge: Jonathan Fuentes and Joselyn Fuentes, you are suing your former landlord, Horizon Investors Corp., represented here by—you are—are you an owner also?

Defendant: Yes, yes.

Judge: Okay, good. What should it be, Audio or Oreo?

Defendant: Oreo.

Judge: How is it—why is it not a—alright. Oreo Cardona, Executive Vice President and your landlord. You’re suing him for $5,000 for moving expenses, a security deposit that wasn’t returned, loss of wages—but basically, you’re really mad about the security deposit not being returned. Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff: Basically, it was a long winter, so there was a lot of snow and a lot of stuff accumulated.

Judge: So you folks move into—is it an apartment or a house?

Plaintiff: It’s an apartment.

Judge: Okay. And the apartment is owned by him, and you had a very bad winter. Why?

Plaintiff: Well, there were pools of water on the roof, and we had very bad leaks.

Judge: Did you complain to your landlord about the leaks? And were the leaks fixed?

Plaintiff: No, they said they couldn’t address it because it was dangerous conditions on the roof. It was ice and whatever.

Judge: So when the ice melted, did they address it?

Plaintiff: They addressed it that spring, but by that time, mold had accumulated.

Judge: In the spring?

Plaintiff: Yes, and we emailed them, we called them, we let them know like, “Hey, you know, this is—we have two children here.”

Judge: So were you seeing mold on the ceiling? Again, do you have pictures of it?

Plaintiff: Yeah, actually, we have the video of it.

Judge: You have a video of it?

Plaintiff: Yeah.

Judge: Hold on. I have one here. I have this—I’ll just show this.

Defendant: He has a video that’s just on the spot. It could be a picture, but nothing happening.

Judge: Oh, it’s the leak. Oh, I can—I’m sorry, you are right. I can actually see the dripping water. It took a minute. You’ll see the pot—oh, that’s horrible. Yeah. Is that a red Solo cup, or—

Plaintiff: No, that’s a—that’s a pot that you boil your pasta in. And that first waterline is the initial time where I dumped it.

Judge: Inside the apartment?

Plaintiff: Yeah.

Judge: Alright. So at some point, you get frustrated and you call the city?

Plaintiff: Yeah, she reported it.

Judge: And when you call the city, you report it, and the city comes out. And what happens?

Plaintiff: So they came back to the apartment to make sure that all the damages were fixed.

Judge: Well, had the repair been made?

Plaintiff: It was made, but now we have a new problem.

Judge: And the new problem is?

Plaintiff: That—did you make four apartments out of two?

Defendant: We made one apartment out of two on each floor.

Judge: When you bought the building, did you turn them into two on each floor for more money?

Defendant: They were two—they were already there.

Judge: So it already had a zoning violation.

Defendant: It wasn’t a zoning violation.

Judge: It had to be. Because the problem the city had that made you make them one is that there was only one egress on each floor.

Defendant: I—I can explain that.

Judge: Yeah?

Defendant: That whole city block was torn down by the city of New York. So the only building left was that little building in the middle of that vast wasteland.

Judge: How does the other buildings’ existence mean that there’s a method of egress for both apartments?

Defendant: You climb up, you go to the roof, and you go to the next building if there’s a fire or a problem.

Judge: Wait, wait, wait, wait. That is rich. You expect people, during a fire, to climb up—to where? Go where?

Defendant: In the city of New York—

Judge: Jump from building to building like they’re Superman?

Defendant: In the city of New York, if you live next—

Judge: Just stop.

Alright, the bottom line is that the city said what you got going on is illegal, and they have to leave because you are not legally renting it out the way it is.

Does anybody have the document given to you by the city?

Plaintiff: I do.

Judge: Okay. Let’s see what both parties show me now.

Plaintiff: That was the vacate order that was on our door.

Judge: Illegal apartment. Yeah, just—alright. Illegal apartment, two legal Class A apartments subdivided. Yeah, it’s not this fancy footwork about all the other buildings and jumping from building to building. It’s the bottom line—it’s the same thing that always happens, which is somebody wants to make more money, they put up a wall, but they can’t do that without the city approving it because the city’s going to require that there’s a method of egress. dialogue:
Judge: Ebony, yes, you are suing A Sip of Class, represented by Rex Murray. You’re the owner?

Defendant: Yes, ma’am.

Judge: All right. You are suing for $3,000 that you want returned to you because, according to you, he did not do his job when you employed him as a bartender for a big party. Let me hear from you first. What kind of party was this?

Plaintiff: It was our 13th wedding anniversary for my husband and me.

Judge: Okay. Is your husband in the room?

Plaintiff: Yes, he is.

Judge: All right. Come on, front and center. Why are you leaving her alone here?

Plaintiff’s Husband: Oh no, I’m not.

Judge: Tall drink of water. You okay? All right. So, what happens? You guys are having this big party. How many people?

Plaintiff: We had invited 175 people.

Judge: Okay, and how many showed up?

Plaintiff: 142.

Judge: Okay, and were you serving dinner and drinks?

Plaintiff: Yes, we hired a food truck to cater and then A Sip of Class to provide bartending services.

Judge: And the party was to last from when to when?

Plaintiff: The party was to last from 8:00 p.m. to 12:00 a.m.

Judge: Do you have a contract with them?

Plaintiff: Yes, I have the contract.

Judge: Okay, may I see that?

Plaintiff: Sorry, Rex—I contracted Rex from 8:30 to 11:30.

Judge: Okay, so that’s an issue in the case. 8:30 to what time?

Plaintiff: 11:30.

Judge: 11:30, all right. So tell me what happens the night of the party. By the way, how much were you paying him?

Plaintiff: $5,000.

Judge: And according to this contract, you paid him $5,000, and he does what?

Plaintiff: He was supposed to come with four bartenders and himself and provide all of the alcohol listed on our signed contract for 175 guests.

Judge: Okay. The alcohol—it’s listed in the contract?

Plaintiff: Yes. It was supposed to be: S.B. gin, Hennessy, Bacardi rum, 1800 Tequila, Bulleit bourbon, Stella Artois, cups, napkins, fruit, water, juice, soda, ice…

Judge: Cabernet, red wine, white wine, Chardonnay. You didn’t specify any brands for the wines?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: You’re not a wine drinker, are you?

Plaintiff: Not really.

Judge: I know you’re not, or you would have. All right. Okay. So then what happens?

Plaintiff: He shows up, and the first time that I realized something was wrong, my husband had gone to the bar prior to the party starting and asked for a glass of Bulleit, which is what he drinks—another reason why I was very specific in the contract—and was told that Bulleit was not available.

Plaintiff’s Husband: My husband came downstairs to my dressing room to let me know that there was no Bulleit.

Plaintiff: I subsequently came out, and my husband and I spoke with Rex, who explained that the liquor service company he purchases from did not send Bulleit to him, but he offered to go to a local liquor store around where we were to buy a bottle of Bulleit. My assumption was that he was going to buy an appropriate amount for my guests. When he came back, I was told that he purchased one bottle, and my husband got one drink from that Bulleit.

Plaintiff’s Husband: When I went back to the bar after that, I was told there was no Bulleit.

Plaintiff: Subsequently, I talked to guests who were not able to get the alcohol they asked for every time they approached the bar. Alcohol ran out before the party was even halfway done.

Judge: What alcohol ran out, and at what time?

Plaintiff: I approached the bar at 9:00 p.m. to ask for a glass of Ciroc, which is what I drink, and there was no Ciroc.

Defendant: I was the bartender that night. I was there watching my staff.

Judge: How many bartenders were there?

Defendant: I brought four bartenders.

Judge: Okay, so really? Was it 9:00? Are you sure?

Plaintiff: Yes, it was 9:00, because I ended up not drinking at all that night since he didn’t have Ciroc.

Judge: Oh, that’s just criminal on your part. All right, so go on. What else happens?

Plaintiff: I have a statement from one of the guests.

Judge: Can I see it? Is the guest here?

Plaintiff: No, but my brother’s mother is here.

Judge: Your brother’s mother?

Plaintiff’s Witness: I’m Corliss. I have to agree with her. There wasn’t any Ciroc when I went to the bar.

Judge: What time do you remember it being?

Plaintiff’s Witness: Probably around 9:00.

Judge: All right. Let’s talk to you, Rex. What happened that night?

Defendant: First of all, I’ve been in business for three years. This is my first complaint. Basically, we purchased the liquor, and we guaranteed that alcohol would last the entire night—not one particular brand, but overall alcohol.

Judge: But you shouldn’t be running out of all of them. Did you not have the man’s drink?

Defendant: Yes, ma’am, I did.

Judge: Then what happened?

Defendant: When Mr. went upstairs to check, we were barely unloading. When I came back from grabbing ice, he said it wasn’t up there. So I immediately went to get it.

Judge: How many bottles did you buy?

Defendant: I bought two bottles of Bulleit bourbon.

Judge: And that ran out?

Defendant: Yes, ma’am.

Judge: So two wasn’t enough.

Defendant: The man drank one and a half bottles by himself.

Judge: That’s hard to believe. Did you, sir?

Plaintiff’s Husband: Absolutely not. I got maybe three or four drinks out of that bottle.

Judge: All right. So what about cups? Did you run out of cups?

Defendant: We ran out of cups around 11:15, 11:20.

Judge: That’s just minutes before the party ended.

Defendant: The venue was so hot that guests arrived at 8:00 and started drinking early.

Judge: Based on what I’ve heard, I’m ordering $1,666 to be returned to the plaintiff.

Defendant: I don’t feel I got to explain everything, but I’ll learn from this experience.

Plaintiff: I am very grateful.

Judge: That’s it. Court is adjourned.
manipulation_techniques: deflection, dismissal, minimization, exaggeration, emotional appeal

dialogue:
Plaintiff: “I really don’t want our son to grow up without a father like I did. It’s just not fair to him. I know what it’s like to feel abandoned, to have to go through life without knowing your dad. I don’t want that for him.”

Defendant: “I’m not ready to be a father. I’ve told you that before. I don’t think I’m cut out for this.”

Plaintiff: “But don’t you care about him at all? Don’t you care what he’ll feel growing up without you? I’ve been through it, and it’s the worst feeling in the world. Do you really want to make him go through the same thing?”

Defendant: “It’s not that simple. I don’t know if I’m ready to take on that responsibility. You can’t just expect me to jump in and be this perfect dad overnight.”

Plaintiff: “I understand it’s hard. But I’m not asking you to be perfect, I’m just asking you to be there for him. I don’t want him to grow up thinking his dad didn’t want him. Please, don’t make him feel the way I did.”

Defendant: “I never said I didn’t want him, I’m just not sure I can handle this.”

Plaintiff: “You say you care, but if you really do, then why aren’t you willing to be there for him? It’s not about you anymore, it’s about him. I had to struggle through life alone, and I don’t want that for him. Please don’t make him feel the same pain I did.”

Judge: All parties are right here. Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case on the docket: the plaintiff says the defendant stiffed him on embroidering the defendant's company name on some T-shirts, but the defendant says the guy wrote "Newark Heart Care" instead of "Car Care," so he's got to be kidding. It's the case of brokenhearted Leon against heavy debts.

Judge: Okay, Ernest Ricka, you are suing Leon Goretski of Newark Car Care Incorporated. You’re the owner, for $1,618.15 for 90-something t-shirts that he purchased from you and never paid for. Okay, what happened?

Plaintiff: Well, first of all, I've been doing work with Newark Car Care for about 20 years. I spoke to Leon, he said come in, and he needed stuff for the staff.

Judge: What is Newark Car Care?

Plaintiff: An auto repair shop.

Judge: How much staff do you have at any given time?

Plaintiff: Fourteen guys.

Judge: Okay, go ahead.

Plaintiff: So, he gave me an order for, I believe, 97 t-shirts for the mechanics in the back, and then he ordered polos for the guys at the counter and some Nike jackets for Leon and the higher-up people. That was delivered in March. I went in and picked up a check, and the check was returned.

Judge: How was it returned? For what?

Plaintiff: Insufficient funds. So then I told Leon, "I need the money," and he gave me another check for $1,639. That check came back. So then I called the bank that he used, and they literally told me, "This check will never be good."

Plaintiff: After going back to him, he gave me a third check. That check also came back as insufficient.

Plaintiff: We went back and forth for weeks. I called him, and he kept saying, "I know I owe you the money, everything was fine, and I’m going to pay you." He said I’d been fair. But it dragged on, so I finally filed with the court.

Defendant: The first part of the story is correct. Everything was fine, about $2,600 worth of merchandise. I was trying to work something out and get a discount on the last $1,600 because when the summer hit, we started putting on the t-shirts and realized the sizing was wrong.

Judge: What do you mean the sizing was wrong?

Defendant: The triple XLs were too tight.

Judge: You’re saying the shirts were too small?

Defendant: Yes, especially for my bigger guys.

Judge: But you didn’t bring any shirts here as proof?

Defendant: No, I left them at the shop.

Judge: How can you be this relaxed about your defense? You didn’t bring a single piece of evidence.

[Laughter]

Judge: Does this guy lose?

Judge: Yes, because he doesn't have proof that there was anything wrong with the shirts.

Judge: Fair point. I’m giving you the last word. Your answer to the complaint says the shirts were mis-sized and the name was misspelled. How many shirts had a misspelling?

Defendant: Four or five.

Judge: Did you bring them?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Why not?

Defendant: I left them at the shop.

Judge: So you’re telling me you didn’t bring the shirts to prove there was a mistake?

Defendant: No.

Judge: You stop payment on the check?

Defendant: That’s not true.

Judge: No? You didn’t stop payment on the check? It bounced because you didn’t have money in your account. So why did you say you stopped payment on the check?

Defendant: I told the plaintiff about the mistakes.

Judge: Did he ever tell you anything about mistakes?

Plaintiff: No. Every time I saw him, he was fine with the order.

Judge: You haven’t paid for the Nike jackets either. Weren’t you wearing the jacket when he came in?

Plaintiff: Yes, and so was everyone else.

Judge: And you told him, "I’ll give you a credit card in a week," then in a day, and you just kept pushing him off?

Defendant: I was working on paying him.

Judge: No, you weren’t. Paying him would mean handing him $200, $300 a week. What you did—stringing him along with three bounced checks—is not working on paying him. There’s no shame in financial struggles, but there is shame in treating him like garbage. That’s what you did.

Judge: You didn’t even bring the shirts you were complaining about. If you had, we could examine them right now. Instead, you’re making vague claims and hoping I believe them.

Judge: Pay the man. Verdict for the plaintiff: $1,618.15.

Judge: This is the plaintiff, Cecile. She says she's been friends with the defendant for over 40 years, and she can't believe it's come down to this—a lawsuit. Turns out her onetime friend stole 22 pieces of valuable jewelry from her and refuses to return them. Well, friend or no friend, she wants the value of her stolen jewelry, which is $3,515.26, and she's suing for it.

Judge: Now, this is the defendant, Moren Bennon. She says she and the plaintiff started an online jewelry-selling business, and the plaintiff still owes her money. She's keeping the 22 pieces of jewelry until the plaintiff's debt is paid off—simple as that. The plaintiff has thus far refused to pay her what she's owed, and she's not giving her anything back until she does. She's accused of breaking up a long-time friendship.

Judge: The defendant has brought a countersuit for $3,387—the amount she's owed.

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hand.

Bailiff: Please raise your right hand.

Bailiff: You solemnly swear to tell the truth, the whole truth, and nothing but the truth, so help you God?

Plaintiff: I do.

Defendant: I do.

Bailiff: Thank you. You may be seated.

Judge: Okay, Cecile, doing business as Vintage Button Bling, you are suing Moren Bennon, your former partner, for $3,515.26. You have a counterclaim against her for $3,387.50. The two of you have known each other for 40 years, and here we are. Talk to me. Tell me what happened.

Plaintiff: Well, first of all, we are not partners. I started the jewelry business 10 years ago. I was having lunch with the defendant and told her that I wanted to start selling online instead of continuing to travel. She expressed interest in repping it, basically.

Judge: So repping it, but you were splitting the profits?

Plaintiff: The gross, not even the profits—50/50. That was my big mistake.

Judge: Okay, that's called a partner. Go on.

Plaintiff: That was my big mistake.

Judge: For how long?

Plaintiff: That went on for the last two years.

Judge: All right, now, the first year went well?

Plaintiff: The first year went well.

Judge: What happens the second year?

Plaintiff: The second year, we were not on the same internet site.

Judge: Why not?

Plaintiff: Well, it was a problem because we were selling designer buttons made into jewelry. And the designer sent us a cease and desist because you can't sell designer buttons, make them into jewelry, and profit from it.

Judge: Who was the designer who gave you the cease and desist?

Plaintiff: Chanel.

Judge: Oh. And how many times did Chanel ask you to cease and desist?

Plaintiff: Ten.

Judge: Well, you guys both got away with trade infringement and murder.

Plaintiff: (laughs nervously)

Judge: So now—so you both get away with murder until when?

Plaintiff: Until Etsy had had enough of us and then canceled us.

Judge: Etsy does not want to deal with anything unless Chanel gives you permission?

Plaintiff: Of course, because you're not allowed to do what you're doing.

Judge: So you got fired from Etsy. Where did you go after that?

Plaintiff: Shopify.

Judge: And now Shopify—you figured you'd be on the lam with Shopify for a while because it would take Chanel a bit to catch up?

Plaintiff: Not really.

Judge: Who’s the lady who’s with you?

Plaintiff: This is Devin. She assisted me in all aspects of my business.

Judge: All right, so you go to Shopify. How do the sales go at Shopify?

Plaintiff: Well, Shopify is such a totally different thing that you have to build the traffic.

Judge: What do you mean?

Devin: You need an online presence, essentially.

Judge: Yeah, I know. That's actually what you got paid for and got 50% of the profits for—knowing how to create an online presence. But how exactly did you guys create an online presence for your shop?

Plaintiff: They created social media accounts, and they paid for some Facebook ads, but basically, it just wasn’t profitable.

Judge: Exactly. So then who decided it wasn’t profitable, and you should part ways?

Plaintiff: I did.

Judge: What did you tell her?

Plaintiff: I just said I don’t see how I can keep spending the money that I’ve been putting out.

Judge: What money were you putting out?

Plaintiff: The money that I was spending was on her because we were—I’m not the computer expert. So because of the 50/50 partnership, I was willing to invest my time and the money to learn how to do it.

Judge: Okay, so hold on. So you were being paid a salary by her? By the hour, or how?

Defendant: Hourly, yes.

Judge: What was your hourly rate?

Defendant: $25.

Judge: What was the relationship between you two before this? Anything or none?

Plaintiff: We met in an elevator.

Judge: (laughs) Okay. Listen, what is it you tell her? “We’re going to part ways.” How? What do you say?

Plaintiff: It was all done on emails.

Judge: Okay, do you have the emails?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: May I see the emails? Hand them to my bailiff, please.

(Plaintiff hands over emails.)

Judge: So Moren sends you an email at 12:13 on November 27th: “10% of sales till I reach $2,000. I want to retrieve the approximately $2,000 I am underwater to break even.” What $2,000 were you underwater in?

Defendant: What I spent.

Judge: Why would that be appropriate for you to recoup the cost when she doesn’t get to recoup the cost? But anyway, you agree to this?

Plaintiff: I felt coerced.

Judge: How were you coerced? What was the size of the gun that she put to your head?

Plaintiff: There was no gun.

Judge: Right, but there was never a mention of returning it without the 10%.

Judge: So say no and call the police. She has your stolen goods. You knew how to do that later. You did do that later.

Judge: So you end up agreeing that you will give her 10% of future sales?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And then what happens?

Plaintiff: We agreed that I was going to pick up the inventory, and before I even got home, there was an email from them saying that they had forgotten to put in the most valuable of the collection.

Judge: (Sighs) Alright, let’s wrap this up.

Uh, even though he was there for a couple of hours or whatever, you own—after a while he called me, and I said to him, "Look, you came to court, but you didn’t do anything for me. You didn’t testify."

Judge:
But if he's sitting in court for you for a couple of hours, and through no fault of his own the court won’t accept his testimony, then why would you think that people shouldn’t get paid?

Defendant:
No, I asked him to do something on the money we agreed because—anyway, I don't know what that means.

Judge:
Meaning?

Defendant:
Meaning to cut from $1,500, to cut something. He agreed also.

Judge:
And then what was it cut to?

Defendant:
Nothing.

Judge:
So, he didn’t take a lower amount?

Defendant:
No.

Judge:
Well, here’s the problem. There’s something called the statute of limitations. For what you are saying occurred, it’s six years. We’re 10 years out. You can’t bring a lawsuit for that.

Judge:
Case dismissed in favor of the defendant.

Judge: Besides her putting you through turmoil, why do you believe you should not have to pay child support? Give me a legal reason not based on your feelings.

Defendant: Because she should. She's just making too much money now and I'm poor.

Judge: You're poor?

Defendant: I'm poor.

Judge: You were not poor within the last year that you came here. So what has occurred, Mr. Cassidy?

Defendant: Crop failure, okay? And you know, too much rain. We've had too much rain. A lot of crop failure. And she just don't need my money anymore. She's making good money and she's got old camel toes helping her out.

Judge: Okay, let's just be clear. It's not for her. The money is for your son. You have also not provided any documents suggesting a change in your income.
