dialogue:
Judge: This is the Defendant, Brian Failen. He says he needed a pool cover for his pool because he didn't want his kids falling in and drowning if he took his eye off them for a minute. He had discussions with the Plaintiff about a pool cover but never made a deal with him to get one. He has no idea why the Plaintiff went off and ordered him a custom cover because he never signed off on anything. Besides, he doesn't even need a custom cover because his pool is just a standard pool, and a store-bought cover would have fit.

Judge: He's accused of pooling around. All parties, please raise your right hand.

Judge: Welcome back to The People's Court. Next case on the docket: The Plaintiff ordered a custom pool cover for his friend, and the Defendant just up and canceled the deal and says he's not going to eat it. But the Defendant says he never pulled the trigger on the deal. It's the case of the chlorinated cover-up.

Judge: Thank you, Douglas.

Judge: Darren Cook, you are suing Brian Failen for $1,396.41 that you say he owes you for a pool cover that he ordered from you and now refuses to pay. What's going on?

Plaintiff: Back at the beginning of August of last year, 2011, he called me to see if I could call and give him a price on a pool cover.

Judge: How do you two know each other?

Plaintiff: His wife, I believe, works for a good friend of mine. So actually, in the beginning of 2011, I went over to his house and helped him get the pool clear because it was dirty.

Judge: Helped him get it clear because he called you to hire you to do that originally?

Plaintiff: Yeah, they called to see if I could give them some help. So I did that for nothing. I just went over to help him. It took about 15-20 minutes.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: Got the pool clear for him. Then in August, he called. He wanted a safety cover for his pool, which has the springs on it so kids can walk on it, in case anything happens. A safety cover. I measured the pool. I called him up. I went back to the house, measured it again. I gave him a quote on 3x3 spacing, which is narrower straps. But his pool, I told him he saves a couple hundred if he makes it 5x5 spacing.

Judge: What's 5x5 spacing?

Plaintiff: Between the straps on the safety cover. They put them every 3 feet or every 5 feet, depending on which cover you get. If he went 5x5, it would be cheaper. So he said okay, get me one. I gave him the price of the cover. He said, "Go ahead and order."

Judge: What was the price of the cover?

Plaintiff: The price was $1,748.

Judge: What was so custom about this pool? Did it have an odd shape?

Plaintiff: No, it’s just a rectangle with the steps coming off the shallow end.

Judge: So the custom pool cover is just a rectangle?

Plaintiff: Yeah, they're all custom because the steps aren't exactly most steps. Like, say, 8 feet. His was 3 feet by 4 feet, which is an off-size step.

Judge: But what does the cover have to do with the steps? Aren’t you covering the whole top?

Plaintiff: No, you can’t. It’s got to be cut into a rectangle with an extra square coming off for the stairs because that’s how his pool is shaped.

Judge: You ran that by him verbally? Nothing in writing?

Plaintiff: I went to his house twice and talked to him.

Judge: But you didn’t have him sign a proposal?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: So he tells you, "Sure, go ahead."

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And then where do you go to have this made?

Plaintiff: I go to a wholesaler, and they send it out to a company that makes them.

Judge: Okay. When was the first inkling you got that there was going to be a problem?

Plaintiff: September 15th. He called and spoke to my wife. He wanted to know when the cover was coming in.

Judge: Okay. Tell me about the phone call.

Plaintiff’s Wife: He asked when the cover would come in. It had not come in yet, so I told him that it should be in shortly, and as soon as it arrived, I would give him a call.

Plaintiff: Two days later, he calls back and says he doesn’t want it anymore.

Judge: What did he say?

Plaintiff: He left a message saying, "I don’t need that cover anymore. Somebody gave me one."

Judge: What’s going on, Mr. Failen?

Defendant: I met him in June through a friend. I called him a few times in July about a pool cover but didn't hear from him until the end of August. When I finally spoke to him, he said he could come over and measure the pool. I told him, "Okay."

Judge: And then?

Defendant: He calls me a week later, tells me about the price difference. I said, "Okay, I’ll take the one with the warranty."

Judge: So you agreed to it?

Defendant: Yes, but I kept looking around because I wasn’t sure if he’d follow through.

Judge: But you told him to go ahead?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Then you found a cheaper one?

Defendant: Yes, so I called him and left a message saying I didn’t need it anymore.

Judge: That’s not how custom orders work. You don’t get to just cancel them when you find a better deal. I find in favor of the Plaintiff for $1,396.41.

Judge: The pool cover belongs to him. Make arrangements with Officer McIntosh to transfer it over. You can't just bail out of a custom order because you found it cheaper. The time to find a cheaper option is before placing the order. Good luck.

Judge: This is the plaintiff, Kimo Lee. He says he's a bail bondsman, and when the defendant's brother was arrested, she signed a bond for him. When the defendant's brother skipped out on his court date, he had to pay the court $2,000. The defendant is financially responsible for the two grand. She refuses to pay him, and he's suing.

Judge: This is the defendant, Sandra. She says she told the plaintiff her brother moved back to Ohio and told him where he was hiding. The plaintiff is a bail bondsman; it's his job to go to Ohio to get her brother and bring him to the courthouse so he can get his money back. That's his job, not hers. That’s why she owes him nothing.

Judge: She’s accused of bailing on a bond.

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hands.

Narrator: Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case on the docket: The plaintiff is a bail bondsman. The defendant's brother was arrested, and the defendant signed a bond for him. Now, the defendant's brother skipped out on the court date, and now the bondsman is going after her. She says it's his job to wrangle her brother.

Narrator: It's the case of He's skipping, now you're tripping.

Judge: Kimo Lee, ma’am, on behalf of Kahuna Bail Bonds, you’re the owner?

Plaintiff: Yes, ma’am.

Judge: You are suing Sandra—you’ve asked us not to mention your last name—for $2,000 because a bond that she signed for was forfeited. What happened?

Plaintiff: Well, I got her brother out of jail.

Judge: What was your brother in jail for?

Defendant: Three misdemeanors… uh, domestic dispute.

Judge: Okay, and then what happens?

Plaintiff: So she signs for it—

Judge: She co-signed for him?

Plaintiff: Yes, ma’am.

Judge: She co-signs for him, and what does she sign?

Plaintiff: I promise to pay you.

Judge: Well, does she give you collateral?

Plaintiff: No, no collateral was taken. It’s paperwork that she has to fill out—her personal information, Social Security number, addresses, work details, stuff like that.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: On the back of each one of the papers, it states that if he doesn’t appear, she’s held responsible.

Judge: So your brother calls you from jail and says, “I’m in jail because I’ve been arrested on a bunch of domestic violence charges.” You say they’re all misdemeanors? Were they all misdemeanors?

Defendant: Yes, ma’am.

Judge: So how do you find him as a bondsman? Had you used him before?

Defendant: My brother provided me with his number, I guess.

Judge: You bonded the brother out before?

Plaintiff: No, ma’am.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: It could be, uh, jailhouse chatter.

Judge: And you call him?

Defendant: I call.

Judge: And what is it you sign?

Defendant: This is the document that I signed.

Judge: Okay. And what does the document say is going to happen when your brother fails to appear to court—which apparently happened? Where’s your brother?

Defendant: Still in Ohio at my—

Judge: Why did your brother not go to court?

Defendant: He lost his job, and he had an opportunity for another job with a friend in Ohio, so he returned back to Ohio.

Judge: Why didn’t he take care of his court case before doing that?

Defendant: I don’t know. I tried to get him to come back down there and take care of his court case—explained to him that they were just misdemeanors, and… and he just wouldn’t do it.

Judge: Does that sound like your brother to you?

Defendant: Kind of.

Judge: So why did you co-sign a bond for him?

Defendant: Um, because he was trying to change his life and—

Judge: Is he still with the woman who pressed the charges against him?

Defendant: Well, it was actually my spouse who pressed the charges on him. They got into an argument.

Judge: Your spouse?

Defendant: Yeah.

Judge: Oh. Maybe that’s why you’re calling a bondsman. So are you still with your spouse?

Defendant: At the time, we did separate for, um, like eight months. But then, yeah, we ended up getting back together.

Judge: That’s weird. And your spouse won’t drop the charges, or the DA won’t allow your spouse to drop the charges?

Defendant: They won’t allow him to drop the charges.

Judge: Right. Because you’d love for him to drop the charges so that he would then stop pursuing you.

Defendant: Right.

Judge: So what happens? He doesn’t show up for court, and, uh, court says, “Gimme, gimme.”

Plaintiff: Well, he actually was going for a couple of court dates, then he—

Judge: But you gotta go for all of them, right?

Defendant: Yes, ma’am.

Judge: Right.

Plaintiff: Then he didn’t show. So I got the bond forfeiture—which is the yellow piece of paper you have there—saying I have five months to have him either get another—

Judge: Five months? 150 days?

Plaintiff: Yes, ma’am.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: You have three options: either he files a motion to get another court date, which didn’t happen; turn himself in and get another court date, which didn’t happen; or I can get him and turn him back in, or he gets picked up by the cops, which didn’t happen either because he’s in Ohio.

Judge: Right.

Plaintiff: So after the five months, I had to pay the bond forfeiture.

Judge: So you paid it?

Plaintiff: Yes, ma’am.

Judge: May I see that you paid it?

Plaintiff: It’s that paper, the one you have.

Judge: Okay. So what do you think is going to happen here, and why do you think you shouldn’t have to pay him even though you promised you would if this happened? This is exactly—this is your one job in this contract you signed. Your job is to pay $2,000 if your brother doesn’t show up. That’s the only job you have. And you feel you shouldn’t have to pay it—why?

Defendant: Because I provided him with the whereabouts of my brother, and he never—he showed up at my house one night and stated that he had a warrant to search my house.

Judge: He said he had a warrant to search your house?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: I have no idea, but that sounds kind of fishy. In any event, it doesn’t matter, because the guy’s in Ohio, and you think that he should spend $3,000 or $4,000 going to Ohio instead of getting $2,000 from you and calling it a day.

Defendant: [Silent]

Judge: Verdict for the plaintiff.

Judge:
Okay, Electrical Control Systems, represented here by Mr. Prasad. You're the owner, yes?

Plaintiff (Cuk Prad):
Yes, I was the owner.

Judge:
The business is no longer in business?

Plaintiff:
No.

Judge:
You are suing Edward Catalinus, your former landlord of 20 years, for $3,000, a statutory maximum that you say you are out because he won't return your $1,500 security deposit, and you want interest on it, plus the value of all the things that you left behind. Is that correct?

Plaintiff:
Yes, that’s correct.

Judge:
Okay, what happened?

Plaintiff:
As stated before, I was a good tenant. I paid my rent on time every month for 20 years.

Judge:
20 years. Okay, what kind of business did you have?

Plaintiff:
A computer repair business mostly.

Judge:
Okay, the store was just accommodating, doing repairs for the locals.

Plaintiff:
Yes, that's correct. I was there for 20 years, paying almost $375,000 during that period of time for rent and property tax adjustments.

Judge:
Go on.

Plaintiff:
Then it was time to go.

Judge:
Why did you break down your business?

Plaintiff:
Well, no, I mean, the lease ended, and I didn’t need the space anymore.

Judge:
So you informed him in January that when the lease is over in May, it's over, and that you no longer need the space?

Plaintiff:
Correct. And everything was fine until it wasn’t.

Judge:
When was the first inkling you had that you were going to have a problem?

Plaintiff:
Well, one month passed, so I contacted him, and he said, “Well, you know, he didn’t forget me, and he would take care of it." Now three months passed, and I received an email saying that I have no security deposit for you because he had to spend an amount that was more than what the worth of the security deposit was.

Judge:
The security deposit was $1,500?

Plaintiff:
Yes.

Judge:
Okay, so once you got that response from him, what did you do?

Plaintiff:
I was angry, right, because I felt that I had left the place in good condition, and I shouldn’t have to fund him making it spiffier for the next guy.

Judge:
And therefore, you are suing for the $1,500 security deposit?

Plaintiff:
Correct, and I want compound interest on it for those years.

Judge:
Where did you get the idea that you could sue for interest on a business lease?

Plaintiff:
From my attorney.

Judge:
Really? That’s inaccurate. Time for a new attorney.

Defendant (Edward Catalinus):
All right, Mr. Catalinus, what’s going on?

Defendant:
He’s a good tenant, paid on time for 20 years. A 20-year relationship. We have this issue over $1,500.

Judge:
You have this problem.

Defendant:
Well, we probably could have eliminated it. In one of my emails, I said, “Let’s sit down and talk about it, and I’ll go step-by-step so we could eliminate this.”

Judge:
How were you planning to eliminate this?

Defendant:
Well, this was a security interest on a commercial lease. You don’t have to give interest on a security deposit. I looked up the statute, and it said only on residential, not commercial. I would have gone step-by-step explaining this.

Judge:
What happened?

Defendant:
Mr. Prasad was leaving in early April, and his lease expired at the end of May. I called him and told him I wanted to do a walkthrough with him to make sure everything was in accordance with the lease surrender.

Judge:
Okay.

Defendant:
I went in with a contractor who had done a lot of work for me in that building, and we went through it with Mr. Prasad. We started upstairs, and there were two panels of sheetrock missing. Mr. Prasad said he did that because he removed the panels to get more heat and cooling upstairs. So we had to pay $275 to replace the sheetrock panels.

Judge:
You have a receipt for that?

Defendant:
Yes.

Judge:
What else was wrong?

Defendant:
Apparently, Mr. Prasad had a client or a company give him some lighting, which he put in the store. There were nice fixtures in the front room, but in the back room, we had a hodgepodge of ceiling lights. One was made for a drop ceiling and was sticking down from the ceiling with exposed wires. Two other light fixtures had round circular fluorescent lights, one of which was held up by a piece of wire.

Judge:
Do you have pictures of this?

Defendant:
No, because I told him I was going to have to take them out, or he had to do it.

Judge:
Why didn’t you just bring the lights back to the way they were?

Defendant:
Those fixtures aren’t made anymore, and the ones that were there were 20 years old.

Judge:
So why didn’t you just save the ones you took down?

Defendant:
Because the fixtures that were there were already 20 years old. They don’t make those fixtures anymore.

Judge:
But you could have put in new recess lighting?

Defendant:
They were never wired to code. The building was never wired to code. Do you have evidence that it wasn’t wired to code when you were there?

Plaintiff:
No, but I can show you one of the light fixtures that were there.

Judge:
A picture of a light fixture is not going to tell me that the building wasn’t wired to code. What about the smoke alarm rewiring?

Defendant:
Well, the plaintiff wired the smoke alarm into the building. When he left, he took it out, and that caused problems.

Judge:
You can’t remove something like that when it’s part of the building.

Defendant:
It was part of the building, and it caused issues. The monitoring system needed to be replaced because wires were cut and pieces were missing.

Judge:
I agree with you on that. The alarm system became part of the building and needed to be maintained. So what happened when he left?

Defendant:
When he left, the alarm system was damaged, and we had to replace it. The new tenant had to deal with it.

Judge:
So you're keeping the security deposit because of these repairs?

Defendant:
Yes. And because of the changes he made to the lighting and other fixtures.

Judge:
Okay. Based on what I’ve heard, I find that the $1,500 security deposit has been used up in bringing the place back to code, and since this is a commercial lease, it doesn’t require compound interest. Therefore, my verdict in this case is for the defendant.

Defendant:
Thank you, Your Honor.

Judge:
All right, the plaintiff comes out with nothing.

Plaintiff (Cuk Prad):
I think justice is not served. I don’t understand why I have to pay for an alarm system I own, and I have to pay to repair it, even though I left it in good condition.

Judge:
Why didn’t you sit down with him to go over everything step by step?

Plaintiff:
We tried, but he wasn’t interested. After 20 years, I thought he’d be reasonable.

Judge:
If he would have read the lease in the beginning, none of this would have happened.

Plaintiff:
Right. If he would have sat down and gone over everything with me, it could have been worked out.

Judge:
How come you couldn’t get him to sit down and go over everything with you?

Plaintiff:
I guess he didn’t have the time.

Judge:
What’s a fixture and what’s not a fixture? In most states, it comes down to intent. Was it the intent of both parties to make something part of the building when the tenant leaves?   Judge: What happened with the smoke alarm rewiring?
Defendant (Edward Catalinus): Because the plaintiff wired the smoke alarm to the building so tightly into the building, can the plaintiff remove the smoke alarm when the plaintiff leaves?
Plaintiff (Cuk Prad): What do you think?
Judge: If it affects the safety of the rest of the tenants in the building, then no. But if it doesn’t…
Defendant (Edward Catalinus): Well, it clearly does. That’s what a smoke alarm is for.
Judge: But if it's in their—if it’s in their own apartment?
Defendant (Edward Catalinus): Well no, it’s a commercial space.
Judge: So, at a point, does it become a fixture in the building, part of the building?
Defendant (Edward Catalinus): I would think so, yes.
Judge: So tough luck. I mean, you put it in and you can use it for as long as you're there, but when you leave, you can't remove it. Right? That seems reasonable to me. Going inside the courtroom, there was no smoke alarm in the building. There were smoke detectors in the building, but at some later date, the town required a central monitoring system with a dial-up in case of a fire. He did put that in, along with a burglar alarm. But after the new tenant moved in, she went to hook up the monitoring system with a company, and they came in and said it had to be replaced because there was not functioning. Wires were cut, pieces were missing.
Judge: So then why would you be entitled to keep anything more than what it takes to remove it and put one in for your new tenant or tell your tenant to put her on?
Defendant (Edward Catalinus): Well, because I looked at it as an addition to the building. He had to leave when he—and when he left, wires were cut, pieces were missing, and it shorted out the panel and it had to be replaced.
Judge: You have a surrender clause, which is typical in a lease, that says that you'll surrender the premises together with any alterations, additions, and improvements, including all plumbing fixtures and other similar installations which may have been made, except movable furniture, movable trade fixtures, carpeting, cabinetry, lighting fixtures purchased at the sole expense of the tenant.
Judge: Alright. I kind of agree with you. Once you make the alarm part of the place, it’s part of the place, and it needs to be in working order.
Judge: Based on what I have heard, I find that well over the $1,500 security deposit has been taken up with bringing the place back up to code. And this commercial lease doesn’t require compound interest on the security deposit. Therefore, my verdict in this case is for the defendant.

Judge: Alright, Mr. Hodge, Ms. Gorman is your niece?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Wow, okay. And how—how so? Like, your—?

Plaintiff: My sister's daughter.

Judge: Okay. And, um, the two of you were visiting—I guess this happened when?

Plaintiff: Uh, 11/23/17.

Judge: Thanksgiving?

Plaintiff: Thanksgiving, yeah.

Judge: Alright. So, you're visiting your mother?

Plaintiff: I was at my mom's house, yes.

Judge: And she comes over to visit her grandmother, right? And what happens, according to you?

Plaintiff: A little verbal argument. And, uh, my niece made a comment to me about something. I had just gotten out of the hospital that day, actually. And my niece made a comment to me that I should have died in the hospital.

Judge: Okay, and it was—that sounds, to my trained ear, that sounds like you two already had a problem. So what was your pro—? You didn't get along with your niece?

Plaintiff: Uh, we've had our differences over the years. Uh, minor arguments, little tiffs over family issues and stuff like that.

Judge: Okay, and so she tells you you should have died in the hospital. And then what happened?

Plaintiff: Uh, we got into a little bit more of an argument. She said a couple more things, and—

Judge: How old is Grandma?

Plaintiff: Mom?

Judge: Mom.

Plaintiff: At the time, she was 86.

Judge: Okay, that's pleasant. It's Thanksgiving. We're at the home of an 86-year-old, and the two of you engage in this.

Judge (to Defendant): What did you say to him? Did you say to him, "I wish you died in the hospital?"

Defendant: No, I did not say anything.

Judge: What was it you said that caused the problem?

Defendant: We were arguing because he came home.

Judge: What were you arguing about?

Defendant: About him not feeding my grandmother. She was in bed, laying in bed at almost midnight, crying that she hasn't eaten all day.

Judge: At midnight?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: So, didn't all this happen—did it happen before midnight?

Plaintiff: I had come home from the hospital around maybe 8:00.

Judge: Yeah, and what time were you visiting?

Defendant: After that. Around 11:00 p.m.

Judge: Yes?

Defendant: I came home from dinner with my parents that night.

Judge: Okay, and you were visiting your grandmother at 11:00?

Defendant: Yes, because I went to go see her to pay my respects to her on Thanksgiving.

Judge: Okay, and then you get there, and then she says, "I haven't been fed all day"?

Defendant: Yeah, she was laying in bed crying. And I asked her what had happened, and she said that he was complaining since he got home from the hospital that there was no toilet paper in the house.

Judge: Okay.

Defendant: And I feel like that shouldn’t be her responsibility.

Judge: He was in the hospital.

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Yes, he just had a heart attack. But he also has two kids that could be helping her as well.

Judge: Okay, so what did you say to him?

Defendant: I didn't say anything—we got into a verbal dispute.

Judge: Obviously, you got into a verbal dispute. And then what happened?

Defendant: Okay, and we—one thing led to another, and I left.

Judge: And then what happened?

Defendant: And then he accused me of damaging his vehicle.

Judge: Okay, you tell me what you say happened. Go ahead.

Plaintiff: The argument—she made the statement about, you know, that I should have passed away in the hospital.

Judge: By the way, had you left your mother, your 86-year-old mother, without food between 8:00 and midnight?

Plaintiff: I was in the hospital for 10 days. But my daughter—

Judge: (to Plaintiff’s daughter) Stand up, please. Come forward.

Judge: Were you living in that house or staying in that house, or were you there for Thanksgiving?

Daughter: No, I was visiting.

Judge: When did you visit there? What time?

Daughter: I got there about 11:30.

Judge: While the fight was going on?

Daughter: At 11:30.

Judge: And everybody just visits Grandma at 11:30? Grandma doesn’t sleep?

Daughter: No, she stays up all night, actually.

Judge: Okay, so you go to visit Grandma at 11:30, and the fight's going on?

Daughter: Yeah.    Judge: I'm finding in favor of the plaintiff in this case. I'm awarding him the remainder after the $300 he's already received, for a total of $1,650.

Judge: Verdict for the plaintiff. Good luck, folks.

Judge: "Miss Daniels, 300k is what you have in the bank. How much money are you making annually?"
Defendant: "Well, it kind of just depends on the year and how many promotions I get, um, how many companies want to invest in me, so it just depends."
Judge: "When are you going to answer my question?"
Defendant: "Judge, that's a... it's a difficult question for me because, you know, sometimes I can have a promotion that's 500 bucks or I can have a promotion that's 50,000 plus."

JUDGE (QUESTIONING PLAINTIFF)

How long was the defendant renting the space?

PLAINTIFF: About a year and a half.

Why did you file for eviction?

PLAINTIFF: The defendant was late on rent, specifically for July and August 2018. Also, there were complaints about the smell from acrylic nails, which she promised to fix with ventilation but didn’t.

JUDGE (QUESTIONING DEFENDANT)

Did you pay rent for July and August 2018?

DEFENDANT: No, because I received a notice to quit.

What happened with the ventilation issue?

DEFENDANT: My workers stood their ground because they believed they were in the right. The plaintiff came in one day, threw down her purse, and started searching through my drawers.

JUDGE (REVIEWING LANDLORD-TENANT COURT AGREEMENT)

The agreement required the defendant to pay $1,665.28 by September 5th. Did she pay on time?

DEFENDANT: Yes, I personally put the check in her mailbox, and I have a photo as proof.

JUDGE: (Reviewing evidence) The payment was made on time.

JUDGE (REVIEWING PROPERTY CONDITION UPON VACATING)

The agreement required the defendant to leave the premises "broom clean" and return the keys. Did she comply?

PLAINTIFF: No, the place was a mess. There was garbage, furniture left outside, and items abandoned inside.

JUDGE (QUESTIONING DEFENDANT)

Why did you leave trash on the sidewalk?

DEFENDANT: That’s where we always put our trash. I had no help moving everything.

JUDGE: That’s not an excuse. You know this would cause fines and problems for the property owner.

JUDGE (REVIEWING ADDITIONAL EVIDENCE)

Photos show garbage, leftover alcohol bottles, nail polish, and debris inside the property.

(To DEFENDANT) You knew you had an agreement requiring the place to be clean. Now, because of your actions, the plaintiff is suing for back rent as well.

JUDGE (FINAL RULING)

The plaintiff wins the case. The defendant did not comply with the agreement and is responsible for the damages and unpaid rent.

Judge: "What is a flipper exactly?"

Defendant: "So basically what you do is you purchase a home, fix it up, and then you sell it."

Judge: "Okay, that sounds like a nice little income."

Defendant: "Correct."

Judge: "Right. How much are you making?"

Judge: No?

Plaintiff: Nope.

The plaintiff began harassing him and called him 24 times a day, to the point where he had to change his number. Next thing he knows, he's getting sued for gifts she gave him during the relationship. Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: You are suing Javier Dorot—how do you pronounce your name?

Defendant: Javier Dorot.

Plaintiff: We met, we talked, we seemed to hit it off. We started seeing each other. I would come over to his apartment. I started staying over. His birthday came up, we went to a party.

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And his birthday was when?

Judge: So then what happened?

But I would pray with him while I was there. So I bought prayer rugs because his rug wasn’t that clean.

Judge: Okay, let’s skip past that. When do you start giving him money?

Plaintiff: End of September.

Judge: What happened?

Plaintiff: He told me some story about how his account got frozen, and he couldn’t get access to his money. I had maybe $100 on me, so I thought, "I don’t want to leave you without money." I gave him $75 until he could get to his money.

Judge: And what did he say?

Plaintiff: He was grateful, said it was kind and thanked me.

Judge: Then you loaned him another $500. When did that happen?

Plaintiff: The next couple of days.

Judge: He hadn't paid the $75 back yet, and you still loaned him another $500?

Judge: Sounds like a him problem, not a you problem.

Plaintiff: I know, I know.

Judge: Did you have him sign any promissory notes?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: Did you text him or record him acknowledging the loan?

Plaintiff: No, I wasn’t thinking.

Judge: What have you learned watching this show for 18 years?

Plaintiff: I know, I know.

Judge: Go on.

Plaintiff: I loaned him the $500.

Judge: Then what happened?

Plaintiff: We started having conversations, but he kept blowing up at different things I was saying. He would fly off the handle.

Judge: Who broke up with whom?

Plaintiff: I broke up with him.

Judge: What did he say?

Judge: And what was his reaction?

Plaintiff: He said, "You don’t really care about me, you’re so petty."

Defendant: I’m not going to say she wasn’t generous—she was. From the very beginning, she was showering me with gifts. She brought roses, a comforter, a TV, everything.

Defendant: She just brought it to me, opened it, and gave it to me. She didn’t say it was a gift, but I assumed it was.

Judge: What about the money?

Defendant: She offered it to me.

Judge: You thought it was a gift?

Defendant: Yes. She gave me everything else, so I assumed she was just helping me. The "loan" came up only after I broke up with her.

Judge: When did you break up with her?

Defendant: Early November.

Judge: How did you meet him?

Judge: Were you incarcerated?

Plaintiff: Yes, for drugs.

Judge: I’m ordering him to pay you $575. He’s also to return the comforter and other items through a third party.

Defendant: That’s fine.

Judge: Let’s move on.

dialogue:
Judge: All parties, please raise your right hands. Welcome back to the People's Court. Next case on the docket: the plaintiff wants the defendant to pay up on a loan, and he doesn't care that they've known each other for 29 years. But the defendant says he doesn't owe the plaintiff anything; he's making it up. It's the case of "Should Old Acquaintance Be Forgot."

Judge: Shannon Grant?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Okay, you are suing Richard Green for $1,325 that you want paid to you for parking tickets, impound fees, transportation, and lost wages as a result of tickets that the defendant got on a car of yours—car of his that you put in your name?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: What are you doing doing that? Why did you do that?

Plaintiff: When you know somebody for over half your life, you grew up with them, you know their mother, father, and of course, when people just get married and have kids, and they ask for your help because of family problems... You know, I was going through family problems at the same time, and I was living on my own. So when he came to me reaching out, I felt deep inside, like, you know what? If my mother wasn't there to help me and I'm busting my behind working like he was at the time, I'd want a friend to do that for me.

Judge: Yeah, but why did he need you to do that for him?

Plaintiff: He had an accident with his brother's van, and it wasn't his fault, he said, or something like that. And there was a conflict within the family business that he worked in with them helping him get a car on the road.

Judge: Why does somebody have to help him get a car? He's a grown man. First things first, just give me the answer. I know the answer is going to be because he has bad credit, right? That's going to be the answer.

Plaintiff: Basically.

Judge: Okay, how do you get bad credit?

Plaintiff: Um... basically not paying your bills.

Judge: Paying bills. I believe it wasn't just bad credit, though. It was worse than that.

Plaintiff: Well, that's enough to not want to put a car in your name that he's driving because if he gets tickets, he's not going to pay them, right?

Plaintiff: You're right.

Judge: All right. So you decide to put a car he's driving in your name, and what happens?

Plaintiff: And of course, like, if he ends up hitting a truckload of orphans, who do you think gets sued?

Judge: You would.

Plaintiff: Okay.

Judge: All right, so what happens?

Plaintiff: What happened was it was supposed to be for a short period of time until he could just get on his feet, about three months, and four months, really. It was a six-month ordeal with the insurance.

Plaintiff: Long story short, within a two-month period, I couldn't find Rich.

Judge: You couldn't find him?

Plaintiff: Yeah.

Judge: What are you talking about? This guy is like your blood brother, your best friend, who you have to... I'm making fun of you right now, so I don't know why you're chuckling. Okay, your best friend who you can't help but help out in his time of need because you've grown up together—how do you not find him?

Plaintiff: I'm trying to avoid it, but uh... it's drugs.

Judge: Who?

Plaintiff: Who’s it was because of drugs?

Judge: Whose drug use?

Plaintiff: It was because of drug use.

Judge: Whose drug use?

Plaintiff: Everybody else understands the question I'm asking, right? Whose drug use?

Plaintiff: He couldn't be contacted at his house or where he was at because his family and nobody had contact with him. He ran away from everybody.

Judge: Okay, because of drug use?

Plaintiff: His, yes.

Judge: Okay, so now you can't find him. Did you know that he had a drug problem?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: Well, apparently, you didn't know him very well to be putting the car in your name. So now he's run off, and what? Who's the lady next to you?

Plaintiff: This is my fiancée.

Judge: What does she think about all this?

Plaintiff's Fiancée: [gives a dirty look]

Plaintiff: Well, the thing—

Judge: Oh, she just gave you a dirty look. Go ahead.

Plaintiff: The thing is, I honestly would have never believed that my friend would have ever put me through this...

Judge: And yet here you are.

Plaintiff: Here I am.

Judge: Mr. Green, did you ever have a car in his name?

Defendant: No, ma’am.

Judge: Did you get parking tickets on a car registered in his name?
Judge: So, Mr. Green, let me hear from you. Did you ever have this car in your possession?

Defendant: No, Your Honor. I never had a car in his name, and I don’t know what he’s talking about.

Judge: You’re saying you never drove this car?

Defendant: Never. He never gave me a car; I never asked him to register anything for me.

Judge: Mr. Grant, do you have any proof that this car was registered under your name for him?

Plaintiff: Yes, Your Honor. Here’s the title, and here are the parking tickets.

Judge: [looking at documents] So, these parking tickets—do you have any proof that he was the one driving when they were issued?

Plaintiff: Well, I mean, the car was for him. I wasn’t the one driving it.

Judge: That’s not enough. You need something connecting him directly to these tickets.

Plaintiff: Your Honor, why would I pay for someone else’s car if it wasn’t his?

Defendant: That’s what I’m saying! I don’t know why he did that.

Judge: Okay, Mr. Green, did you know about these tickets before this lawsuit?

Defendant: No. This is the first I’m hearing about it.

Plaintiff: That’s a lie, Your Honor. I tried reaching him, and he ignored me. He knew.

Judge: Mr. Green, did you avoid him?

Defendant: No. I was dealing with personal issues, and we lost touch, but I didn’t run away from him.

Judge: Mr. Grant, you mentioned something about drugs. Are you claiming that Mr. Green was using drugs at the time?

Plaintiff: Yes, Your Honor. That’s why he disappeared.

Judge: Mr. Green, do you have a history of drug use?

Defendant: That’s personal.

Judge: I understand that, but it’s relevant. Did you have a drug problem at the time?

Defendant: I had some struggles, but that doesn’t mean I owe him money.

Plaintiff: Your Honor, he’s dodging responsibility.

Judge: Mr. Grant, I get why you’re frustrated, but I need direct proof linking him to the debt. Right now, I see a car in your name, tickets in your name, but no proof that he was the one driving it.

Plaintiff: Your Honor, why would I just make this up?

Judge: People make things up all the time in court. I need proof.

Plaintiff's Fiancée: He knew what he was doing. He’s playing innocent now.

Judge: I understand your frustration, but the law requires evidence. Mr. Grant, unless you have something more, I can’t rule in your favor.

Plaintiff: But—

Judge: My ruling is for the defendant. Case dismissed.
Defendant: No, ma’am.

Judge: So you say he's making this whole thing up?

Defendant: I have no clue what he's talking about. I never asked him to put a car in his name. This whole thing is ridiculous.

Judge: Well, we’re going to find out. Do you have any proof of the tickets and impound fees?

Plaintiff: Yes, I have all the paperwork right here.

Judge: Good. Let me see it.

Judge: "But you had told him, 'I'm pregnant eight months, I didn't find out 'til I was six months.' You told him anyway. So what is this about breaking up a marriage? You’d already told him you were pregnant."

Defendant (Person1): "Because I was with the other guy, and I had been living with him for a while, and I thought I was gonna keep living with him, but we broke up."

Judge: "And this is the other man that was at the hospital when Lilian was born?"

Defendant: "Yes, Your Honor."

Judge: "Did you ever tell this other man that he was Lilian's biological father?"

Defendant: "No, I did not."

Judge: "So why not allow the man who supposedly is her biological father to be present for the birth, or at least know she's in the world?"

Ms. Willard: "That was my fault, Your Honor."

Judge: Nicoletta Longo, you are suing Natalie Nora for $2,730 for June, July, and August rent—her half of it—that, according to you, she didn’t pay. What’s going on here?

Plaintiff: So basically, it started when Natalie and I were friends in high school, and we ended up going to the same college in Boston. Freshman year, we decided to do the dorm on campus, and after that, for sophomore year, we decided we wanted to get an apartment together.

Judge: Okay. In freshman year, did you two get along?

Plaintiff: Yeah.

Judge: You were right in each other’s faces in the dorms?

Plaintiff: Exactly.

Judge: Everything was hunky-dory?

Plaintiff: So hunky-dory that we decided to get an apartment together.

Judge: Exactly. All right, so you get an apartment together. It’s a one-bedroom apartment?

Plaintiff: Yes, ma’am.

Judge: So each of you have a twin bed in the bedroom?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: And then there’s a living room?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Kitchen?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: Okay. And each of your rent is $910?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: All right. You move in together, everything’s great?

Plaintiff: Yes, good friends.

Judge: Best friends. Wow. So sad. All right, so now you’re together in an apartment in your sophomore year, and what happens?

Plaintiff: So at the beginning, everything was going good. I would say around maybe early December, we started just little arguments more and more, but everything was still—

Judge: What was it about?

Plaintiff: What do you think? It was more for me—I just saw her life going in different directions. I think our living styles were different.

Judge: Okay.

Plaintiff: I’m more of a neat freak, and I know this, and she’s a little messier than me.

Judge: But didn’t you guys know that freshman year?

Plaintiff: We did.

Judge: You did?

Plaintiff: But things just started—we just started bickering off of that.

Judge: It got testy. I read the text.

Defendant: If I may, though, prior to those text messages, there was one incident which I kind of mark as the starting point of all of this falling down. She decided to go to Virginia, I believe, for four days throughout the weekend, and I worked doubles—I was working over 70 hours a week while going to school.

Judge: Okay.

Defendant: And we had the dog in the apartment.

Judge: What do you mean by “we had the dog”?

Defendant: So her uncle said that when we moved into an apartment together, he would help us get a dog. So he purchased the dog for us. We drove to Maryland together over the summer and got the dog—like at six weeks old maybe or something.

Judge: What a bad idea this is.

Defendant: And then—

Judge: Was there some understanding about whose dog it was?

Plaintiff: So yeah, I mean, I always assumed that since her uncle paid for it, you know, it’s her dog, whatever.

Defendant: But then—

Judge: But then you guys were sharing the expenses?

Plaintiff: Yes.

Judge: So you split the vet fees?

Defendant: Yes, we split them until February, when things got sour.

Judge: Okay. So about the Virginia thing—you were starting?

Defendant: Yeah. So I worked all Thursday through Sunday. My schedule was doubles pretty much Thursday through Sunday at this place, so I would be gone 12, 13 hours a day. So she was going to be gone Thursday through Sunday. I simply asked a question—

Judge: Okay.

Defendant: “Is there any way we can contact one of our friends to come to the apartment and help let the dog out? He’s a six-month-old puppy; we don’t want to leave him in the apartment all day long.”

Judge: Which is why sophomores shouldn’t have dogs. That’s my theory. My personal theory is you’ve got plenty of time for responsibility later. I can’t tell you how short this little window you’ve got going on here is.

Defendant: So she just got upset, I guess, by that question, and she said that, “If it’s going to be such a big problem for our dog to be staying in our apartment, I’ll just have my mother drive all the way up from Connecticut and take him home for the weekend.”

Judge: Okay.

Defendant: So I was like, “Okay,” taking a little aback, because there was a little bit of an attitude there.

Judge: Okay.

Defendant: She started FaceTiming her boyfriend, complaining about that.

Judge: About what?

Defendant: About the dog.

Judge: How do you know?

Defendant: Because I could hear.

Judge: Was she texting him or was she talking to him?

Defendant: She was talking to him on the phone.

Judge: Go on.

Defendant: So I knocked on the door and I said, “If we’re going to be roommates, not friends, let me know, because there’s been a distance between us lately.” And she was like, “Don’t worry, we’ve been roommates for the past six months anyway.”

Judge: So then?

Defendant: That’s when I said, “Okay, I told her to her face that I would be moving out in May.”

Judge: Okay, but you had a lease until August 31st.

Defendant: Yes, but I gave her three options.

Judge: Why should she take you off the lease?

Defendant: Because her boyfriend had been living there.

Judge: Okay, stop. If you guys think I’m going to sit here and try to figure out who was sleeping with who, what days, how loudly, whether it was your freshman year or your sophomore year, you are out of your minds. It’s not going to happen.

Defendant: I know.

Judge: Here’s what I know. Your name’s on a legal contract.

Defendant: I know.

Judge: I find in favor of the plaintiff in this case in the amount of $2,730, minus the $500 security deposit. Verdict for the plaintiff in the amount of $2,230. Good luck, folks.

Defendant: Thank you.

Judge: Make sure you get that other $500 from the boyfriend.

Judge: How many times have you been convicted?

Defendant: Probably like three times.

Judge: What were the others?

Defendant: Um, burglary and breaking and entering.

Plaintiff: I didn’t know that.

Judge: Well, of course, you didn’t know that, because unless you run a criminal records check on a guy, then you are just assuming that everything’s hunky dory, aren’t you?

Defendant: She knows that though from like where I live at and like—

Judge: How dare you? How dare you suggest that where you live means you’re going to be a criminal? How dare you insult the people of your community in that fashion?

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hands.

Judge: Welcome back to the People's Court. Next case on the docket: the plaintiff helps people get car insurance, and the defendant stiffed him. But the defendant says the guy’s a rip-off artist. It’s the case of “You’re in bad hands.”

Judge: Thank you, Douglas. Okay, David Z. Vandervell, doing business as Ure One Investments and Insurance, you are suing... You want to be referred to as Malcolm?

Defendant: Yes, please.

Judge: You are suing the defendant for $3,533.61 in insurance fees that you say he owes you. What happened here?

Plaintiff: Your Honor, Mr. Malcolm came with his cousin in 2015. They needed car insurance. The cousin wasn’t working, and they couldn’t get insurance elsewhere. I specialize in assigned risk insurance.

Judge: So you specialize in selling insurance to people who would have a hard time getting affordable insurance?

Plaintiff: Yes. Not those who can't get insurance, but those who can't get affordable insurance.

Judge: Why were you having trouble getting conventional insurance?

Defendant: Tickets.

Judge: What was it?

Defendant: Well, it was just that I hadn’t had a car insured in some time, and I did have a previous suspension for unpaid tickets.

Judge: Okay. So just tell me what happened in this case. You sold him insurance on what date?

Plaintiff: September 5, 2015.

Judge: And you sold him insurance for a year. The insurance was going to cost how much?

Plaintiff: $2,770 plus $50, Your Honor.

Judge: So then how much are you charging in finance?

Plaintiff: What we do is take a risk. Until the ninth month that they pay consecutively, if they cancel or drop out, we lose money because we pay for months 10, 11, and 12 upfront.

Judge: So until the 10th month, not the 9th month?

Plaintiff: Right.

Judge: So his monthly payments were supposed to be what?

Plaintiff: The first year, it came down to $236.

Judge: So then, like, the last two payments of $236 would be the interest charges for financing. All right. So now, in that first year, they find out there’s a teenager in the house, and they raise his insurance. How much?

Plaintiff: $458.

Judge: Okay. From the inception of the insurance?

Plaintiff: Yes. I asked him many times for a letter from the dean or whoever is in charge to prove that the young lady is studying at least 22 hours a week.

Judge: And then what did you do? Did you ever tell your daughter she had to get proof she was living in Albany?

Defendant: I guess because it was during her first year, she was getting situated in school. The process got drawn out, and I never actually followed through to get the information he requested.

Judge: So now, the year ends. What happened?

Plaintiff: At the end of the year, they owed me $766.43 from payments they had not made.

Judge: But how do you get to this $3,533?

Plaintiff: That’s very simple, Your Honor. I kept calling Mr. Malcolm and his cousin. I said, “Guys, we have a new policy coming in on September 5. You have to pay the back amount plus the future amount.”

Judge: What happened on September 5?

Defendant: I didn’t go in. My cousin went in to make the payment.

Judge: And what was the payment for?

Defendant: To keep the policy from being canceled.

Judge: So year two kicks in, but you guys still owe him money. What’s your defense?

Defendant: My defense is that even though we dealt with David as the broker, I would still receive statements from the insurance company. From what I received, the amount I owed was different from what he said.

Judge: That’s because you have to pay finance charges. Show me the difference.

Defendant: This is the last statement I received from the insurance company. At the time of cancellation, it shows a balance.

Judge: Did the insurance get canceled?

Defendant: I let it lapse.

Judge: How come?

Defendant: Because I knew that after having insurance for a year with no major violations, I could get something more affordable.

Judge: So you’re suspicious because this notice says the premium due is $1,699, but you were paying $2,770 for the year, which would be an additional $1,071 in finance charges. Why?

Plaintiff: I prepaid two months. The difference was $60.99 because I had already prepaid part of his insurance.

Judge: According to your invoice, you’re out $1,463.61. That’s the insurance he hasn’t paid for. Why are you now asking for $3,533?

Plaintiff: Your Honor, the insurance company still wants more money.

Judge: But you haven't proven that. I’m ruling in favor of the plaintiff for $1,463.61. You have to pay that because the man is out that amount.

Judge: Verdict for the plaintiff in the amount of $1,463.61.

Judge:
This is the plaintiff, Wendy Zuckerman. She says the defendant, her former landlord, went to Argentina and basically stole her security deposit. This guy just got mad when she told him she was moving out. He refuses to communicate with her. She wants the money he owes her and is happy she served him with papers to appear in court today. She is seeking the $4,100 she is rightfully owed.

He is accused of non-communication.

The defendant has filed a counter-suit for $1,575 for money owed for additional damages.

All parties, please raise your right hands.

Welcome back to The People’s Court. Next case on the docket: the plaintiff says the defendant, her landlord, left for Argentina and stole her security deposit. The defendant says the apartment was a mess.

It’s the case of Buenos Aires, Argentina – Security Deposit.

Judge:
Okay, Miss Zuckerman, you are suing your former landlord for $4,100. You want the return of your security deposit, plus you feel that you overpaid rent during the time that you were there.

That is correct, Your Honor.

He has even falsely accused me of something.

On the day of my move-out, as we were walking out the front door, my son and I had some of my belongings in our hands. He suddenly said, “Hey, hey, you! Someone stole my tools out of my garage!”

Judge:
Okay…

Plaintiff:
I was shocked. He then said, “Yeah, I see your face.”

Judge:
Show me how your mouth looked.

Plaintiff:
(Opens mouth wide)

Judge:
Okay, that looked good—agape.

Plaintiff:
He then said, “I know you did it, but I can’t prove it. But I know you did it, or someone you know did it, or your friends did it.”

At that point, I was honestly shaken. I wasn’t expecting it. It was like a sneak attack—he came right out of his garage.

Also, when I was moving my belongings, he made a point of moving his car just a few inches away from a bush, so my son and I had to either push a bush out of the way to carry our belongings out to my car or walk around two-foot-tall grass.

Defendant:
I’m not going to be harassed!

Plaintiff:
Harassed? By who?

Defendant:
By you.

Plaintiff:
By me?

Defendant:
Yes.

Plaintiff:
Why?

Defendant:
Well, why don’t you ask my friends where the tools are that you—you accused us of stealing?

Judge:
Okay, okay. Let’s focus.

Plaintiff:
Who are you?

Defendant’s Friend:
I’m his friend, who you accused.

Plaintiff:
I don’t even know you!

Oh my God. Didn’t you just tell her the other day, “I think your friend stole the tools” when I was by myself?

Do you think that I could have predicted that you’d end up in court based on how hostile everything was?

Plaintiff:
I understand why I want my security deposit back.

Judge:
Right. So let’s talk about it.    Judge:
Right. So let’s talk about it.

Defendant:
The place looks very good in the video she took when she moved in. She told me she was going to have a dog in there. I went along with it and I told her—generally, and we’ve been renting for many, many years—generally, there is a payment every month for a pet. We decided to avoid that, to void that, and we didn’t charge anything for the dog. But then a month later, I learned that she had two cats in there.

Judge:
How did you learn that?

Defendant:
We went up there.

Judge:
Okay. Are you folks—Is this a two-family house?

Defendant:
Yes.

Judge:
And you live downstairs?

Defendant:
Yes.

Judge:
Okay.

Defendant:
She, uh—In fact, at one point, she asked us to take care of the cats.

Judge:
Okay. So there’s no dispute that you had cats?

Plaintiff:
I never tried to conceal them or hide them.

Judge:
So, and is it accurate that the cats were adopted by you after you moved in?

Plaintiff:
No, they’ve been with me for years, actually.

Judge:
This was not a secret at the time?

Plaintiff:
No.

Judge:
That wasn’t my question. Is it accurate that you moved into the place with one dog and two cats?

Plaintiff:
That is correct.

Judge:
Or did the two cats come later?

Plaintiff:
No, I moved in with them.

Judge:
Did you ever tell him that you had two cats?

Plaintiff:
I told the leasing agent who was there at the time of the signing of the lease.

Judge:
Okay. So, and according to you, you didn’t know about the cats?

Defendant:
No. At some point, she asked me to take care of the cats.

Judge:
So you knew about the cats?

Defendant:
Yes.

Judge:
Did you ever say to her, “You owe me another $100 in rent, $50 for each cat”?

Defendant:
No.

Judge:
So if a landlord just starts harassing you, saying, “I want you to do this, I want you to do that” three months into a one-year lease, can you break the lease, get your deposit back, and walk away scot-free?

Bystander:
No, you can’t because they have it in writing.

Judge:
They do have it in writing. So therefore, when you have papers going to court, the judge is going to see that. And you signed on that, correct?

Bystander:
Fair enough.

Judge:
But at a point, if they harass you, can you break that lease?

Bystander:
Harassment is never okay, but I don’t think you can break the lease.

Judge:
Okay. Going inside the courtroom.

Judge:
So you are—Here are the things you feel she owes you. You feel she owes you $275 for the oil bill for March through April. Do you dispute that?

Plaintiff:
No.

Judge:
All right. So then you would agree that you owe this amount, correct?

Plaintiff:
Right.

Judge:
Okay. Let’s talk about something else. Let’s talk about carpet cleaning and painting. I saw a video of a really clean apartment. Why—What is it? Do you have pictures to show me?

Defendant:
Not only the carpets, but I also have the bills from the carpet company.

Judge:
The bills from the carpet company?

Defendant:
Yes.

Judge:
What are they saying?

Defendant:
That there was a urine smell. Yes, they could not remove it. I had to change the carpet.

Plaintiff:
That happens with cats. Both of my cats are females and fixed and never spray.

Judge:
And I’ve yet to see a carpet cleaning company say the smell of cats can’t come out and recommends replacements. And they charged you $100 to come to your house?

Defendant:
Yes.

Judge:
What did they do? Did they clean?

Defendant:
They tried cleaning, but the smell didn’t come out.

Judge:
So did you pay them $100 to clean?

Defendant:
Yes.

Judge:
All right. So what you’re suing for is not new carpets, you’re suing for the two cleanings?

Defendant:
Yes, correct.

Judge:
All right. And then what—What’s the painting that would be required?

Plaintiff:
The painting—I have something to explain to you. The painting—He charged me $200, but then he put down that to remove the things on the wall, he wanted to charge me $150 extra. I didn’t pay him.

Judge:
Okay. Now I want to—I want to see pictures of the way she left it. Do you have pictures of the way she left it?

Defendant:
Yes.

Judge:
You were there 27 months, correct?

Plaintiff:
Correct.

Judge:
Okay. What is this a picture of?

Defendant:
Uh, the kid used to put stickers on the wall, and there were—

Judge:
Is that a wall?

Defendant:
Yeah.

Judge:
And what is that? What’s that dark mark?

Defendant:
It pulled the stickers, and it pulled the paint with it.

Judge:
Oh, look at that. Took the whole chunk out. What was that? What was on there?

Plaintiff:
It was one of those command strip hooks.

Judge:
Well, you didn’t put it up right. Those things work like a charm.

Defendant:
There were three or four of them.

Judge:
All right. And then what is this?

Defendant:
This is just her garbage that she put by the garbage.

Judge:
Is that her carpet she put out?

Defendant:
Yes.

Judge:
Okay. Maybe she just didn’t want it.

Plaintiff:
I didn’t want it.

Judge:
Okay. So it would appear to me that you owe the oil. That’s $275. It would appear to me that you owe the carpet cleaning. It would appear to me that you owe the painting because there were several places where drywall is ripped out, and somebody has to fix that. And I don’t think that $200 is an unreasonable request for that.
Judge:
The big chunk of money, the biggest chunk of money, and the problem that we’re having is the $2,600.

Defendant:
That’s for lost rent.

Judge:
Right. Because you say she broke the lease.

Plaintiff:
I gave my notice, your Honor.

Judge:
Okay. When did you give notice?

Plaintiff:
I told them in January that I would be leaving at the end of February.

Judge:
And when was your lease supposed to end?

Defendant:
April.

Judge:
So you left two months early.

Plaintiff:
Yes.

Judge:
Was there a written notice?

Plaintiff:
No, it was verbal.

Judge:
Do you agree that she gave you verbal notice in January?

Defendant:
Yes, but the lease required written notice.

Judge:
Did you attempt to re-rent the apartment?

Defendant:
Yes, but we weren’t able to find a tenant in time.

When did you start looking?

Defendant:
February.

Judge:
And when did you find a tenant?

Defendant:
April 1st.

So the unit was vacant for March and part of April?

Defendant:
Yes.

Judge:
Now, did you keep her security deposit when she moved out?

Defendant:
Yes, we applied it to the unpaid rent and damages.

Judge:
Okay. Here’s where we are. You did break the lease early, but you did give verbal notice, and the landlord attempted to re-rent the unit. However, in most cases, a landlord has to show that they made a reasonable effort to mitigate damages.

Defendant:
We did, your Honor. We listed the unit immediately.

Judge:
Right, and you found someone by April. Now, based on the lease agreement, she was responsible for rent through the end of her lease term. However, landlords can only claim lost rent if they made a reasonable effort to re-rent the unit. Plaintiff:
I don’t think that’s fair. I left the place in good condition.

Judge:

Plaintiff:
Okay.

Judge:
Here’s my ruling. The security deposit was $1,500, correct?

Defendant:
Yes.

Judge:
You are entitled to keep the $275 for the oil, the $100 for the carpet cleaning, and the $200 for the painting. That totals $575. Plaintiff:
So I don’t get any of my deposit back?

Judge:
No. The costs exceed the deposit amount. Case dismissed.

Judge: All parties, please raise your right hand. Welcome back to The People's Court. Next case on the docket: the plaintiff says that his landlord had it out for him because she didn't like his friend. But the defendant says the plaintiff and his friends smoked lots of pot and damaged the place. It's the case of "Smoking The Joint." Thank you. You're welcome.

Judge: Okay, Ricardo Torres, you are suing Karen Reyes for $650, the amount of your security deposit that you are saying she is wrongfully withholding. What happened?

Plaintiff: Around the month of September, I was looking to acquire a room, and I was hanging out with one of my friends, which so happens to be her neighbor. And, um, I see her bringing out the sign that says "Room for Rent," so I asked my friend if he knew Karen, and he said yes, that he would let her know that I was interested.

Judge: So you're interested, and you decide you're paying $450, and then what happens that you start paying $650?

Plaintiff: Um, I acquired, uh, she had a bigger room in the same apartment.

Judge: So then you're there for how long before the problem begins?

Plaintiff: I was there entirely for about seven months.

Judge: Okay, now at some point you decide to leave. Which is what month?

Plaintiff: March 30th.

Judge: March, okay. Now, when you leave, you tell her when? That look, I'm not staying.

Plaintiff: I told her about two weeks prior to that.

Judge: Because?

Plaintiff: And then she got mad because she felt like it wasn't enough notice.

Judge: Yes. All right. Do you have a lease?

Defendant: My lease is under my name.

Judge: Oh, do you have a lease with him, is what I meant, because you're a landlord to him.

Defendant: Yes. We didn't make a lease because he was just renting a room at that time.

Judge: I understand, but when you say your feeling is he gave me no notice, he gave me... okay, how much notice do you say he has to give you?

Defendant: Thirty days.

Judge: Says who? Says where? You don't have a lease. What are you talking about?

Defendant: One of the agreements when he rented the room.

Judge: Verbal? It was an agreement?

Defendant: Stop and listen. A verbal agreement or a written agreement?

Defendant: A verbal agreement.

Judge: Okay. Did you agree with her verbally that you would give her 30 days' notice before leaving?

Plaintiff: No.

Judge: Okay. Now you have a problem with that. See, when there is no lease, written lease, there's still a lease. You can have a verbal lease, but the law fixes what the terms are, not you. If you want terms outside of that, then you have to get them in writing and get both sides to sign it. The law where you're from, in the Bronx, he doesn't have to give you 30 days' notice. I don't get it, but that's how it is. So, yeah, if you want 30 days' notice, it better be in writing somewhere. Is it in writing anywhere? In an email? A text? Anything?

Defendant: No.

Judge: No. All right. But according to you, there's more. When he leaves, he ends up leaving the place damaged. Was he a good tenant while he lived there?

Defendant: No. I actually had to always, um, let him know the rent was due on the first.

Judge: That was one thing that was verbally said, that was agreed on? When was it always due?

Defendant: The first.

Judge: It would be the first. It'll be the morning, and you have to ask him in the afternoon because you have to give the rent to the owner?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: So when you say he would pay late, you mean late on the first?

Defendant: Late on the first. Sometime the second.

Judge: Okay. Were there any other problems?

Defendant: Um, he used to smoke around the house. He used to do spray paint in the house.

Judge: He used to smoke... cigarettes?

Defendant: No.

Judge: Marijuana?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Okay. Can you tell him to stop?

Defendant: I told him. That was one of the number one rules because I knew he was smoking, and that was one of the number one rules. I told him no smoking allowed in the house because I have a three-year-old asthmatic child. That was one of the rules. He said fine.

Judge: So why didn't you get rid of him when he was violating it? I was waiting. Why would you put your asthmatic child in that?

Defendant: To be completely honest, uh, overall, even though that was that one little problem, he told me he didn't smoke in the house. I was never around the house, to be honest. I was always working and in school.

Judge: What about your kid?

Defendant: He was in school.

Judge: So it was only basically the nights when he would be home?

Defendant: Every night when you're home, your kid can't breathe. No, never. Not every night. He couldn't breathe, obviously. He had his asthma machine. But, yes...

Judge: Where's the machine? Because this guy's smoking in the house. Why don't you just get rid of him?

Defendant: I was trying to tell him, you know, I asked him nicely.

Judge: So now, but according to you, he damaged the place?

Defendant: Yes.

Judge: Let me see the pictures of the damage.

Defendant: Everything has been fixed. I don't have any pictures. Everything was fixed.

Judge: So can a landlord get a tenant’s case in 2017 for smoking pot? Yes. Okay. Well, lady, do me a favor. Pay the man his $650 and learn how to be a landlord. Verdict to the plaintiff. Thank you.
